item.name: 10 Days in Asia
item.comment: [i]I have enjoyed the different 10 Days games I've played more than I thought I would, but the Asia map is probably my least favorite. I really don't like the bottlenecks that exist on this map; there can potentially be a lot of dead ends on this map. Also the map is basically cut in 2 by one country unless you use a boat or plane which makes you feel like you have very limited options on some of your turns. Our game devolved into everyone looking for a specific boat turn after turn without being able to change anything on our racks without having to replace a lot of tiles. I did enjoy the game, but I'd rather play any of the other maps over this one[/i]

item.name: 10 Days in Europe
item.comment: Highlights: - Quick and easy to learn/teach. - This is a great gateway/filler game. - This game could be used to help kids learn some basic geography. - This is a quick game (about 30 minutes) making it ideal for those nights when there is a time crunch. - Turns also play very fast, so there is not a lot of downtime.

item.name: 1775: Rebellion
item.comment:
Received in a math trade (5/15/14).
[i]- Great theme, with beautiful production values. - Simple game play and easy to teach, but man this game has lots of depth. - The card play for movement/ special actions is great. You can move any armies, but only a limited number and only so many spaces. - The dice based combat is perfect, units can flee (which you get back later) or you may be able to move an army to an adjacent space. - I could write a novel about how amazing this game is, if you are interested at all check out some of the reviews. - The 4p game has you play in teams: with each side being composed of 2 armies (The British Regulars and British Loyalists on one side and the Continental Army and Colonial Militia being the other). You each control an army and you decide how to move armies that contain at least one of your units making it very important to talk with your ally.[/i]

item.name: 7 Wonders
item.comment:
[i]- Beautiful artwork on the cards which helps the theme come through. - Plays well with 3+ players. - Quick playtime (under 45 minutes) even once you add more players. - Card drafting made extremely accessible, this is an easy game to teach. - I enjoy building a tableau of cards that builds on itself and allows you to obtain better cards. - There are enough different ways to win which helping to give this game good replay value. - Great game to begin/end a game night.[/i]
4 plays -> Cities 3 plays -> Leaders 11 plays -> Cities + Leaders

item.name: 7 Wonders: Cities
item.comment:
[i]I will mention that my wife really enjoys clean game design without lots of fiddlyness, so sometimes when we add an expansion to a game she does not care for it because they will typically add some amount of complexity. This was not the case with the 7 Wonders expansions. She really enjoyed both expansions because they did not break/or change the rules of the game. The expansions really extend and add to already existing powers/effects. Overall I really enjoy both expansions, and what they bring to the table.
However; if you are only going to get one I would get the Leaders expansion. I really like how the leader powers affect all the different phases of the game (resource generation, money, victory points, military strength, science, etc.).[/i]

item.name: 7 Wonders: Duel
item.comment:
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]First I have to admit that the hype surrounding this game has probably effected how I feel about it. I was expecting a similarly amaziing experience to the first time I played 7 Wonders and it actually kind of fell flat. I understand all the decisions that were made to add tension into the 2p game, but I'm not sure that I like them.
Specifically I'm talking about the alternate victory conditions, winning via military or science. While this adds a lot of interaction and tension in the game, there are times when your hands are tied and you need to select a card you don't want because you've already let your opponent collect too much military or science. This isn't really fun or very strategic, in fact it's pretty straight forward. There is also a fair bit of randomness in the game for 2 reasons, first you have o idea what the face down cards are so your opponent can get a huge boon if the right card gets revealed, on top of that 3 cards are removed from each age at the beginning of the round. It is surprising how much those 3 cards have effected our games, in one game one of the science symbols was completely out of the game and in another I was strapped for resources the whole game because a lot of resource cards were removed from the game. There are ways to help mitigate the luck found in the game which I'll highlight below:
- The drafting pyramids you build create some tense decisions when choosing which card to take, but also introduces a lot of randomness since you have no idea which card(s) you'll be revealing for your opponent. - The wonders do help mitigate the randomness of the game, especially the wonders that give you another turn. - You can mitigate a lack of resources if you focus on getting cards that have the upgrade symbols. - The guilds are quite powerful because you can choose whether to use your tableau of cards or your opponents when figuring out the VP/coins that are generated.
Where does that leave me, I'm really not sure. Considering how much my family enjoys 7 Wonders (one of my son's favorites) I'm willing to give 7W Duel more plays and my gut feeling is that the more I play the less random the game will feel. In the end I think I'll always prefer 7 Wonders, but it is nice to have a quick, 2 player version in our collection. It'll be interesting how I feel about this one a year from now.[/i]

item.name: 7 Wonders: Leaders
item.comment:
Christmas gift 2014 (Family)
[i]See Cities.[/i]

item.name: 7 Wonders: Wonder Pack
item.comment: [i]I enjoy having more civ boards to choose from, but they are by no means necessary. My favorite by far is the Great Wall of China because you can build the wonders in any order.[/i]

item.name: Abyss
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Abyss[/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 1/12/15. (Received Wasabi)
My thoughts:
[i]- One of the most beautiful games I have ever seen, really, the art is amazing. - Top notch components as well (especially the pearls and seashell cups to hold them). - Some interesting interactions between the lords/locations.
Basically Abyss is a set collection game with all kinds of special abilities which effect game play and scoring, but a lot of your strategy is dictated by the randomness of the lord/location draws. I prefer games like Battle Line or Morels which allow for more long term planning and bluffing; games where you have knowledge of what cards are available and knowing you will most likely see every card in the game.
In my opinion Abyss is an average game with beautiful artwork. I think it works well as a family game if you are looking for a relatively light game with a fair amount of randomness. For me the decision space felt too constrained and not very deep.[/i]
item.conditiontext: Excellent condition, only played once.

item.name: The Adventurers: The Pyramid of Horus
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]The Adventurers: Pyramid of Horus[/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 1/12/15. (Received Power Grid)
My thoughts:
[i]I would describe this as Incan Gold with unnecessary extra rules and fluff which causes the game to overstay it's welcome (takes about an hour). A game I was happy to trade away and one I would not play again.[/i]
item.conditiontext: Very good condition, only played a few times.

item.name: Agricola
item.comment:
Received in a trade (7/17/14). I traded away Castles of Burgundy.
[i]- I really enjoy balancing the feeding of your people with managing the rest of your farm. - Theme: I really enjoy building a farm and seeing how everything looks at the end of the game. - Beautiful artwork and amazing bits (if you upgrade them, which I did directly through Lookout Games). - Card play: They can really push you to try a different strategy in the game, since they give you a small advantage in one part of the game. - High replay value: There are a lot of cards and different decks of cards to explore in this game.[/i]
5 plays -> E deck 5 plays -> G deck 3 plays -> I deck 2 plays -> K deck 2 plays -> France deck 2 plays -> FotM E deck 1 play -> FotM F deck 1 play -> FotM F + France decks 1 play -> FotM F + K decks

item.name: Agricola: All Creatures Big and Small
item.comment: [i]- Excellent 2p worker placement game. - Components and art are top notch, love the animeeples. - I enjoy seeing what our farms look like after the game, we always have a story as to what kind of farm we created. (I always feel bad having 10 sheep crammed into a stable). - The expansion buildings really make you think outside of the box as you plan your farm. - 30 minute play time packed with strategy. - Extremely high replay value once you add the expansion buildings (I can't believe we've played this 50+ times).[/i]

item.name: Agricola: All Creatures Big and Small – Even More Buildings Big and Small
item.comment:
[i]I actually like these buildings even more than the first expansion. They really make you think outside of the box as you plan your farm. I vow to win using the organic farm, probably my favorite building of the bunch.
*If I were getting only one expansion, this would be the one.[/i]

item.name: Agricola: All Creatures Big and Small – More Buildings Big and Small
item.comment: [i]Adds a lot of variety to the game, I would recommend buying this with the base game.[/i]

item.name: Agricola: Farmers of the Moor
item.comment:
[i]- An amazing expansion that makes a great game even better! - I really appreciate how the game unfolds now, it isn't necessary to max out your family/house to remain competitive because now you have to heat your home. - The addition of horses also adds another way to score some serious points (each horse = 1 point without a cap). - The variable board set up in the beginning of the game also impacts how you're going to play your game (your farm now has 8 spaces filled with bogs and forests that need to be removed if you want to use those spaces on your farm). - I know some players aren't in love with the new major/minor cards, but since I'm not playing to always score the most points I really enjoy the variety they add. A lot of them take advantage of the new additions to the game that this expansion adds. - As much as I like the occupations I actually enjoy the game more just focusing on minor/major improvements and the forests/bogs. It is definitely easier for my kids to focus there stratedy and the additional action cards you get are great too because they can really help you jump start your engine.
I couldn't be happier with this expansion and I can't imagine playing Agricola without it. It may be the best expansion I own, it adds that much to the game play. I would highly recommend getting it if you want to breath new life into Agricola.[/i]

item.name: Agricola: France Deck
item.comment:
[i]The first thing I want to mention is the art, I actually appreciate the fact that the publisher went through the effort to get all French artwork for this deck. There are some beautiful images.
On to the deck itself, (I've only played 2p so please take that into account). I love the cards in this game and how they really encourage you to explore different paths to victory. There is a lot of synergy between the cards, in all of our plays we've gotten out more cards than usual.
Right now I would probably say this is my favorite Agricola deck, I'm looking forward to exploring it further.[/i]

item.name: Agricola: Gamers' Deck
item.comment:
Sold via auction 7/10/15.
[i]Became even more unecessary after getting the FoTM expansion. I don't think it's worth the current asking price.[/i]

item.name: Airlines Europe
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Airlines Europe[/COLOR] was sold via auction 8/8/15.
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Another excellent family weight game [i](probably a step up from TTR)[/i], but still very easy to teach to new gamers. - Beautiful production quality and components, the board looks great as you fill it up with the airplanes. - Each turn you can take 1 of 4 possible actions [i](simple right?)[/i], but that decision is never easy since the scoring cards always seem to come up one round too soon. - I really appreciate the hidden scoring combined with the variable round ends create a very tense game where every decision is extremely important.[/i]

item.name: Akrotiri
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Akrotiri[/COLOR] was traded away 12/14 (received Memoir 44) Received in a trade (12/15/14).
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
[i]Boy was I wrong about this one, after playing 3 times I still never felt like I had a good grasp of the rules ([i] way to many ambiguities, especially with the scoring cards)[/i] and it just ended up sitting on the shelf until I traded it.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Beautiful components [i](the temples look great on the board)[/i], love the art style and the art really pops off the glossy tiles. - Excellent combination of tile laying, route building and pick up and deliver. - Really interesting use of the spacial elements of the board by having to build temples on a specific island that meets all of the temple placement rules of a card. - Tough choices to make since you are concerned with not only the route you are building, but also the placement of the symbol on the board. - Race element; at a certain point in the game you really start to feel pressure to stockpile money and build temples as the islands without temples built become scarce.[/i]
item.conditiontext:
Condition: Very good
Edition: English first edition

item.name: Alhambra
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Alhambra[/COLOR] was traded away with Thebes for El Grande Decennial Edition 10/28/14. Received in a trade (3/11/14).
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]8[/COLOR]):
[i]This was a game my wife and I enjoyed, but our kids never got into it. The much prefer the tile laying found in Carcassonne or the route building in Ticket to Ride (both are different games, but fill a similar niche in our collection). I ended up trading this away because my wife and I did not enjoy the 2 player variant. In the end I am sad to see this go, but I know it would just sit on our shelves.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (9):
[i]- Tile laying/ building your city, which is always a hit in my house. - Having to figure out the layout of your alhambra in order to extend the outer walls. - Simplicity of choices: buy tiles, take money and add/place tiles from your reserve. - $ management: you need to buy tiles with specific colored money and if you pay exact change you get another turn. - Uncertain scoring rounds which adds some tension to when you want to lay tiles versus stockpile cash. - The anniversary edition has beautiful components with a really nice board. It is too bad this is not the standard edition that Queen puts out.[/i]

item.name: Alien Frontiers
item.comment:
[i]I have been wanting to play this for years and my buddy Mat let me borrow it to play with my kids. I really thought they would love it and I thought I would like it a lot more than Kingsburg.
After playing for over an hour I could tell that my kids were getting bored (mind you long games are not an issue with my kids, they'll sit and play Agricola with me). In the end nothing about the game grabbed them and they felt like they were repeating the same actions over and over and I kind of agree. There really isn't much variety in the actions you can take. Also waiting for each person to place all their dice gets old fast, especially by the time my daughter had 7 dice. I much prefer Kingsburg because there are a lot more choices you can make when placing your dice (a total of 16 advisers versus maybe 8 - 10 spaces in AF).
I would play it again if someone requested it, but it's not a game I would consider adding to our collection (I am grateful that I got a chance to try it out before buying it).[/i]

item.name: Among the Stars
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Among the Stars[/COLOR] was sold via auction 7/10/15. Received in a trade 12/18/14.
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Great family game with easy to teach rules. - Love the art on the cards, and while unrealistic I wish the cards were bigger to show off the art. - Card drafting, this is a mechanic I love and I think AtS pulls it off quite well. - Love the spacial aspect of building your space station, actual card placement is critical to being successful in this game. - Having to balance your power supply adds another dimension to consider when building your space station.[/i]
Games with the Ambassadors expansion: 5 Games with the Ambassadors and EtA: 1

item.name: Among the Stars: Expanding the Alliance
item.comment:
Sold via auction 7/10/15.
[i]I didn't think it added much to the game. The dual type special cards are okay, but this is not an expansion I would recommend.[/i]

item.name: Among the Stars: The Ambassadors
item.comment:
Sold via auction 7/10/15.
[i]- The ambassadors elevates AtS from a good game to a great game. - The ambassadors add another much needed choice to the base game, now you can choose to invite an ambassador to your space station. - The ambassador powers open up some really interesting ways to manipulate tiles already built in your space station. - A lot of new basic locations and special locations which really cranck up the variability of the game.[/i]

item.name: Animal Upon Animal
item.comment:
Christmas gift 2013 (Lilly)
[i]My favorite dexterity game out of the few I've played. Lilly is a ninja at this game.[/i]

item.name: Apples to Apples
item.comment: Fun party game that you can play with anyone. Definitely more fun when you play with people you know because the in jokes can abound.

item.name: Apples to Apples Junior
item.comment: Great version for kids.

item.name: Arboretum
item.comment:
Boardgame Bliss (April 2015)
[i]- Amazing artwork, I would love to get prints of some of these images. - Awesome 2p experience, great couples game to play at a cafe or pub. - This is one of those chill games for us, you can't help but feel peaceful looking your tableau of cards. - I enjoy the added complexity in how you can sequence different card types as you build your arboretum. (It reminds me of Lost Cities and Musee but the placement of cards is not as constrained.)[/i]

item.name: Archaeology: The Card Game
item.comment:
I enjoyed my one play of this and would play it again if requested, but I would much rather play a host of other card games that invovle set collection elements. I really hated the sandstorm and thief cards, they added way to much chaos and randomness to the game. There is no way to mitigate their effects. In the end you could play a great game and then a thief or sandstorm hits and completely ruins your plans.
[i]If you are looking for an Egyptian themed card game that involves set collection and digging through treasure I would highly recommend [thing=114387][/thing] over this.[/i]

item.name: Artifacts, Inc.
item.comment:
[i]I may end up being in the minority with this one and possibly my judgement is clouded by having played so many dice placement games, but Artifacts fell flat for me. I really don't have much to say because the game has a narrow decision space where everything is the same. Sure you can collect different types of artifacts, but they all function the same so it's a matter of getting what you can with the dice rolled. There also didn't seem to be much variation in the cards you could buy and the spacial aspect of the game was interesting, but again very limited in what you could do based on the placement rules.
I did enjoy the art, it would have been cool to have different pieces for the artifacts especially since the theme really doesn't come through int he game play. It ends up being a typical Euro optimization game with beautiful artwork. I would play it again if asked, but definitely won't seek it out.[/i]

item.name: Ashes: Rise of the Phoenixborn
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Ashes: Rise of the Phoenixborn[/COLOR] was sold via auction 11/5/15.
My thoughts:
[i]May be my biggest disappointment of 2015 so far. I'm keeping my comments short and sweet on this one. First off I love the use of dice in this game to manage your mana, but you can get hosed if your playing a deck that has a lot of top tier mana requirements. Yes you can discard a card to change a die value, but that is costly and you really can't afford to keep doing that throughout the game. Still I had fun managing my dice pool, but is something to be aware of going in.
I have 1 major gripe with the game though. I do not enjoy deckbuilding, especially in games I'm playing with my kids. I knew going in that was a big part of this game, but I expected the base factions to be better balanced against one another. Summoner Wars, (another PH game) is extremely well balanced when playing just the base faction decks. In Ashes some decks will more often than not get destroyed by other decks and I'm not interested in figuring out how to balance the base game decks. I'm not a fan of the LCG model, but as with Summoner Wars, I would have been happy buying new factions that I wanted if I thought PH was making efforts to balance all of the basic decks.
I have one other minor conern, after a few plays with each deck strategies become apparent and games become very samey. Again I realize that building decks alleviates this, but I expected more variety, balance and replay value from the basic decks in Ashes (Imperial Settlers pulls this off exceptionally well so it can be done).[/i]
item.wishlistcomment: [i]Need to wait for the hype to die down and really decide if I want to add this to the collection. Looks pretty good, not sure if I want to buy into this type of game though.[/i]

item.name: At the Gates of Loyang
item.comment:
Received in a trade (4/30/14)
[i]- Great theme, with beautiful production from the artwork to all the wooden vegimeeples. - Another Uwe game that plays awesome with 2 and doesn't involve feeding anyone. - The card drafting system is really tense because you are discarding cards to a common pool that both players can choose from. However; the twist is that you must choose a card from the common pool and your hand. - There is something therapeutic about planting fields of vegetables and then harvesting them. It is a tense game, but somehow I stay very relaxed while playing. - Great variety of card types (long term customers, one time customers, market stands and helpers) and character abilties on the helper cards. - Figuring out how to optimally fulfill orders to customers while also making sure you are going to continue to harvest the vegetables you need is a great, brain burning puzzle you have to figure out each turn.[/i]

item.name: Atlantic Storm
item.comment:
[i]My play experience was completely ruined by someone at the table who whined the whole game about the cards they had, yet in the end they were miraculously in contention (partly because other people "helped" said person).
Either way I enjoy Pacific Typhoon more, but both games tend to be too long for what they offer.[/i]

item.name: Balloon Cup
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Ballon Cup[/COLOR] was sold via auction 11/5/15. Received in a math trade (8/8/14).
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]8[/COLOR]):
[i]Out of all the games I played this month, this is the one that stood the test of time. As soon as I played it I began looking for a copy and was lucky enought to get one in a math trade (As a quick aside I had no interest in the Piñata reprint because the art is terrible).
However; We now play by the designer's original rules (found in this thread) and it makes a great game even better. In a nutshell you can't play cards on your opponents side of a tile until your side of the tile has the necessary number of cards. This really adds a lot more strategy to the game and makes the game feel like more of a race.
Balloon Cup has been a hit with everyone in my family, but especially with my older daughter. This is her most requested game when we're looking for a short game to play. I would highly recommend this game if you can find a copy, this is one of the older Kosmos 2p games that has stood the test of time (The only reason it is an 8 is because I would still choose Battle Line first when looking to play this type of game).
Even though I still think Balloon Cup is a solid game, we have way too many 2p card games and I'd always rather play Battle Line so it ended up getting sold.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (9):
[i]- Excellent 2p cafe game, very compact. - My wife really enjoyed playing this game, it falls right into her sweet spot for games. - Beautiful artwork, nice components. - Easy to learn/teach. - There is a lot of strategy because you are allowed to play on your opponents side of the tile/board which leads to some interesting choices when deciding where to play certain cards.[/i]

item.name: BANG! The Dice Game
item.comment:
Meh, take it or leave it. I would much rather play King of Tokyo for a dice fest attacking game or Coup/Cockroach poker for a bluffing game. I find it mediocre in both categories.
I would like to play this again, I could see it being fun during family get togethers.

item.name: Basari
item.comment:
Sold via auction 7/10/15.
[i]- The best negotiation/bluffing filler I've played [i](games last about 20 minutes tops and it is easy to teach)[/i]. - Amazing how much game has been condensed down into a deck of cards and some jewels, perfect pub/cafe game. - My favorite mechanism in the game: 1 person selects an action - they get it, 2 people - they negotiate who will get it by giving gems to the other player, 3 or more people - no one gets anything! - You constantly second guess every choice because you are not only worried about what action you want to take, but what other people may be interested in (too many people choose it and you get zilch)[/i].

item.name: Baseball Highlights: 2045
item.comment:
Thank you Ralph for teaching/playing the game with me. I played a prototype version of this game and had fun. Another take on deck building with a baseball theme. The game play was quick and I really liked how you could recruit new players onto your team between each match.
While I thought the game was fun I am probably not the intended audience for a few reasons. The first being my general dislike for deck builders, I think they are fun at first but I very quickly burn out on them. Second the baseball theme does nothing for me, especially with the robot/cyborg element they threw in.

item.name: Battle For Souls
item.comment:
This was a hard game for me to rate. While I had fun playing the game, nothing really jumped out at me. In some ways it felt like a game that I had played before just with a different theme [i](which was okay, but I wouldn't really enjoy playing on the side of the devil)[/i]. The strongest part of the game for me is the artwork they used; awesome.
[i]I would definitely play it again, but it is not a game I am looking to add to my collection.[/i]

item.name: Battle Line
item.comment: [i]- Another great 2p game that plays quick but offers lots of strategy. - Interesting take on basic poker mechanics being used to gain a majority of flags (scoring markers) on the table (5 or 3 that are all next to each other.) - Tactics cards: help add an amount of uncertainty to the game; it becomes harder to make sure that you really have a flag scored. They let you manipulate the cards you have played in some interesting ways, but they are well balanced because you can only play one more tactics card than your opponent has played.[/i]

item.name: Battlestar Galactica
item.comment:
While I found this game to be okay, but it is long. And while I (as a hidden cylon) managed to convince everyone else to throw a different player in the brig, I actually felt bad for that person because their options were so limited.
[i]I had fun playing, but not a game I need to play again.[/i]

item.name: Beasty Bar
item.comment: [i]- Top notch production, the card quality is outstanding and the cards are tarot sized [i](like Lost Cities)[/i]. - Excellent family/gateway filler game. It is easy to teach/learn and plays well at all player counts. - Awesome artwork and theme for this style of game, my kids love it. - There is a lot of depth to be found in the game; the way each animal reacts towards each different animal makes each game a unique experience. - Beasty Bar does a great job presenting a take that style game in a family friendly package, it is a must have filler game![/i]

item.name: Belfort
item.comment: Highlights: - The theme is awesome [i](a funny take on fantasy)[/i] and the artwork is beautiful and really supports the theme. I love all the Easter eggs found on the main board's artwork. - Excellent blend of worker placement and area/majority control [i](it even extends to how many of the different workers you have)[/i], which are 2 of my favorite mechanisms in a game. - The rules take a little time to get straight, but once you get them down the game flows smoothly. I ended up appreciating how the different phases were split up. - I really appreciate how upgrades are used in this game, whether it is buying a gnome to unlock a building ability or turning one of your dwarves or elves into a "super" dwarf which will collect more resources for you [i](but still only counts for one when determining majorities)[/i].

item.name: Biblios
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Biblios[/COLOR] was sold via auction 4/4/15. Received in a math trade 11/10/14.
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
[i]In the end, for my wife and I, this game didn't stand up to repeated play. Most of my plays were with 2 and I definitely think Biblios plays better with more, so I am quite surprised that it's so highly recommended for 2. The drafting of cards worked well with 2, but I found the dice manipulation to usually be a back and forth affair with very little difference in the numbers (most of our 2p games ended with a bunch of 3's and maybe a 2 and 4 thrown in). With 3 or 4 I t would gladly play it, but since it was mainly a 2p game I played with my wife I ended up trading it.
*I lowered my rating to a 6 based on the 2p experience, with 3 or 4 I would rate it an 8 and highly recommend playing it. [/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- An auction game that plays very well with 2 - An excellent cafe game [i](small footprint)[/i] - Easy to teach since you can teach each phase of the game separately [i](drafting/auction phases) [/i] - Interesting draft mechanic [i](you must choose a card for yourself, the auction piple and put cards out for the other players to choose)[/i]. - Dice manipulation: the whole game hinges on adjusting the value of the dice, the tricky part is when do you do it.[/i]
item.conditiontext:
Edition - English 2014 (white bordered cards)
Condition - Very good

item.name: Black Fleet
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Black Fleet[/COLOR] was traded away for Diamant 12/10/14.
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
[i]This ended up being a huge disappointment. The game is beautifully produced, but in the end lacked any real staying power. Our subsequent plays ended up feeling very similar, there just wasn't enough variety in the cards or decisions you had to make. It was also much lighter than it first appeared, as we realized the decision space was much more limited than what we first thought and the game became boring and definitely outstayed its welcome (an hour is way too long for the decisions you make in this game.
It's certainly been well received by the gaming community and maybe I would recommend it if you are looking for a light, family game and the theme appeals to you. Personally though, we've found other games released around the same time to be much better (Camel Up and Rattlebones spring to mind).[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Absolutely beautiful production, the ships are amazing (they hold the cargo in them) and who doesn't love metal coins? - The board/cards have great cartoony artwork which works well in a family game. - Excellent family game that is easy to teach and plays in under an hour. - Plays great with 3, there is still plenty of pirate shenanigans taking place. - Light intro into pick up and deliver games. - Special cards are really fun to combo together and create a mega turn were you are making $ and sinking ships left and right. - The powers on the cards you purchase with doubloons are all different, adding to the replay value of this game.[/i]

item.name: Blue Moon City
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Blue Moon City[/COLOR] was sold via auction 8/8/15. Received in a trade 10/31/14
Updated thoughts and rating [COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]:
[i]This one started out strong and ended up fizzling out after more plays. What really soured me on the game was the lack of variety in how the game played out. Even though the layout of buildings changed from game to game it really didn't change much. It basically just meant you were looking for different colored cards to play. The 2p experience was okay, but there was a lot less conflict over who was going to build each building and the game devolved into a race with a predictable outcome of who would score the last cube in the tower.
It sounds like I really don't like the game, which isn't true, I'm just not interested in keeping games in our collection that will only get played once or twice a year and that's about how often I'd want to play BMC. However; if someone else pulled out a copy I'd happily play.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- I love the artwork on the tiles (the buildings), most of the characters (there are a few that I really don't care for) and the dragon pieces are great. - Plays well with 2, although it does become even more of a race where you may try to build each site on your own. - An interesting twist on area control, since you can build where someone else has you may be able to share in some of the benefits for building that site. - Dragons: the addition of the dragons/scales adds another layer of depth to the game because you can get quite a few crystals if you have the majority of scales. - Cube management: my son and I played a 2p game and I almost lost because I did not have a cube left to build in the temple. - Hand management and all the different card powers/combos. - Random tile layout: This really changes how you play the game since getting adjacent building bonuses can be very important.
This is an excellent game that really deserves a reprint, I really haven't played anything quite like it.[/i]

item.name: Blue Moon Legends
item.comment: I really enjoyed playing this game and I would love to play it again. A different take on a card based combat game, with Summoner Wars being one of my favorite 2p card based combat games. While I would gladly play it anytime it was brought out, I do not think my family would enjoy it too much because they would not want to invest the time into learning all the different decks (especially since they have done this to some extent with Summoner Wars). For this reason I doubt I will end up buying it.

item.name: Bohnanza
item.comment:
Sold via auction 4/20/15 Received in a math trade 4/14/14.
[i]I highly recommend this game for families getting into the hobby.[/i]
Highlights: - Great gateway/family game, especially if you are interested in a game that focuses on trading. - Encourages trading every turn [i](it is very rare for someone to keep both cards they flip, usually at least one gets traded).[/i] - Best mechanic in the game [i](which also helps drive trading)[/i] is not being able to rearrange your hand, ever. - Very easy to teach/learn. - I like the cartoony artwork and the card quality is excellent.

item.name: BraveRats
item.comment: [i]Overall very uninspiring 2p variant of Love Letter; not a game I need to play again. I enjoyed my first play, but after playing it again it just fell flat. I am starting to realize that I really don't care for micro games that play in a few minutes and I'm not interested in playing multiple rounds of this game. Instead I would rather play a quick dice filler like [thing=117942][/thing], [thing=111148][/thing] or stick with [thing=129622][/thing].[/i]

item.name: Brew Crafters
item.comment:
This was a tough one for me to rate because I did enjoy the game play. I love the theme (being a huge craft beer fan) and I love WP games, so I asked myself why it fell flat for me. I ended up basing my rating on where Brew Crafters would fit into the WP games I really enjoy [i](specifically my two favorites - [thing=31260][/thing] and [thing=118048][/thing]).[/i]
[i]Thoughts on Agricola versus Brew Crafters:[/i]
A lot of people are comparing it to Agricola and I don't think they feel that similar. BC does not have nearly the amount of variability during set up that Agricola has (due to the occupation and minor improvement cards in Agricola). There is also not the same tension in BC, yes you have to pay your employees but that is much easier to accomplish as opposed to feeding your family in Agricola. The similarities to Agricola are similar game length and weight plus the fact that both are WP games. If I want to play a heavier WP game I would choose Agricola because I love how the cards you get in the beginning of a game of Agricola can completely change how you will play the game compared to other plays you've had.
[i]Thoughts on Targi versus Brew Crafters:[/i]
Why Targi you ask... because Targi offered something brand new to the WP genre when it came out, the spacial element of placing workers to get certain goods/tribe cards. All of this is packed into a 1 hour experience [i](including set up).[/i] I had fun playing Brew Crafters, but it felt like more of the same without offering anything new to the experience. I haven't played with 2 yet, but a 3p and 4p game took a few hours to play and there were plenty of turns where my optimal move was quite apparent.
[i]In closing, while I enjoyed my plays of Brew Crafters it doesn't stand up to the variability of Agricola or the innovation of Targi. I will happily play again, but it is not a game I feel the need to add to my collection.[/i]

item.name: Brew Crafters: The Travel Card Game
item.comment:
Mat had a print and play copy he made. In some ways this game reminded me of Morels with some additional cards to vary how you can score points. I will admit to having had a few choice brews by this point so I really need to play it again. I think this would be another game my wife would like.
[i]I need to play it more to give it a solid rating, but I've really enjoyed my first 2 plays.[/i]

item.name: Broom Service
item.comment:
[i]- The artwork is beautiful and whimsical which really drew my daughter into the game. - The production is top notch all around[i] (great wooden potions, great card stock and the tiles are nice and thick) which isn't always the case with Ravensberger games.[/i] - The combination of role selection and pick up and deliver is clever and really engaging [i](I'm not aware of other games that have combined these mechanisms).[/i] - This is definitely a great [i]"next step"[/i] family game as long as everyone doesn't mind a fair dose of chaos in their games. - Flexibility is key and you need to make sure you can do a few different things with the roles you select, even if some of those plans are less than ideal. - There can be turns where certain roles may be useless if you need other roles to be resolved first.
I'm interested to see how it handles a lower player count, especially 2p, because my daughter really wants to play again. I'll update mt initial thoughts once we play it at other player counts.[/i]

item.name: Bruges
item.comment: I really enjoyed the card play of this game and I would love to play it some more. However; it will be staying on my wishlist for now because I do not know if my family would enjoy it. I need to find a way to play with my wife sometime.

item.name: Bruxelles 1893
item.comment: Highlights: - Theme; this is what really drew me into the game. - Learning the game was easy because all of your actions tied in quite well with the theme. - Similar to Terra Mystica this is another heavy game that offers a variety of strategies to explore over multiple plays. - Loved how the board where you can place workers only has a certain section available for each round. - Bidding mechanic: On top of that when selecting a location for your worker you are bidding for majority in that column in order to receive the benefit of a card at the end of the column. - Patrons: you can collect patrons that will give you different abilities which will typically help you with one of the scoring areas. - Worker placement with set collection and area majority.

item.name: Bugs in the Kitchen
item.comment: [i]I really enjoy this game, watching the hex bug almost go into your kitchen but then inexplicably turn away is funny. This game also has great production values, everything works smoothly and I really like the art on the board. This game is easily played by my 4 year old daughter and she loves "the bug game".[/i]

item.name: Ca$h 'n Guns (second edition)
item.comment:
[i]- Awesome family game to play with our extended family; I consider it family therapy :p - Great components and I prefer the new art style over the old one. - Simple to teach, I haven't had any problem teaching this. - I like the draft that takes place at the end of each round to divy up the loot. - Plays with 4 to 8 players [i](and it still plays quick with 8)[/i].
I can't recommend this highly enough as a great party game to play with friends and family. This game will continue to see lots of play whenever we have people over.[/i]

item.name: Cacao
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Cacao[/COLOR] was sold via auction 8/8/15.
Updated thoughts and rating [COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]:
[i]This ended up having very limited replay potential for my family and I. We got in a bunch of plays right away and then lost all interest in playing. This game is really light and the decisions aren't as interesting as Carcassonne for us, mostly because in Cacao there isn't the same kind of interaction that farmers cause in Carc.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- The first tile laying game that I would put in the filler category. - It plays fast (20 minutes tops) and has enough decisions to remain engaging. - Worker placement tiles are a great idea, you activate the tiles you place your worker tiles next to if there are workers facing that tile. - Excellent production values, everything is top notch (thick tiles/ player boards, and really nice cacao pieces). - I really like the theme/artwork, it is simple but still beautiful to look at.[/i]

item.name: Call my Bluff
item.comment: [i]I need to play this with my family and see if they like it.[/i]

item.name: Camel Up
item.comment:
Received in a math trade (3/17/15).
[i]After playing a few times I believe Camel Up definitely deserved to win the Spiel award. This is a game that you really have to play, reading about it will not get across just how much fun this game can be. This game is all about the experience of playing it!
Highlights: - Awesome family/party game that can be taught to anyone in minutes. - Components are top notch, the camel meeples are awesome! - Fun... really fun. [i](Seriously; this game is a blast to play, trust me!)[/i] - There is just enough happening with the camels (due to the stacking mechanism) to keep this game engaging and unpredictable, which makes each turn exciting.[/i]

item.name: Camel Up: Supercup
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Camel Up: Supercup[/COLOR] was traded away for Wharfside 10/25/15.
My thoughts:
[i]I can't fault the expansion as much as I fault myself for picking this up. Supercup does offer some interesting twists on the game play that make the game a bit more tactical, but in doing so I think it raises the barrier to entry and sucks out some of the fun we've had playing the game. Since this has been a game that we've brought out with extended family, I couldn't see us getting much play out of the expansion so I ended up trading it.[/i]

item.name: Can't Stop
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Can't Stop[/COLOR] sold via auction...
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
[i]I ended up trading this because the game really drags with 4 and it has since been Jones Theoried by other games in our collection; Diamant if I'm looking for push your luck or Qwixx for a quick dice filler.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8.5):
[i]- The most fun push your luck game I have played! - Nice components with a cool stop sign board. - Lots of dice rolling - Everyone gets excited during each turn... "Come on just one more roll" -This is a great family/gateway game.[/i] - You could easily play this with younger kids as well.

item.name: Carcassonne
item.comment:
Traded away in a math trade 3/21/15. (Received Castles of Burgundy... again) Reaquired 9/21/14 Traded away in a math trade 4/14/14. (Received Innovation)
Great game I originally bought to play with my wife. She loved it but what surprised me was how much my kids enjoy it as well. This is a great family game, and what is most surprising is that my wife is probably the most cutthroat player closely followed by my son. This game has a very easy to learn rule set but there is a surprising amount of depth for a tile laying game. This really is the game that every family should have.
This is a game we have played with a lot of people who don't typically play or enjoy games. My in-laws played it one night at our house and they bought it the next day!
item.conditiontext:
Condition: The box shows some shelf wear, but the tiles and meeples are in excellent condition.
Edition: This is the Rio Grande version that included the River expansion.
item.wishlistcomment: Only looking for the new 2014 printing.

item.name: Carcassonne: Gold Rush
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Carcassonne: Gold Rush[/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 8/2015. (Received Dynasties version of Sun Tzu)
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
[i]The hidden scoring ended up introducing way to much randomness and fluctuation in the scoring. It is way too easy to get a couple of 0's while someone else gets a few 5's. I originally liked the idea of a hidden scoring element, but it was too random for my taste.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Great theme, artwork and components (cowboy meeples) that will definitely draw kids in. - Simplified farmer scoring, you now look for tepees and horses on the tiles which score you 2 and 4 points respectively. - Mining tokens which you collect these tokens when finishing a mountain, tents which allow you to steal these tokens before a mountain is finished. - Railroad tracks can now score like inns (2p per tile instead of 1) if you have 1 train on a section of track. - The Sheriff mini expansion adds a few excellent editions to the game play,
*As of now this is my favorite version of Carcassonne (I've owned the base game with expansions, the winter version and South Seas). The mining tokens add a bit of randomness to the game (they can score you 0 to 5 points, typically 1 or 2), but I actually like having some hidden scoring in the game. [/i]

item.name: Carcassonne: Goldrausch – Der Sheriff
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Carcassonne: Gold Rush - The Sheriff[/COLOR]
My thoughts:
[i]This adds a few tweaks to the game play. The Sheriff stops people from stealing mining tokens with their tents so you can protect a mountain you control that has a lot of mining tokens. It also adds graveyards which function like monasteries in the original Carcassonne with the added benefit of scoring more points for each city tile it is adjacent to.[/i]

item.name: Carcassonne: Hills & Sheep
item.comment:
Traded away in a math trade 1/12/15 with Inns and Cathedrals. (Received TTR Map Collection: Asia)
[i]Played one time 2p, I think the sheep and hills would be interesting when playing with more players. The additional points for cloisters with the vineyards is okay, but nothing earth shattering. Since I play this game mostly 2p, I think this expansion plus Inns and Cathedrals is too much. There are too many tiles and it extends the game too much for me. I still prefer just the base game plus Inns.[/i]
item.conditiontext: Excellent condition, only played once.

item.name: Carcassonne: Inns & Cathedrals
item.comment:
Traded away in a math trade 1/12/15 with Hills and Sheep. (Received TTR Map Collection: Asia)
Love how this expansion adds a little more depth to the base game, some great new tiles but it does not burden the game with too many new rules. You can still explain the rules in a few minutes and then finish a game in about an hour.
item.conditiontext: Excellent condition, only played once.

item.name: Carcassonne: South Seas
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Carcassonne: South Seas[/color] was traded away in a math trade 11/10/14. (Received Ra) Received in a trade 4/30/14.
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
[i]South Seas was fun, specifically I liked how you traded goods for ships (which are your points) and the fishing mechanism. However; the theme/art wasn't my cup of tea and really detracted from the experience for me. I also didn't care for the tile distribution, there never seemed to be enough jungle tiles.
Now that I own Carcassonne: Gold Rush (the 2nd game in the Around the World series) I am content not having South Seas in my collection any longer. I prefer the theme and new game play variations found in Gold Rush more than those found in South Seas.
At this point I am interested in trying Carcassonne: H&G which seems to offer a nice variation in game play from the base game and Gold Rush. I don't miss having South Seas in my collection, but if the theme appeals to you I think it offers solid, new mechanisms to the Carcassonne formula.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Quick playtime (a 2p game takes about 25 minutes). - Scoring: You are collecting resources [i](seashells, fish and bananas)[/i] which you trade in for ship tiles (which have values from 2 to 6 points). There is no need for a clunky scoring track. - The artwork is excellent and it includes nice wooden seashells, bananas and fish.
This is the third version of Carcassonne I have owned [i](I have the Winter version and traded away the original with Inns and Cathedrals) [/i] and I would consider it the easiest to teach new players. I find the scoring to be much more clear cut since there are no farmers and the fishermen (which replaced farmers) are easier to score.[/i]

item.name: Carcassonne: Winter Edition
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Carcassonne: Winter Edition[/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 9/21/14. (Received Pastiche: International Edition)
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
[i]Carcassonne is one of my wife's favorite games so I thought she would like the winter version, turns out she prefers the original with Inns and Cathedrals. Since we only need one version of Carcassonne I traded this one away (another victim of the Jones theory). I still loved the artwork in this edition, especially the tiles with animals.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (7.5):
[i]We live in the NE were snow is plentiful so I love the new art. Also the animals added to some of the tiles are beautiful, especially the birds. I also like how the roads are more organic and not perfect curves. The simple addition of the gingerbread man adds some meaningful decisions to the game. You can score quite a few points with him if you plan well. There is also a larger tile selection than the base game, including a better variety of tiles with different shapes/features.[/i]

item.name: Castellan
item.comment: Okay abstract, but overall a forgettable experience. Not a game I would clamor to play again.

item.name: The Castles of Burgundy
item.comment:
Received in a math trade 4/14/14. Traded away for Agricola 7/17/14. Reacquired in a math trade 3/21/15.
[i]This is the third Feld game I have played, the others are Bruges and Notre Dame. As of now Notre Dame may be my favorite, but it is currently out of print. I am not sure how I feel about his games yet, which means that I don't know if I like point salad games. I need to play all of these more before I make up my mind, so on some level I definitely enjoy them.
I like Castles but I need more plays before I decide whether it is a keeper or not. I do enjoy how the dice are used to determine what you can do on a turn. And I always enjoy finding ways to maximize points, but as of yet I feel like the game is a bit random. Also the components are mediocre at best.
This is definitely one I want to return to and I look forward to teaching my wife.[/i]

item.name: The Castles of Burgundy: 1st Expansion – New Player Boards
item.comment: [i]I only ended up with these because I was already getting a few Spiel magazines for some other promos. They add some new boards to the game which is great, but I haven't played the game enough to really feel like I needed the variety. I also like the monastery boards more because of the added feature of scoring the monasteries.[/i]

item.name: The Castles of Burgundy: 4th Expansion – Monastery Boards
item.comment: [i]I enjoy the added spacial scoring found on these boards. Those points can easily be the difference between winning and losing.[/i]

item.name: The Castles of Burgundy: 5th Expansion – Pleasure Garden
item.comment: [i]Love the tile ability, fun to work out a turn using the white die. If you can find it, I'd recommend getting the expansion. I ordered directly from the Spiel magazine.[/i]

item.name: Castro
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Castro[/COLOR] was sold via auction 4/4/15.
My thoughts:
[i]This was another disappointment, I specifically asked Time Well Spent to bring this in and they did ([i]awesome service btw![/i]). I was really excited to get this and it finally came in. It really is just a combination of Yahtzee and Connect Four.
My problems with the game is that it is either over really fast [i](with very little excitement)[/i] or it completely overstays it's welcome. It is missing the tension and push your luck aspect of Cant Stop and the extremely quick playing time and constant engagement of Qwixx. On a positive note this game can be taught in less than a minute and could be played with anyone, this is a very light game. However; this game is not for us and I will be trading it away.[/i]

item.name: Catch a Falling Star
item.comment:
[i]This is the first game published by Drei Majier Spiele that has fallen flat as a game. The dexterity element of the game is fun (trying to place all your sticks to the star, which has a few magnets, or place sticks on top of other sticks), but in practice there end up being these big stacks of sticks because it is so easy to place them there. The scoring is counter intuitive for a kids game, eventually sticks fall and you'll have to collect some of them for negative points. The person with the least amount of negative points wins. I don't think this type of scoring clicks with young kids.
This will stick around for now, but more as an toy for my daughter to play with. If you are looking for a children's dexterity game that works as a game and a toy I would highly recommend Animal Upon Animal.[/i]

item.name: Caverna: The Cave Farmers
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Caverna[/COLOR] was traded away for At The Gates of Loyang, Ninjato and Carcassonne South Seas (4/30/14).
[i]Having now played Agricola, I much prefer Agricola and do not regret this trade at all.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
*When I originally wrote this I hadn't played Agricola yet.
[i] I like Caverna, but I prefer Glass Road and for a lighter game Agricola ACBaS. I can't really explain it, it is fun to play but I do not feel the same sense of accomplishment at the end of the game that I get from Glass Road. In my opinion I feel like Glass Road is getting pushed to the side because it came out at the same time as Caverna. I much prefer the card play and resource management found in Glass Road. Maybe Caverna just feels like other WP games I have already played, albeit with a cool theme/wrapper and really nice components.
Will be interested to see how this game fares a year from now. Overall a solid game, but I am not on the hype wagon, go try Glass Road instead![/i]

item.name: Cheaty Mages!
item.comment: I played a six player game and it was quite fun and chaotic. One person ended up running away with it, but that didn't detract from the experience. Definitely needs to be played with the right crowd or this game could become very boring, a game that it meant to be played quick.

item.name: Chinatown
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Chinatown[/COLOR] was sold via auction 11/5/15.
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- A pure negotiation game that works extremely well in a family setting. - Very easy to teach, clean rule set and you are engaged the whole game (there isn't any down time). - I will mention that the game can get pretty intense because everyone is negotiating at the same time. (We slowed it down a bit so my daughter (9) wouldn't get overwhelmed.) - Production is good (although I'd prefer wooden discs to the plastic ones) and I appreciate the much smaller box. - Not sure if I'd play this with less than 4, I think it would fall flat.
I was very happy when whole family enjoyed Chinatown. Up to this point we have played Lords of Vegas, but I'd been a bit weary of introducing a pure negotiation game because there isn't any luck involved, whereas in Lords of Vegas you have lots of die rolling which can swing the game in some unexpected ways. Because of that fact I definitely think there is room in our collection for both of these games, depending on what kind of mood we're in.
Both games are great fun, but the one thing Lords of Vegas has over Chinatown are those insane die rolls when everything is on the line and you could lose a huge casino to an opponent. However; I think Chinatown offers a more exciting negotiation environment because you are negotiating not only for the lots, but also the different business types which means you usually have something everyone else at the table wants.[/i]

item.name: Ciao, Ciao...
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Ciao, Ciao...[/COLOR] was sold via auction 8/8/15.
My thoughts:
[i]I took a flier on this game after hearing about it from a few people who's opinions seem to jive with mine. Unfortunately this was a miss for my family and I. It is a family weight bluffing game in the vein of Cockroach Poker except sometimes you have no choice but to lie (because you are rolling a custom die that has two x's on it, but you always have to declare a number between 1 - 4 to move your piece). It is dead simple to teach and relatively fun.
The problem is Cockroach Poker came along after this game was designed and managed to one up Ciao Ciao. Cockroach is even easier to teach and there is never a point in the were you are forced to bluff (a mechanism that I don't care for). My whole family has also find Cockroach poker to be more fun partly because the stories now associated with all the different bugs. Cockroach also plays up to 6 (we've played with 7) where as Ciao Ciao tops out at 4, so we can bust out Cockroach when we have friends and family over too.
The bottom line is Ciao Ciao and Cockroach Poker fill the a very similar niche in our collection, and we all prefer Cockroach Poker, so Ciao Ciao will be leaving our collection. [/i]

item.name: Cinque Terre
item.comment:
Highlights: - Perfect gateway/family weight pick up and deliver game. - Beautiful board and artwork. I love the use of color in this game, everything pops. The wooden delivery trucks are awesome too. - This plays great with 2, which is always a huge plus for me. - Variable set up [i](each game the 5 towns will pay different amounts for certain goods)[/i] and multiple ways to win this game.*
*This game may seem random at first, but that is only if you are focused on collecting the order cards. You can also focus on delivering certain goods to the towns that are paying out high prices that game, which in turn will also put you in the running to collect the Most Popular Vendor point tiles.

item.name: Ciúb
item.comment:
[i]I thought this was a really fun dice filler, unfortunately the component quality is awful (well the dice are okay). I only got to play one game and it was the short version. I'd definitely like to play more to really solidify my opinion of this one. Mat said he thought it went a bit long when you played the regular game and it suffered from downtime issues when playing with more than 2. Still I quite liked the way dice got manipulated, especially swapping out dice in order to get new dice that had different values/powers.
I'm not sure this game has legs, but I am excited to play again even though it dropped down on my wishlist.[/i]

item.name: Coal Baron
item.comment:
I really enjoyed this WP game and it would definitely be enjoyed by my family, but the components are horrible. All of the cardboard was warped including the played boards which have this cool mine elevator that slides up and down. However; they were so warped the did not work well.
[i]A game I would love to own but the quality is awful so unfortunately a pass for me.[/i]

item.name: Cockroach Poker
item.comment:
[i]- My favorite bluffing game! - Great gateway into bluffing games, I have been able to play this with lots of different people. - I am using this game as a stepping stone to eventually teach my wife and kids Coup (which is my favorite bluffing game). - Plays fast, but there is definitely an interesting meta game that develops if you play with the same people. - Great artwork!
I play with a few different groups, including my family, and each group plays this game differently. Certain bugs become taboo because of what has happened in previous games. My kids also figured out pretty quickly to pass specific cards around so that the last person is faced with a very difficult choice which could lead to them losing.
The fact that all of this naturally emerges from such a simple rule set is what makes this game brilliant and instantly accessible to everyone. There is nothing tacked on or convoluted. As much as I love Coup there is still a slight barrier to entry with people who don't game much. In fact even in one of my groups a few people really don't like the "heavier" bluffing games but love Cockroach Poker.
This game is a keeper and one I would recommend adding to anyone's collection.[/i]

item.name: Coconuts
item.comment: Great kid's dexterity game that I found to be very fun.

item.name: Codenames
item.comment:
[i]Both of my plays were with 2 and I had a blast. I definitely think 4 or 6 would be the sweet spot for me. It can definitely induce some AP, especially when the board is fresh and you have to look at everything to make sure your clues aren't too broad. I could see busting this out with our extended family, but since those opportunities are infrequent I still would rather play games like Camel Up, Cash n' Guns, Diamant or Cockroach Poker. I also think this would be a tough game for kids, especially if they were giving the clues (who knows though maybe I'm completely wrong about that).
As of now definitely a game I'd enjoy playing again, but probably not one I'll add to my collection anytime soon (although I am curious what my wife would think of it as a 2p game).[/i]

item.name: Colosseum
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Colosseum[/COLOR] was sold via the BGG marketplace.
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]8[/COLOR]):
[i]As much as I enjoyed this game my family did not. My original thoughts still hold true, but I ended up trading it away because it was not going to get played. The one thing everyone enjoyed was the trading/wheeling and dealing and once we got [thing=20437][/thing] I unfortunately knew it was all over for Colosseum. This just didn't click with my family and since we try to keep our collection lean it left.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (9):
[i]- Easy to teach to my family on our weekly game night. - The theme is awesome and well integrated into the game. - A great introduction to auctions and trading for a family game. (We do not trade one at a time, but instead everyone trades at once). - There is a helpful catch up mechanic for the person in last place that only affects the person in first (which actually adds some extra strategy into the game. - The scoring: you only score your best round (out of 5). - The artwork and production quality is top notch.[/i]

item.name: Colt Express
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Colt Express[/COLOR] was sold via auction 11/5/15. Received in a trade (6/1/15)
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Colt Express is a great family game that deserves to win the SDJ. - Amazing components, the trains look awesome set up on the table. - Wild west train robbers and programmed movement is a perfect paiiring of theme and game mechanism. - A breeze to teach, you can teach this game as you go. In this game the more chaos the better, so no worries if anyone makes a "mistake" since you never know how things will shake out. - It is FUN! (In a hobby that can be so serious it's great to play a game that is not afraid to be a bit unbalanced, player powers really vary, and quite chaotic.)
This isn't a game that I want to play all the time, but it is fun especially when playing with family and friends. It also pulls people in once it is set up on the table and it can be taught easily, you will be off and running in no time. I highly recommend this game if you play with your family a lot, my guess is your kids will love it![/i]

item.name: Concept
item.comment: [i]This was okay, but not a game I feel any need to play again. For many this would be a fun party game to bring out with family and friends, but we prefer games like Camel Up, Diamant and Cash $ Guns.[/i]

item.name: Concordia
item.comment:
[i]- I love the decision space in this game, planning out your colony expansion while managing your resources and income [i](pure Euro goodness)[/i]. - Plays great with 2; I just ordered the expansion map which should make the 2p experience even better. - Card management; not only do the cards in your hand provide you with the actions you can take, they also have a scoring rule attached to them. You only score points based on the cards you collect. - Low rules overhead, this is a very clean design. (Once you start playing you have a card that lists the scoring opportunities and cost for establishing cities and that is about all yo need to reference while playing.)[/i]
5 plays -> Britannia map 2 plays -> Hispania map with Salsa expansion

item.name: Concordia: Britannia & Germania
item.comment: [i]After 2 plays with the new map I am extremely pleased with this expansion, it really elevates the 2p experience. The board becomes crowded quickly and you are forced to build into cities where your opponent is (you can no longer get away with going in a separate direction in the 2p game). In my opinion this is a must own expansion if you plan on playing Concordia with 2.[/i]

item.name: Cosmic Encounter
item.comment: Highlights: - The Grudge: Okay they are one of the many races, but they are the first race I got to play. Normally I am a pretty laid back guy, but when I play games like this I tend to get really fired up and play aggressively. The Grudge fed right into this, they allowed me to have a strong negotiation presence whenever I was involved in a conflict. - Negotiation: The whole game is about negotiation and reading other players, which may be my favorite mechanic in a game.

item.name: Coup
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Coup[/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 9/21/14. (Received For Sale)
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
[i]Coup got Jones Theoried in favor of the much more elegant Cockroach Poker. I have talked about this comparison a lot so I will be brief. Cockroach poker has very simple rules that allow the players to develop their own play style and meta game which makes Cockroach Poker instantly accessible to everyone. There is nothing tacked on or convoluted.
As much as I have enjoyed Coup there is still a slight barrier to entry with people who don't game much. In fact even in one of my groups a few people really don't like the "heavier" bluffing games but love Cockroach Poker. Another major gripe I have with this game is that it can be over before it starts which isn't very exciting (and can't happen in Cockroach Poker).[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]Great bluffing game were the meta game develops very quickly. It doesn't take long before you start figuring out how you think other people are playing and then the accusations start flying. I really want the original version, I much prefer that art over the Resistance themed cards.[/i]

item.name: Court of the Medici
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Court of the Medici[/COLOR] was sold via auction 4/25/15.
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
[i]The more I played the less interested I got in playing again. It also is an extremely cutthroat and confrontational game and that's not typically the kind of game my family enjoys. So finally after months of sitting on my shelf unplayed I decided to sell my copy.
Since I have so many card games I love in our collection this isn't one I will miss, but if anyone ever wanted to play I would happily get trounced.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Awesome, confrontational 2p card game. - This would make an excellent cafe game. - Plays really quick (about 15 minutes per game). - Excellent riff on trick taking, I love how there are only 3 cards with special abilities. - Another game where you can play on your opponents side of the board (in their court). - The tension is ratcheted up because it is very difficult to get a new card into the inner court in an empty space. You really need to protect some of those cards.[/i]
item.conditiontext:
Condition: Excellent
Edition: Z-man games edition

item.name: Cribbage
item.comment:
[i]Lots of great memories from playing with my pepere and my dad. In my opinion the best 2 player card game you can play with a poker deck.
Worst Cribbage moment: Playing with my dad I get dealt four 5's. Awesome, highest odds of getting 28, all I need is a 10 or face card. Didn't get one!
Best Cribbage moment: Fast forward a few years. Playing against my dad I get dealt three 5's and the queen of spades. The 5 of spades got cut! 28 points! (If I had the Jack instead of the Queen I would have scored 29.)
We both now have a framed picture with the cards and a photo of us holding the board; a great moment I got to share with my dad.[/i]

item.name: Cubist
item.comment:
Received in a math trade. (9/14/14)
[i]- I absolutely love the theme, this is what sold me on the game (that and the beautiful dice). - Quick playtime, even with 4 players (30 - 45 minutes). - Plays great at all player counts (2,3 and 4 players). - It would be a bit tight, but I think this can be brought out at a cafe. - Easy to teach/learn. You can really just start playing and teach as you go. - Artist cards are quite valuable and I am surprised at how much they can be fought over. - Love the idea of not only building your own installation but also being able to share in the building of the museum. - A surprising amount of tension in the game, especially since any of the 3 installations can be built by anyone (once built a new one comes out).[/i]
[i]Includes the following promos: - Additional Installation cards - Museum expansion pack - The Attic[/i]

item.name: DC Comics Deck-Building Game
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]DC Comics Deck-Building Game[/COLOR] was traded away for Perry Rhodan: The Cosmic League 7/12/14. Received in a math trade (5/20/14).
My thoughts:
[i]First I have to admit they I really do not like most deck builders and DC is no exception (Super Motherload is the one deck builder I like). The ruleset is simple which rule set leads to very straight forward play. Therefore I think it would serve as a great introduction to deck building especially for families, but personally I was extremely bored while playing. Had to pay this again and all I can say is :gulp:[/i]

item.name: Deep Sea Adventure
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Deep Sea Adventure[/COLOR] was sold via auction 11/5/15.
Initial thoughts and rating (6):
[i]- Can be taught in under a minute, plays quick. - Small box packed with some nice components and is easy to travel with. - Potentially a good, light weight family game depending on how random you like your games.
I definitely got caught up in the hype with this game and got a copy as soon as it was available in the BGG store. I thought this game would replace Diamant/Incan Gold in our collection, but so far I'm less than impressed. I really don't care for the shared oxygen mechanic because all it takes is one player to completely screw everyone else over. I'm also not a fan of the randomness found in the die rolling combined with the random points distribution on the treasure tiles. Also Diamant plays up to 8 and is still very fun, Deep Sea caps out at 6 and I really disliked the 5p game I took part in.
I would recommend TROLL over Deep Sea Adventures if you want to try a push your luck game published by Oink Games.[/i]
item.wishlistcomment: [i]Really want to play, may replace Diamant in our collection.[/i]

item.name: Desperados of Dice Town
item.comment:
I played this with Mat and our sons and had fun. Be warned this game is all about take that and can get a little mean. I have been looking for a light dice filler so I was really excited to play this, but I thought it took too long for what it is. There are not that many decisions to be made so playing this for 45 minutes gets a little repetitive. This may seem like an odd comment but I also thought only rolling four dice not very fulfilling; I always felt like I was missing a die.
I am glad I was able to play this before I bought/traded for it.

item.name: Deus
item.comment:
I need to start by saying that I really enjoyed my play of Deus and look forward to playing again. It is an interesting take on tableau building; once a card is built in a certain color it will get activated every time a new card is built in that color. This really opens up the game play and strategies/tactics you can employ. You are trying to create an efficient tableau so that you can maximize each activation of your cards [i](they will only be activated 1 to 5 times during the game)[/i]. I also do not have a problem with the aesthetics of the game, I like the card art and wooden buildings and the tiles are fine. [i]The one concern I would have is playing it with more than 3, I have a feeling that the game would drag (similar to Imperial Settlers)[/i].
[i]*The question you may be asking is why did I remove it from my wishlist. It has nothing to do with the game itself, it is more a statement of where my collection is at the moment. I have a lot of games that while not exactly similar scratch the same itch as Deus [i]([thing=28143][/thing], [thing=154203][/thing], [thing=166669][/thing] and to a lesser degree [thing=164338][/thing])[/i]. Add to that the fact that one of my friends has a copy so I know I will get to play it.[/i]

item.name: Diamant
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Diamant[/COLOR] was received in a trade (12/10/14).
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]8[/COLOR]):
[i]Originally owned Incan gold but the component quality was just okay. The card quality was not that good, and the fold up tents stunk. Also every game we played multiple people would get confused with the cards used to show whether you were leaving or staying. I ended up trading Incan Gold and got a copy of [thing=15512][/thing]. This has remained one of our go to push your luck games, especially when we have friends and family over.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating:
[i]- Fun, quick filler that plays up to 8. - This game is easy to teach/learn; we have brought this to family get togethers and had a lot of fun playing with our extended families. - This game can be an addictive push your luck game. - The components for Diamant are absolutely amazing (diamonds for the gems, cool boxes for the gems and little Indiana Jones meeples)[/i].

item.name: Diamonds
item.comment: [i]- Amazing artwork and graphic design, I love the art deco style. - A fresh take on the trick taking genre, if you don't follow the suit led you get to take the special action granted by the card you played. - As the dealer you get to decide how many cards [i](1 to 3)[/i] to pass leading to some creative play since you don't always know what your final hand will look like. - There is a lot of player interaction since you are constantly stealing diamonds from other players and then trying to vault them before the same happens to you.[/i]

item.name: Discoveries
item.comment:
[i]- I've seen some debate on the topic, but I really enjoyed Discoveries with 2. - The artwork is beautiful (and I really appreciate the fact that they are actual paintings and not digital artwork). - The common die pool mechanic creates player interaction since grabbing someone else's dice can really help you out (unless they recall their dice before you use them). - Excellent blend of dice manipulation, racing to score cards and collecting the American Indian cards. - This game moves along because you only get to take one action on your turn (it can slow down a bit when someone is figuring out how to complete multiple cards). - Discoveries has a nice progression arc to it, it does not suffer from the fits and starts of Lewis and Clark, and in my opinion is the far superior game.
I am looking forward to getting in more plays of this game and I think it will be a hit with my family. I'm sure we will add a copy to our collection soon, especially since my kids are focusing on early US history this year and this would be a fun game to play when they need some downtime.[/i]

item.name: Dominion
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Dominion[/COLOR] was traded away for Ticket to Ride (3/3/14). Received in a trade for Innovation (Iello version) 1/21/14.
My thoughts:
[i]Wow, I have been looking forward to trying this one and now that I have I am not impressed. I find it extremely dry and all about the mechanics. There is no theme at all, the cards simply state what the action is, no fluff or flavor at all. This game has made me appreciate Legendary and eminent domain even more. I am surprised at how much the lack of theme really bothers me with this game, but I am uninterested in playing again. My kids do not like it at all.[/i]

item.name: The Downfall of Pompeii
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]The Downfall of Pompeii[/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 10/5/15. (Received Marvel VS 2PCG) Received in a math trade (9/22/14).
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]8[/COLOR]):
[i]This game lasted a year in our collection and we really enjoyed our 10 plays (in fact this is a game my dad played with us). I have to admit that after the last few plays we decided that we played the game out. Yes there is randomness in each game based on the card draw and tile selection/placement, but the game started to feel samey.
