We all new where the best spots on the board were and even throwing other players people into the volcano started to lose it's charm. All that said I would still recommend this game to other families, just go into knowing that it will likely have a limited number of plays in it for you but I'm sure you'll enjoy the ride.
I also need to admit that I may have been hasty getting rid of Survive: Escape from Atlantis! which received twice as many plays as Pompeii before I traded it. Looking back Survive definitely had a lot more variety in the way the game played out. I would consider getting another copy since it was a game that we played a lot with our extended family (especially once we got the 5/6 player expansion.)[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Fun! Everyone loves throwing meeples into the volcanoes and blocking other peoples paths to safety with a well placed lava tile. - Another great family game; easy to teach with nice components (especially the volcano). - My dad has had fun playing this with my kids. He enjoys games like this and Survive: Escape from Atlantis!. - I like how the people placement works when you are able to place out "family" members if there are already people in a building. - Love the tile placement for the lava flow after the volcano erupts (the opposite of Survive where you are removing tiles).[/i]
item.wishlistcomment: Received in a math trade (9/22/14).

item.name: Dragon's Gold
item.comment: Highlights: - A negotiation game with a one minute time limit! This game runs at a brisk pace and adds real tension to the negotiations. - Great art, and I appreciate how the theme ties in with the mechanisms. [i]You are fighting dragons with different characters of varying strength and sometimes special abilities.[/i] [i]- The magic object cards add some fun special powers into the game, at least for the person playing the card.[/i] - I appreciate the fact that this game focuses solely on negotiation and nails it, there is zero bloat in this game. - All of the above points make this an excellent family game, my daughter loved it.

item.name: Dragonwood
item.comment: [i]This would be a fun game to play with Lilly when she's a bit older (maybe 6 or 7), but is way too light for my other kids. It is a quick playying card game that includes some dice rolling. You are trying to defeat monsters using sets of cards ("x" of a kind or straights of like color) which allow you to roll a certain number of dice. There were enough different elements to keep the game fresh, but I would only recommend it for people with younger kids (6 - 8) or for gamers looking for a very light filler with some clever card play and dice rolling.[/i]

item.name: The Duke
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]The Duke[/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 9/21/14. (Received The Downfall of Pompeii)
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]4[/COLOR]):
[i]I understand that this game could be engaging if you enjoy abstracts with a chess like feel, but it is far from the kind of game I enjoy playing. I am glad to have tried it, but it's not a game my family and I enjoyed.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (6):
[i]This game had been on my wishlist for a while and then it went oop. A few weeks ago I saw it a local FLGS so I picked it up having never played it before. I was really excited to get it to the table, so my son and I stopped at a cafe on the way home to give it a few plays.
I found it to be somewhat boring and mediocre. I think I might be the problem though, because I don't really think I care for most abstract games, especially ones that feel like chess. The way the tiles move is really cool and the fact that they flip over and have different movement patterns on the back is interesting. However; the game just isn't that interesting. The game wants to be epic and exciting, but you are playing on a small grid where the movement always feels constrained.[/i]

item.name: Dungeon Petz
item.comment:
Wow this game is heavy, there is a lot going on. [i](As a point of reference I think Agricola is easier to teach/learn/play.)[/i] At first my son struggled, but as the game went on he started to get a handle on things.
Highlights: - Love the artwork and theme... brilliant. - The bidding mechanic that determines which workers get placed first. - Puzzling out how to manage all of your monsters needs. - A really weighty worker placement game with a great theme (although I still prefer Agricola).
[i]I really enjoyed my play of this and I would gladly play again. However; this is not a game I would ever own because my wife and older daughter would not like how much micro management there is in this game.
BTW: I have seen this game recommended as a family game and I strongly disagree. This game is heavy and unforgiving, do not let the theme fool you.[/i]

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons: The Legend of Drizzt Board Game
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Dungeons & Dragons: The Legend of Drizzt Board Game [/COLOR]
My thoughts:
[i]This was one of the first games I got to play with my kids. At the time we had played a lot of Forbidden Island, so I thought a dungeon crawl co-op sounded fun. This game is easy to teach and definitely accessible to kids. My kids really enjoyed it for a while, this was a game they would play by themselves sometimes.
However; eventually our collection began to grow and this game just sat on our shelves in favor of other games. I definitely think this game looses some of it's luster after multiple plays, the game play gets repetitive and stale.[/i]

item.name: Dynasties
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Dynasties (now Sun Tzu)[/COLOR] was sold via auction 11/5/15.
My thoughts:
[i]I can see the merits of this game, but it was very dry. I've been looking for a good 2p area control game, but unfortunately the search continues. I enjoyed it more than my son, in large part because he didn't engage in any kind of bluffing and just tried to bulldoze his way to victory. That lead to him receiving a very through beating. While I think the game offers some decent tactical depth, we were both bored while playing it. In the past we probably would give it a few more plays, but we have too many excellent 2p games that we enjoy playing much more.
If you are looking for a 2p tactical game that offers a lot of back and forth and bluffing I can't recommend Battle Line enough. While technically not area control there is a push pull element to this game and you can go all out for a quick victory via a break through or take your time and win by capturing the majority of flags (5 of 9).[/i]
item.wishlistcomment: [i]After watching Marco's review I definitely want to find the Jolly Roger edition. The box size alone is reason enough, I also like the simplicity of cubes versus plastic figures and the easy to read scoring tiles.[/i]

item.name: Easy Breezy Travel Agency
item.comment: This is one of Dice Hate Me's rabbit games [i](a collection of quick playing card games)[/i]. The game is fun, but very light and there isn't really anything that stood out about it. I am not sure that a game like this can stand up against other cards games in this same space [i](such as [thing=56692][/thing], [thing=340][/thing], [thing=153065][/thing], [thing=151835][/thing] or [thing=154905][/thing] - which is another game in this line).[/i]

item.name: Eclipse
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Eclipse[/COLOR] was sold via auction 4/20/15. Received in a math trade (3/17/15).
My thoughts:
[i]This was a tough one to judge. I played a 2p game with my son and by the end the whole experience fell flat for us. There was very little tension since we could each explore our own part of the board. Then when there was finally some conflict I demolished a large portion of his fleet making it almost impossible for him to come back. The ancients in the base game are too weak to put up much of a challenge by the mid game. However, early game, my son got hosed because every tile he explored had ancient ones while I was getting tiles where I could place out my cubes unimpeded.
All that said I loved the game and think it would shine with at least 4 players. I would love to play it again at that player count, but that isn't going to happen in my house so I decided to purge it. [/i]

item.name: Egizia
item.comment:
[i]Definitely a game I need to play again to see how I really feel about it. I honestly don't understand how Egizia is often touted as the heavier version of Stone Age. I agree Egizia is heavier, but fail to see any other connection besides the fact that they are both WP games. To be honest I thought I would enjoy the game much more, but I am starting to realize that I'm not as big a fan of games where you are searching for bonus cards to score (the major scoring opportunity in this game). I much prefer wp games like Targi, Agricola and Snowdonia where there is some resource conversion and all of the point scoring opportunities are known right from the beginning of the game.
I did enjoy the tension created by the wp mechanic; as you progress down the Nile you can never claim an action you already passed. Sometimes you really need to take a certain space, but how much are you willing to pass by to get there? Great mechanic in an otherwise standard game.
I am sure part of my feelings toward this game come from the fact that I've now played a lot of wp games and I've figured out what kind of mechanics I'm looking for in that type of game. Had I played this when I first got in the hobby I would have enjoyed it much more. As it is I'd probably rather lay Stone Age at this point. I'm glad I got to play and I would definitely enjoy playing again, but it is no longer a game that I want to add to our collection.[/i]

item.name: Eight-Minute Empire
item.comment:
I found this to be a very bland area control game. Two things probably doomed this game from the start, I played El Grande around the same time and I only played two player. I could see this game being better with more, but not that much better. Everything about the game is bland and boring and the set collection really doesn't fit in with area control.
[i]This is one I was glad to try, because now I know it is not a game I want to own. Although I would play it again with more than two.[/i]

item.name: Elder Sign
item.comment:
Another co-op game that fell completely flat for me. Part of it may be due to how the game played out. We got the crap beaten out of us, but once the great one came out we handily defeated it [i](which felt very anti-climactic)[/i]. The Cthulhu Mythos isn't necessarily my thing, it's approaching zombie status as far as pop culture over saturation.
There is not much else to say, the game play was kind of blah. Basically you are rolling dice yahtzee style to fill orders on a card [i](room)[/i]. Succeed and get a reward, fail and bad things happen. I can also see how this game could easily outstay it's welcome because the game play is so basic.

item.name: Elysium
item.comment:
Received in a math trade. (10/5/15)
- Different take on a tableau builder because cards are activated if they are in your Domain, but will only score you end game points if they are moved to your Elysium. - You can drastically change the way the game plays out based on which of the decks you use. - The Apollo deck is a must play, it introduces the oracle which allows you to see upcoming cards for future rounds. - The artwork is excellent, I appreciate the decision to have different artists illustrate each separate deck. - The last round can go a bit long because you need to make sure you get everything done before the game ends. - Similar to other tableau builders there are a lot of card abilities you need to pay attention to. My ease of play list for tableau builders which goes from virtually no upkeep to almost too much: Race for the Galaxy -> Deus -> Elysium -> Imperial Settlers.

item.name: Eminent Domain
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Eminent Domain[/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 3/12/14. (Received Thebes: The Tomb Raiders)
My toughts:
[i]This an odd one, this was a game we got early on and played it quite a bit. Then we got [thing=28143][/thing] which killed this game, causing Eminent Domain to become a victim of the Jones Theory.
Fast forward to earlier this month and I picked up a copy with the expansion thinking this would add something more to the game. It really hasn't, the new research cards are okay, but they just don't add enough to make this game exciting.
In RFtG you feel the tension of the dwindling amount of turns you have left; Eminent feels more like a crawl with a very abrupt end. In the end this is just not my cup of tea, and as you will notice later on I really don't care for deck building games at all. (The one exception is Super Motherload)[/i]

item.name: Eminent Domain: Escalation
item.comment: [COLOR=#FF0000]Eminent Domain: Escalation[/COLOR] was sold with my 2nd copy of Eminent Domain.

item.name: Enchanted Forest
item.comment:
[i]- Beautiful board and excellent components [i](the trees look awesome set up on the board)[/i]. - Great theme, has all of the classic fairy tale characters. - Roll and move with a choice... you roll two dice and you can move forward with both, back with both or use one to go forward and the other to move backwards.[/i]
[i]I did use a suggested variant for younger kids and we played with 3 face up quest cards at once.[/i]

item.name: The Enchanted Tower
item.comment:
Christmas gift 2013 (Lilly)
[i]- Amazing family game that you can play with young children. [i]My youngest daughter was almost 4 when she started playing.[/i] - The components are top notch: the wooden prince and sorcerer and a cute plastic princess with a crown. - Beautiful game board. - The tower: The princess "jumps" out when you select the right slot to put the key in. - The prince can be played by a few people to help the younger ones remember where you have looked. - Nice variation on roll and move which involves 2 dice, one for movement and one for which player moves first. - I could see us playing this with only adults for some light hearted fun.
This game will never leave our collection, I hope to play it with my grandchildren some day![/i]

item.name: Escape: The Curse of the Temple
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Escape: The Curse of the Temple[/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 9/14/14. (Received Port Royal)
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR])
[i]This game fell quickly; my kids found this game really stressful and never requested to play it. Also, after 15 plays, I feel like we saw everything it had to offer and adding expansions wasn't really going to change much. This is another co-op game that has fizzled out with my family, therefore I traded it away.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8.5):
[i]- Great soundtrack, really sets the mood for this game. - The theme comes through; you feel like you are trapped in some horrible temple with little time to escape. - Nice artwork and components, I really like the Indiana Jones meeples. - Plays in 10 minutes making this a great beginning/end of night game.[/i]

item.name: Evolution
item.comment:
Initial thoughts and rating (6):
[i]This was high on my want to play list, so I was happy when Drew offered to bring it to a meet up. My first play included the flight expansion, which in hindsight adds some much needed variety to the game play. After 3 plays I'm already finding the game to be severely limited in the amount of variety the evolution cards offer.
In my opinion Evolution occupies the same game space as tableau builders like Race and Roll for the Galaxy, Elysium, Imperial Settlers and Deus yet is severely limited by a small set of species abilities. I understand that the combination of these abilities can change how the different species interact, but there are still only a handful of different ways to evolve your species. Also it is extremely hard to play a carnivore which my kids found really frustrating (even though they were eating me, it was only small bites so I was still raking in the points).. I was able to win 2 of the games I played while completely ignoring the carnivore strategy while my opponents were busy eating my dinosaurs, but unable to consume the same amount of food I was.
I think Evolution is a solid game and if asked I would play it again, but even with the Flight expansion this still isn't a game I want to own.[/i]

item.name: Excape
item.comment:
[i]Excape is a great push your luck, family game that would easily replace Can't Stop if I could find a copy. I only played once, but that's all it took to figure out that this is an awesome dice filler. I can't help but compare Excape to Can't Stop because they are both pure push your luck games that deal with probability.
I actually really enjoy both games a lot, with one exception for Can't Stop that Excape solves... play time. Can't Stop with 3 and especially 4 tends to overstay its welcome. There are always edge of your seat moments, but the game drags on too long for what it offers. Excape fixes that, that game plays out at a very quick pace and you aren't constantly moving pieces on a board.[/i]
item.wishlistcomment: [i]Unfortunately OOP and expensive, maybe some day.[/i]

item.name: Fantastiqa
item.comment:
I will start by saying this is an absolutely beautiful game, they did an excellent job choosing artwork that has a whimsical, folk tale feel to it. I was happy to finally try the game, although at this point I have come to realize that I really don't care for the deck building mechanic. As much as I wanted to love the game (I thought it would be a great gift for my older daughter) it fell flat. I played a 2p game and it lasted over an hour and there really weren't many decisions to be made; the meaningful decisions were few an far between.
[i]All that said I think Fantastiqa is a great intro into deck building, especially for a family.[/i]

item.name: Fields of Arle
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Fields of Arle[/COLOR] was sold via auction 11/5/15. Received in a trade (6/1/15)
Initial thoughts and rating:
[i]- A wide open Uwe game that still leaves you feeling that you could have accomplished more and been more efficient. - A staggering amount of ways to build your engine/score points and they each feel unique. - Surprisingly easy to get into even though there are so many paths open to you in the beginning of the game, it opens up quite naturally and thematically makes sense. - I really appreciate the autobiographical perspective this game offers. I always enjoy playing games that have ties to history, even if it is a personal view of of a time/place (this feels like one of Uwe's more thematic games). - Typical amazing Lookout bits/production, with beautiful artwork by Dennis Lohausen. - As much as I have enjoyed my initial plays of FoA it still doesn't come close to surpassing Agricola for me.[/i]

item.name: Finca
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Finca[/COLOR]
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]10[/COLOR]):
[i]Thankfully I grabbed a copy on the marketplace before prices began to skyrocket. This game continues to see consistent play, especially as a 2p game with my wife. We both love this game, it plays fast and when we play it is a very relaxed gaming experience. To this day I still can not recommend it highly enough. As far as my kids, my son really doesn't like it much anymore since we have so many other games to choose from now.
My older daughter on the other hand still enjoys playing, although she to usually will pick another game to play. Hopefully this game will see a reprint, it is a great gateway/family/2 player game![/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (9):
[i]- Excellent gateway/family game, simple rules and easy to teach. - Plays well at all player counts, especially with 2. - Very strategic in the 2p game because you can plan ahead when it comes to your movement on the rondel. - High replay value due to the random order tile, bonus tile and rondel set up. - Beautiful board, and amazing fruit meeples. - This is one of the most relaxing games to play that I have in my collection. - The perfect chill with a :tankard: board game.[/i]

item.name: Finca: El Razul
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Finca: El Razul[/COLOR]
Initial thoughts and rating (10):
[i]I love what this adds to the game play, the extra action tile is great (it allows you to move an opponents pawn and collect fruit/donkeys with it). The wild windmill tile can make it easier to get a fruit that you've had a hard time acquiring. My favorite part is probably the farmer, I took advantage of him multiple times [he allows you to pay in any fruit on a tile as long as the quantities match, i.e. 2 of one and 3 of another).[/i] I do question whether we played the drought tiles right, it seems like a free 2 points are available if they happen to be face up when you sell fruit. Maybe it would entice you to sell a smaller lot of fruit.
Overall I'd highly recommend picking this up if you own Finca which really deserves a reprint). You can still order the Spiel magazine that includes this promo direct from their website. I also ended up getting all the Castles of Burgundy promos as well. [/i]

item.name: Firenze
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Firenze[/COLOR] was sold via auction 8/2/14.
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]8[/COLOR]):
[i]This is a tough one. I really enjoyed playing this game, but unfortunately my family did not (they found it boring). Firenze has a very clean and streamlined rule set that offers a lot of variety in the tactics you employ to play the game. There is nothing fiddly about this game.
I really enjoyed the tension created by having to manage only one resource in the game (the tower pieces are also your currency). The cards really give this games some legs and help increase player interaction. I also appreciate how the cards also function as a market of sorts were the new tower pieces are placed. It creates some great moments where you only want/need the card or tower pieces but you are forced to take either a card or building pieces you don't want.
This is another great family game that I would probably recommend, but the theme is very dry and for my family the game play got repetitive after a few plays. I also don't think that this game plays well with 2, most of the tension is lost and each player ends up doing their own thing. It also didn't help that I got The Palaces of Carrara around the same time and that has been a hit with my family, especially my wife, and it plays great with 2.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Plays good with 2, but better with more. - This game is a bit simpler than Palaces of Carrara which means that my kids feel more confident when playing this game. - The building blocks are also the currency for the game used when purchasing a card farther down the track. - The addition of the cards introduces some more strategy into the game because not only do you get the card effect (good or bad) but you also get whatever blocks are stacked on that card. - This game is very easy to teach[/i]
item.conditiontext:
Excellent condition, only played a few times. All the components are bagged.
Trade Interest: Medium (I really enjoy this game, but no one else in my family really does so I am open to trading it).

item.name: Five Tribes
item.comment: I'll keep it short on game play since this game has been discussed so much. I have played twice and had fun, but both games I played went on too long due to some players having some serious AP. I understand that this isn't an issue with every group, but it definitely is a problem with some of the people I've played with and it would be a huge problem with my wife [i](she would definitely bog down while playing)[/i] so as much as I enjoy the game play it just doesn't fit in with the circle of people I game with so I removed it from my wishlist.

item.name: Flash Point: Fire Rescue
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Flash Point: Fire Rescue[/COLOR] was sold via auction 4/4/15 (with 2nd Story expansion).
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
[i]Another COOP that started with a bang and then fizzled out. The other two plays came in May 2014 (one month after we got it) and then just sat on the shelf. I finally decided to get rid of a few weeks ago to make some room on our game shelves.
Flash Point is a good family game, but COOP's continue to not get played in my house (well except for Pandemic: Legacy).[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]First I need to say that I am not a huge fan of Coops, but I wanted to try to find one that was thematic and that I could enjoy playing with my family. Long story short, Flash Point fills that niche in our collection.
Highlights: - Awesome theme that is well integrated into the game mechanics. - Great family game and since it is a coop you can potentially play with younger kids. - Great bits that enhance the game. - You actually feel the tension ratchet up as a house fills with smoke and fire. - The group of characters you can play are all interesting and affect the game in different ways. Sometimes it does make sense to change the character you are playing as.[/i]
item.conditiontext:
Condition: Excellent, components are all bagged.
Edition: English second edition (which includes the plastic firefighter meeples)
Sweeteners: Flash Point: Fire Rescue – 2nd Story (stored in the base game box)

item.name: Flash Point: Fire Rescue – 2nd Story
item.comment: [COLOR=#FF0000]FP: Second Stories[/COLOR] was sold with Flash Point.
item.conditiontext: Will only trade with base game.

item.name: Fleet
item.comment:
Received in a trade (12/29/14).
[i]- Really nice artwork and components. The card quality is outstanding. - Employs one of my favorite mechanics, using cards for multiple purposes. - The auctions add something new to this type of game [i](I am comparing it to a game like [thing=28143]Race[/thing]).[/i] - Played well with two using the captains from Arctic Bounty. - Fairly straight forward game to learn/teach, could definitely be a family game in my house. - Plays quick, almost too quickly, but I am not sure about this yet. It may have been the result of using the salty captain cards.
I thought the 2p experience was good, but I think it would be much better with more players. That is the sticking point for me, I know my son would dig it but not sure about my daughter and wife. In my opinion you still can't beat 2p [thing=28143]Race[/thing] when it comes to this type of game. However; I really enjoyed the auction mechanic.
Quick update: my daughter loves it![/i]

item.name: Fleet Wharfside
item.comment:
Received in a trade (10/25/15).
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]I was really excited to get this one since Fleet is one of my favorite games, but it doesn't hit the table as much as I'd like )in part because you need more than 2 players for the game to shine). I was hoping to find another game in the Fleet universe that would be a bit easier to set up and play. After a couple of plays I can happily say Fleet Wharfside has delivered.
- Plays up to 4, but is still an excellent 2p game that will make a great cafe/pub game. - While it uses the Fleet theme (and great artwork) the game play is different and timing becomes very important. - Contract cards are now scored via a set collection mechanic, but until you score them they will give you a special ability to use. - Buying contracts and buildings (which are worth straight VP in Wharfside) involves collecting a certain type/quantity of cards, but the market changes every time a card is purchased. - There is a hierarchy to the fish (think poker hands) so you can always substitute a higher ranking set of fish to buy a contract. - King crab are played to your tableau for VP, but they are also the highest ranking fish when it comes time to buy contracts. [/i]

item.name: Fleet: Arctic Bounty
item.comment:
Received in a trade (12/29/14).
[i]See Fleet comments.[/i]

item.name: FlowerFall
item.comment: [i]This was fun once, but not a game I want to play again. Cool concept, but obviously it's extremely random.[/i]

item.name: For Sale
item.comment:
Received in a math trade (9/21/14).
[i]- Excellent, quick filler that I can see playing with extended family and friends. - Easy to teach, you can teach as you play (only explaining one phase at a time). - I can see this becoming a staple when beginning or ending a game night. - A great family game that can be a great first step in learning bidding/auction games. - Awesome week night filler, we can get a 4p game in under 20 minutes.[/i]

item.name: Forbidden Desert
item.comment: - Another fun, family co-op designed by Matt Leacock (Forbidden Island/Pandemic) with typical top notch art and components. - Happy to find out that it plays much differently than Forbidden Island and is a definite step up in difficulty (this game can be brutal). - The sand building up on the board is really helps immerse you in the theme and helps build tension. - A few role repeats and some brand new ones; what's cool is the old roles still feel fresh because of how differently this game plays out and the interactions with the new roles. - I enjoy having to find the pieces by uncovering the two tiles and finding where they intersect to unearth the treasure. - Quick playtime, Forbidden Desert is another game we can easily bust out on a night when we don't have a lot of time to play a game. It also helps that it's a co-op so there won't be hurt feelings when playing with tired kids who are begging me to play a game :)

item.name: Forbidden Island
item.comment:
[b][i]The game that started it all![/b]
Our first designer board game, this is the game that got my family and I into this hobby. This game helped teach my kids how to cooperate when playing games and not to take gaming too seriously. It also helped my kids to learn to lose gracefully, especially since we all lost!
Highlights: - Great gateway game for families, easy to learn. - Beautiful components and great artwork on the tiles.[/i]

item.name: Fresco
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Fresco[/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 11/10/14. (Received Vikings)
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
[i]I still really like this game, and would be willing to play anytime but my family did not care for it. We also have a lot of worker placement games and this one wasn't seeing any play time so it got traded. I still maintain this is an excellent family game, but for us it fell victim to the Jones theory.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Theme: I am an artist and art teacher so I love the theme of painting a Fresco, especially the color mixing mechanic. - As always beautiful production quality from Queen games. - Love the happiness rating which goes up or down based on how early/late you get up. - My family loves worker placement games (I know this is more a simultaneous action selection game but to my family it is WP).
This is another great family game put out by Queen games. (We also own and enjoy Escape: The Curse of the Temple and Via Appia.) My older daughter is 8 and she has no trouble playing this game well.[/i]

item.name: Friday the 13th
item.comment:
This was the first trick taker of the night Mat introduced me to during our gaming meet up. Perfect game for Halloween Eve, we played the Poison version which had some cool cauldrons to play your cards on.
This one reminded me a bit of [thing=56692][/thing] since you didn't score points if you had the most of a color. As a plus I think this would be a great introduction into trick taking games for kids because the game play is so straight forward.

item.name: Galaxy Trucker
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Galaxy Trucker[/COLOR] was traded away for Firenze 3/26/14.
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR])
[i]I realized recently that the expansion killed this game for me. It added way to many rules/mechanics with very little pay out. I actually enjoyed the base game and I am now looking for a copy (mostly because my son loves this game).[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (7.5):
[i]First couple of games were shaky, lots of rules to remember. I thought this was going to end up being a poor purchase decision, but even though my kids ships are getting trashed they still want to play. Also this has been the worst game, by far, to punch out all the cardboard chits. Even when using a razor blade I still had a few pieces tear.
I think this is a fun family game, my kids really enjoy playing. They love building things (hence our huge collection of legos) and this game offers them a chance to do that. My daughter Madeline (who just turned 8) can hold her own. Her ships are not always as well built, but she has won because she always builds ships with tons of storage. They both handle it well when parts of their ship are destroyed, we usually have a good laugh. I would recommend this as a good family game, especially if your kids love to build things.[/i]
item.wishlistcomment: Not a week goes by that jus on doesn't lament trading this one. Not my favorite, but definitely one of his. [i]Will probably be a b-day gift for him.[/i]

item.name: Galaxy Trucker: Another Big Expansion
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Galaxy Trucker: Another Big Expansion[/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 4/14/14. (Received Targi and Parade Z-Man Edition)
My thoughts:
[i]I have come to realize that this expansion made me really dislike Galaxy Trucker. Just figuring out he movement of the intruders on your ship is enough to drive you crazy. Also added too many additional parts to build your ship. I like the new ship components. The level 4 ships are cool, but a flight with them takes an hour. The new predators and commandos sound cool, but figuring out their movement path is a game in and of itself... highly frustrating. This adds length to a game I already find too long for what it is.[/i]

item.name: The Game of 49
item.comment:
Highlights: - The perfect introductory auction game. - Excellent family game that you can teach to anyone. - Everything about the game feels familiar, so it is very easy to teach/learn.
I love auction games [i]([thing=46][/thing], [thing=12][/thing], [thing=220][/thing] and [thing=34219][/thing] to name a few)[/i] but they are not always easy to grasp for kids. Up until I played this I thought [thing=172][/thing] was the best introductory auction game for families, and it is still a great game. However; now I would rather play The Game of 49 with my family.

item.name: Gardens
item.comment:
[i]- The theme and artwork are beautiful, love the aesthetic of the flower bed drawings [i](they look like 1950's floral fabric patterns)[/i]. - The biggest surprise for me is how well it plays with 2*, which has become my preferred player count. - I don't know how the designer figured it all out, but the placement of the 4 colors on each tile is always less than ideal. When playing a 2p game you are almost always giving your opponent a leg up in another flower bed when placing tiles. - It takes a lot of planning and a bit of luck, but you can finish multiple flower beds on one turn which is extremely satisfying. - The tie breaker is perfect and since the scores are fixed [i](you can score a maximum of 10/8 points)[/i] this could have easily made the conclusion of the game anticlimactic. [i]Tie breaker rule - you have to count how many sections of each flower bed are match the color of the flower bed tile you place. This adds to the strategy because you are constantly trying to complete flower beds with a 2 color majority. [/i]
*I wasn't going to get the game once I read the 2p rules because it sounded like it wouldn't be as streamlined to play since both players control 2 colors. However; what I found was that the 2p game is actually the most tactical game, where you can really plan your future moves since only one other person is placing a tile between your turns.[/i]

item.name: Ghooost!
item.comment: [i]I can see how this game would appeal to kids because of the theme and artwork, but it is a convoluted version of Uno that is not nearly as fun* (*and I don't love Uno). Not something I would ever play again, I can't imagine this game being produced to the same level if it wasn't designed by Richard Garfield.[/i]

item.name: Ginkgopolis
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Ginkgopolis[/COLOR] was sold via auction 7/10/15.
My thoughts:
[i]- I love the area control aspect of the game, there is a lot of direct interaction as the board state constantly changes. - The city building enhances the player interaction. You can either increase the size of the city or make existing buildings taller (which gives you the opportunity to take control of another players building). - The whole time you are doing this you also have to manage your resources and tiles (the buildings you can place) which is tense and fun.
So far I am enamored with the game, then it comes time to score and things start falling apart.I really dislike the scoring in this game. Maybe I am stuck on the elegant simplicity of the scoring system of El Grande, which may not be a valid comparison to some, but hear me out. You spend the whole game fighting for control of districts so you can score the most points, but then you also have to take into account the cards you will score as well.
Here is my problem, you can certainly try and plan which cards you may get to score but this could lead you to ignore building towards majorities in certain districts. Some may find managing these opposing scoring mechanisms tense and exciting; I find it frustrating and chaotic. I don't think the two different ways you score blend together at all, there is very little synergy (if any) between the points cards will give you and gaining majorities in districts.
In the end, I love the game play but hate the scoring. I know that I could eventually learn which cards score what, but I am not interested. I wish the scoring was strictly based on area control and didn't involve all of these other seemingly arbitrary scoring cards.[/i]

item.name: Glass Road
item.comment:
[i]- Plays great with 2 - Quick playtime: 20 minutes per player is accurate. - Resource management including how the production wheels work when producing bricks and glass. - Card play: having to chooses which workers you want to use while also trying to figure out which ones your opponents may want to use (this reminds me a bit of RFtG). - The buildings that are available from game to game really change your strategy, and make this a game with a lot of replay value. - Great production quality, love the eater eggs found in the artwork on some of the tiles.
This may not be Uwe Rosenberg's best game design, but it is probably my favorite. A big part of this is the combination of short play time and this is a game my wife has recently been requesting to play. She does not usually like games with lots of moving parts, but after a couple of plays this game has clicked with her. Glass Road is a game that will see consistent play for a long time.[/i]

item.name: Glory to Rome
item.comment:
Loved this game, which isn't really a surprise since I have loved every game where cards are used for multiple purposes (RFtG and Bruges). I could imagine playing this over and over again, constantly trying new strategies to win the game.
The only problem is finding a copy that doesn't cost an arm and a leg. I have decided to hold out and play Impulse before deciding to plop down the money to get a copy of GTR. (Unfortunately Impulse didn't cut it.)

item.name: The Golden Ages
item.comment:
Received in a math trade (2/1/15).
[i]Special thanks to [user=eekamouse]Joel Eddy[/user] for bringing this game to my attention during his top 10 games of 2014 video.
- I love the art and aesthetics of this game. It is a very clean/slick presentation with very clear iconography. - This is the perfect Euro style civ building game, the rule set is quite intuitive and easy to learn. - Perfect blend of in game and end game scoring, you are never quite sure how you are doing in the game [i](mostly due to your personal end game goal and the military vp)[/i]. - The tech tree might appear slightly generic, but wow does it offer tons of different strategies to explore. - Leaders, they all offer different perks and you get to choose whether or not you want to upgrade your leader each age. - Declaring a Golden Age will net you 2 gold for every turn other players take after you, which really forces you to play as efficiently as possible (having gold in this game is very important because you pay to unlock techs and attack other players)[/i].

item.name: El Grande
item.comment:
Received in a trade (10/28/14). [i]This is the Decennial Edition.[/i]
[i]- Elegant! This game has such a simple rule set, yet there is so much depth and strategy to explore. - Plays great with 3, 4 and 5. - A lot of player interaction, this is not multiplayer solitaire. - My favorite mechanic is secretly selecting a territory to place/move guys using the dial, there are a lot of memorable moments created because of this (Especially when it comes to the Castillo). - Great family game, my 9 year old daughter has picked up this game quickly because the rules are so simple. - For a 20 year old game it still looks good, especially the Castillo.[/i]

item.name: Gravwell: Escape from the 9th Dimension
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Gravwell[/COLOR] was sold 8/2/14 via auction.
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]8[/COLOR]):
[i]This was another game I really enjoyed playing that fell flat with my family (mostly my kids). I really thought the gravity mechanic worked well and there was just enough chaos in the game. I always enjoyed seeing my "brilliant" plan foiled by someone playing a card I didn't expect. I also thought the few card types that either pulled ships toward you or pushed you away from the gravitational pull worked well in mixing up the game play and adding an element of unknown to your play.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Great, light family game (my 2 older kids had no problem figuring out the game after 1 play). - Interesting twist on racing since your movement is tied to the gravity of surrounding ships and how close you are to them. - The drafting mechanic that begins each round when you choose one face up card and one face down card. - Plays well with 2, 3 and 4 players. - Quick: great week night game (plays in 20 - 30 minutes). - The colors used on the board/ cards. - My wife enjoys it and has a knack for playing this game well.[/i]

item.name: The Great Heartland Hauling Co.
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]The Great Heartland Hauling Co.(2013)[/COLOR] was traded away with Las Vegas Boulevard, Sushi Go and Thunder Alley for Fleet/Fleet Arctic Bounty (with all KS rewards), Friday and Viva Java the Dice Game 12/29/14.
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
[i]This is a tough one for me to decide on. I thought I had found a small footprint and quick playing pick up and deliver game. We had tried Perry Rhodan and thought it was okay, then I played Great Heartland and really enjoyed it. Once it was reprinted I picked up a copy and I got it to the table a few times with my gaming group and a few times with my son.
In the end I think it is an okay game, but I think it outstays its welcome. By the end I really just want the game to end, but you end up scratching and clawing your way to the finish and it feels quite anticlimactic because the winner has always been decided a few turns before the game actually ends.
I would play it again if asked, but in the end it didn't deliver. I'm still looking for a quick, small footprint PU&D game but haven't found it yet (both Perry Rhodan and Akrotiri also fell short).[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- An excellent pick up and deliver game that plays in about a 1/2 hour. - Plays great with 2. - Small footprint, would make an excellent cafe game. - Plenty of meaty decisions to be made, feels like a full sized pick up and deliver game packed into a card game. - You need to plan good routes since you can only pick up or deliver on each turn, and you have to move each turn. - Great use of cards to create 2 currencies you need to manage (gas for movement and goods to pick up/sell goods). - Variant map layouts depending on the number of players that really change how the game plays out.
This is exactly the quick playing pick up and deliver game I was looking for (Perry Rhodan: The Cosmic League didn't cut it).[/i]
item.conditiontext: Excellent condition, only played a few times.

item.name: Greed
item.comment: [i]This game fell completely flat. I love drafting games, but I felt like there was one thing to many to manage making it difficult to combo cards together. On top of that the theme is a huge turn off for me, I am surprised Queen chose a theme that is not family friendly at all.[/i]

item.name: Guildhall
item.comment:
[i]- Plays great with 2. - Another great cafe game, as long as you put it into a smaller box. - An interesting take on set collection, each card type has special abilities dependent upon how many have already been played in your guild hall. - There is a surprising amount of depth (I feel like I am still scratching at the surface) for a game that only has 6/12 different card types. - Quick playtime, about a 1/2 hour for a 2p game.
Quick update: I do not enjoy this game with 4, it drags on for way too long. I will only play his game with 2 or 3 from now on.[/i]

item.name: Guildhall: Job Faire
item.comment:
Easter gift 2014 (Madeline)
[i]I love the new professions, just adds more variety to an already great game. I probably prefer this set of cards but I would recommend the original Guild Hall to new players.
*I will be logging all my plays under Guildhall.[/i]

item.name: Guillotine
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Guillotine[/COLOR] was traded away for Alhambra Anniversary Edition 3/11/14.
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR])
[i]This is an okay game that I would play if someone else brought it out. Since this was one of the first games I got it has since been replaced by other card games I would much rather play (Arboretum, Diamonds, Cockroach Poker, Parade to name a few).[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (7.5)
[i]Got this for 0.75 at a homeschool curriculum sale. (I also got Loot for 0.50) After one 2p game with my wife I am slightly disappointed, but it was our first play. My kids enjoyed it but we never play since there is always something else we can play, even if we want a shorter game.[/i]

item.name: Haggis
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Haggis[/COLOR] - I gave my copy to my dad, so I'll still get to play it.[/i]
My thoughts:
[i]Has since been replaced by Parade and Diamonds, which are 2 other card games my dad and son would rather play.
I have been playing Cribbage for over 25 years, mostly with my dad. We have played countless games of Cribbage, so when I found out about Haggis I was intrigued, but I knew my dad was my most likely opponent. The question was would my dad forgo a game of Cribbage to play Haggis?
The short answer is yes. We are still in the early stages of unwrapping the layers of strategy found in this game, and we are really enjoying this game.[/i]

item.name: Hanabi
item.comment:
I played one game with Mat and Joel to close out a great day of gaming at the TotalCon summer sizzler event. We thought we were going to score a perfect round until we realized that the game is scored once the last card is drawn. I have to admit that even though I don't really like co-ops I really enjoyed my one play of this. I could see playing this a bunch of times in a row, getting really good at it and then giving it away to someone else so they can solve the puzzle.
[i]I would definitely like to play this one again, but I am not sure that I want to own it.[/i]

item.name: Harbour
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Harbour[/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 3-17-15. (Received TTR India/Switzerland)
My thoughts:
[i]This is only the second game I kickstarted and wow am I disappointed. Maybe I was expecting too much from this game, but it is very light and too streamlined. Your choices each turn are not very interesting, manipulating the market isn't all that exciting and that is basically the whole game. This is not the quick playing/ lighter version of Le Havre that some people are comparing it too. The decision space is just too limited. Even the building bonuses [i](each card has one of four symbols that give you a bonus)[/i] are really blah.
I am personally even more disappointed because I love the artwork/theme so much. A definite miss for me and not a game I am willing to play again.[/i]
item.conditiontext:
Condition: Excellent
Edition: English first edition
*This is the Kickstarter version and comes with all the stretch goals. It does not include the Belfort promo.

item.name: Le Havre
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Le Havre[/COLOR] was traded away for Fields of Arle .
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]8[/COLOR])
[i]I still actually really like Le Havre, but it was extremely difficult to get to the table and I got offered a great trade. The play time and table space was a major factor in how few times Le Havre got played. I only mention this because I think Le Havre is an excellent design by Uwe, but I like some of his other games more (Agricola, At the Gates of Loyang and Glass Road) and they all play much quicker (usually an hour or less if it's a 2p game).
Since I am not a collector I don't feel the need to own every game created by one of my favorite designers so Le Havre left my collection. There wasn't ever a time that I would choose Le Havre over one of the other Uwe games I own. All that said I'd happily play this again, I still think it's a very good game.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (9):
[i]- Lots of decisions to make/paths to take to try and be successful in this game. - Variability among the buildings which leads to multiple strategies you can pursue. - Resource conversion: I know this may seem like work to some, but I love this in games (Glass Road is another favorite of mine). - I really like the artwork and the components are top notch. - Plays really well with 2.[/i]

item.name: Le Havre: The Inland Port
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Le Havre: The Inland Port[/COLOR] was traded away with Dixit Origins and Splendor for Blue Moon City 10/31/14.
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR])
[i]Initially my kids and I really enjoyed this game, but the lack of any variability to the set up killed it for me. There are different pathes you can take, but each game you define your approach and then execute it without much variance or opposition.
I ended up trading it because we have so many other Uwe games that are awesome with 2 and play fast (Agricola, Agricola All Creatures, Glass Road, Loyang and Patchwork spring to mind).[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- A really thinky game that plays in about a 1/2 hour. - Mechanics: I love figuring out how to use the building in order to maximize the amount of each good I have in my warehouse. - Building variety: There are 30 buildings in the game and you can't maximize each resource so you have to figure out what your scoring focus is going to be. Of course your opponent can then take a building you really wanted, but you can pay them to use that building. - I love using the player board/wheel to keep track of how many times you can use buildings (you can see how he further developed this idea for the resource wheels in Glass Road).[/i]

item.name: High Society
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]High Society[/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 2/7/15. (Received Qwixx/extra score pads) Received in a math trade (11/10/14).
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
[i]I played once with my family and we all would rather play For Sale so I ended up trading this one away. Personally I enjoyed the added mechanic of having to manage your money (if you spend the most, you can't win), but when playing with family it just makes the game a bit more convoluted. I would play it again, but definitely not something I'd seek out to play.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Quick play time, great filler. - Limited amount of money of specific values, which can cause you to overpay for a specific tile. - Tension because of the end game condition: the person with the least amount of money is eliminated from the game before scoring your tiles.[/i]
item.conditiontext: Excellent condition, only played a few times.

item.name: Hyperborea
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Hyperborea[/COLOR] was sold via auction 8/8/15.
My thoughts:
[i]This game held a lot of promise, mostly because I love the idea of deck building but hate shuffling cards continuously so the idea of substituting cubes for cards sounded awesome. Unfortunately the game failed to deliver for both my kids and I.
First turns in this game can be quite slow and prone to AP as you try and plan ahead future turns to make sure you maximize your possible actions without having to reset before getting to pull off the move you want to make. This leads to my next problem, the turns that move quickly for you are usually quite anti-climactic since you didn't get the cards you needed.
I also found the overall aesthetics of the game to be all over the place, the minis were okay, I really liked the card art, but the tiles were ugly and the graphic design was terrible the symbols they use are counter intuitive.
I still think the bag building concept is pretty cool, but unfortunately Hyperborea doesn't deliver. In the end the theme is wasted and the game ends up being disjointed collection of mechanisms and concepts that don't gel together to offer a smooth game play experience.[/i]
item.wishlistcomment: [i]I'd like to try out a bag builder and this would be the easiest sell with my family (I already know my son's interested).[/i]

item.name: Imperial Settlers
item.comment: [i]- Love the artwork in the game, I am a fan of the cartoony style versus something extremely realistic. Also great bits. - Plays great with 2, which means it will see lots of play in my house. - Hits the same sweet spot as RFtG while adding some different mechanics. - Cards can be used for multiple purposes, except it will cost you different resources it is not as simple as just discarding a card for a specific effect. - Multiple factions to play, each with very different strategies/play styles.[/i]

item.name: Imperial Settlers: Atlanteans
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Imperial Settlers Atlanteans[/COLOR] was sold via auction 11/5/15.
My thoughts:
[i]This is a tough one for me because I love the way the Atlanteans faction change the way you play the game. You will not score any points for the Atlantean buildings you construct because they all sink to the bottom of the ocean at the end of the game. The new technology tokens offer all kinds of ways to score extra vp with your common buildings and also help you get extra resources or take extra actions.
I actually really like the new Atlantean common buildings, they offer some new ways to get points, cards and resources and give the other factions even more reasons to collect technology tokens.
Now the not so good news (for me at least):
- Don't play the "peaceful variant" using the Atlantean cards, you need to be able to destroy the Atlantean common buildings or they will run rampant over you. - Now there is even more information to keep track of on a turn by turn basis. It is really easy to forget to takes bonus points throughout the game because there are so many cards laid out in front of you. With all the additional cards from the expansion(s) there are more and more powers/abilities to manage. - Games definitely run longer when playing with the expansion(s), our 2p games take 90 minutes now.
I still really enjoy playing Imperial Settlers, but all of the overhead you need to track during the game is a bit much. I actually find myself wanting to get Deus to the table more because there is a lot less info to track. And by far my favorite tableau builder is Race for the Galaxy which manages to have deep, strategic game play with minimal turn to turn upkeep. I'm interested to see if my plays of Imperial Settlers dip over the next year or if I'm just being cranky right now.[/i]

item.name: Imperial Settlers: Why Can't We Be Friends
item.comment:
[i]I love what this expansion adds to the game; it adds more synergy between the new and existing cards in each faction deck, open production [i](which rocks)[/i] and opens up some new ways to combo certain cards [i](including both the faction and common deck)[/i].
My son and I tried building our own decks, but basically made a mess of it. We are perfectly content to just mix in the new cards and play.
In my opinion this is a must buy if you are a fan of Imperial Settlers![/i]

item.name: Impulse
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Impulse[/COLOR] was sold via auction 8/2/14.
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]4[/COLOR])
[i]I really didn't enjoy my initial plays so the game left our collection. I have zero desire to play this one again. I've played almost all of Carl's games (except Mottainai) and Glory to Rome is by far my favorite (and the only one I can't find a copy of). Every time someone mentions one of his new games it's a reworking of GtR, yet none of them come close to surpassing that game for me.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (6):
[i]In a nut shell I was hoping that this game would scratch the same itch as Glory to Rome and unfortunately it does not. Unlike GtR and RFtG I find the race in this game to be unsatisfying and over too quick. The actions feel bland and mechanical, the theme does not come through at all (and I love sci-fi/ space themes). On top of all of that the artwork and graphic design are quite unappealing to me.[/i]

item.name: Incan Gold
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Incan Gold*[/COLOR] was traded away for Jambo 3/31/14.
My thoughts:
[i]Fun, quick filler that plays up to 8. I bought this to play at family get togethers or a quick open to family game nights in our house and it works great for this purpose. This game is just a simple, yet addictive push your luck game. My only gripe is the component quality is not that good, but for the $ of the game it can be overlooked.
*Moved all 14 of my logged plays of Incan Gold to Diamant (which is the version to hunt down, it has amazing components).[/i]

item.name: Indigo
item.comment:
Joel had told me that this was a really fun game that blows Tsuro out of the water [i](I've never played Tsuro)[/i]. So when the opportunity arose he taught my son and I. I have to admit that I was surprised at how much I liked this game.
Highlights: - Excellent gateway/family game. - Absolutely beautiful board and tiles. I love the artwork. - There is a good amount of player interaction to be found, especially since you share some of the "goals" where you score points. - Simple mechanics, but enough strategy to keep you engaged. It may seem like you don't have a lot of choice, but as the board fills up if you plan well you can score lots of gems. - Great tile laying game that feels different from games like Carcassonne and Alhambra (which are games I enjoy). - Sliding the gems along the path is one of those zen moments in gaming, at least for me (simple things, simple minds...:D)
[i]I am glad Joel taught this game to me, it is now on my wishlist. I think my wife would really enjoy this one.[/i]

item.name: Ingenious
item.comment:
Another new to me game played at the library meet up. First of all this is a great group for these kinds of games since we tend to be a bit raucous. I think this game depends on having the right group dynamic, I could see it becoming very dry and procedural if played with the wrong group.
[i]All that said I would enjoy playing it again, especially since it plays so fast, but it is not necessarily a game that I feel the need to own. Partly because someone in our group has it and I think the more players the better, I would not want to play this with less than 5 or 6.[/i]

item.name: Innovation
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Innovation[/COLOR] was traded away for Dominion 1/21/14.
My thoughts on the Iello version artwork only:
[i]This was the Iello version, and I hated the artwork/ graphic design. I just got the Asamdi version and I love the simplicity of the art and card layout much better.[/i]

item.name: Innovation
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Innovation[/COLOR] was sold via auction 8/2/14. Received in a math trade (4/14/14).
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR])
[i]I have owned both the Iello and Asmadi version of this game and have traded them both away. (I prefer the graphic design and simplicity of the Asmadi version, I hated the art in the Iello version). I've come to realize that Chudyk games aren't for me (except GtR) because of the high chaos factor and all of the info you need to keep tracking while playing.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Plays well with 2. - There are a lot of cards in this game which leads to an unbelievable amount of potential interactions between cards. - The Fission card: Wow; this went off in one of our games and it was crazy, it basically resets the game and destroys everything you have done. - However; I find the game a bit too random and swingy. - You don't always feel like it was your skill that caused you to win; instead you got lucky with a few card draws. - I also found that the game usually ends way before you get to the higher ages (8 - 10) which means you very rarely see very many of those cards.[/i]
item.conditiontext:
Excellent condition, this was only played a few times (most of my plays were the Iello version).
Trade interest: High

item.name: The Institute for Magical Arts
item.comment:
Another game Mat taught me, he thought I would enjoy it and he was right. I really enjoyed the area control aspect of the game that comes into play when you are trying to get cards from the center row. I also appreciated how dice were used in this game, basically the numbers on the dice tell you which cards you can try to gain control of by placing influence discs or you could take that many influence discs from the supply. You also have re-roll tokens that you can get back, but at the cost of points.
[i]This is a great 2p game that I would be happy to own, but I have so many new 2p games that I am holding off for a while. I would be happy to play it again.[/i]
item.wishlistcomment: Enjoyed my play, hated the discs used in the game. [i](Silly complaint to some, but the component quality/aesthetics of a lot of Dr. Finn's games is lacking in my book)[/i].

item.name: La Isla
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]La Isla[/COLOR] was sold via auction 11/5/15.
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Great family game with an awesome theme and a quick playtime. - Plays great with 2 [i](we had quite a bit of interaction in our game)[/i]. - Interesting blend of mechanics that really work well as a whole. - Art and components, specifically the artwork for the animals really stands out and the plastic scientists are a nice touch. - Tough decisions when choosing cards since the can be used for multiple purposes. - Combo building a nice set of powers to use during your turn, but because you can only have 3 powers active at once you constantly have to retool your strategy.[/i]

item.name: Istanbul
item.comment: I was very excited to get to play this game and I was not disappointed. I had a blast trying to optimize my movement in order to eventually collect rubies. I really like the twist put on the pick up and deliver mechanic (you have helper tokens stacked under you that get dropped off and picked up from spaces as you move around the board). I think having a variable set up for this game will definitely increase the replay value of this title. The production quality is high, and it has nice artwork. I also think this could be an excellent advanced family game.

item.name: Jaipur
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Jaipur[/COLOR] was traded away for Akrotiri 12/15/14.
My thoughts:
- Quick 2p game that is easy to teach, making it a great gateway game. - One my whole family can play and enjoy, my daughter was 6 when she started playing this one. - Great cafe game, very small footprint on a table. - The camel cards; I really enjoy playing set collection games that introduce some kind of new element to uncover. The camels really take this game from mediocre to good because there is always a risk when choosing camels, but they will give you a lot of flexibility during future turns.
[i]I still think this is a good game, but was traded because it fell victim to the Jones Theory in favor of [thing=122298][/thing].[/i]

item.name: Jamaica
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Jamaica[/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 4/14/14. (Received Stronghold) Received in a math trade 3/12/14.
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]4[/COLOR]):
[i]Wow, what a bummer this game was, I really don't get the hype that surrounded this game. Note to self... don't believe the hype surrounding OOP games! (I find it quite interesting that now that the game has been reprinted all the hype has dissipated and I don't hear anyone talking about this game). My family and I were bored playing this game, the decisions are very basic and straight forward.
While this should be a great gateway game, it plays way to long for the amount of depth it has and is not a game I want to play again.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (7):
[i]First I need to mention that the production quality is top notch with great artwork. We all had fun playing, but I have to admit that due to all the hype surrounding it I was a bit underwhelmed. I can't put my finger on it maybe I was just expecting more from the game. It is a very simple game to play and teach and there are decisions to be made, but they do not require deep thought.[/i]

item.name: Jambo
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Jambo[/COLOR] was sold via auction and I gave a copy away.
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]8[/COLOR]):
[i]Since we have limited space for games, I gave this to a friend because I knew it would see limited play with all the other 2p games we have. I prefer playing Arboretum, Battle Line, Morels or Musee with my wife.
I am still considering picking up a copy of Asante (which streamlined a few rules, especially no longer having to pay gold to use the sixth space in your market stall).[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (9):
- My wife enjoys it, we have already played 5 times since receiving it in a trade. - I love the combination of set collection and buying/selling goods to make a profit. - The different cards really add a lot of depth to what essentially is a set collection game.
I am always on the lookout for a quick playing game to play with my wife, and Jambo has been a hit. This also is a great game to play with older kids (8+ give or take). It is too bad that this game is now OOP, but Asante seems to be the spiritual successor to Jambo. In fact you can combine the Asante cards with the Jambo cards.
item.conditiontext:
New in shrink.
Trade interest: High

item.name: Kahuna
item.comment:
Initial thoughts and rating (6):
[i]I knew going in that this would be a long shot, but I didn't have to break the bank to get a copy so I decided to take a flyer on it hoping it would be a good 2p area control game. Unfortunately it wasn't my cup of tea, I should've listened to Marc (hawk-x-).
I didn't maind the interaction (El Grande is a favorite of mine) what I couldn't handle was the non existent theme pasted over an Abstract game. In my opinion it didn't feel like an area control game at all. Still I'm not sorry that I tried Kahuna, if nothing else it made me realize that looking for a 2p area control game is a fools errand. Area control games require more than 2 players to achieve the type of interaction I look for when playing this type of game.[/i]

item.name: Kemet
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Kemet[/COLOR] was traded away for Suoer Motherload 6/2/15.
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]8[/COLOR]):
[i]I traded this game because it is such a bear to set up and teach, but I would play it anytime. I still think it is a great game, just not a great fit in our small collection. I've completely changed my mind and would rather set up and play Nexus Ops if I want a quick skirmish game and Memoir when we're looking for a longer game. Also if I had one negative I would say that the tiles are a red herring, you really can't get more than a few because you need to be grabbing points and someone else will run away with the game (just ask my son : )[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (9):
[i]- Beautiful production quality, especially the minis. - Love the action selection board where you can only select certain actions once or maybe twice each turn. - Turns are quick, this game moves along at a brisk pace. - The pyramids/power tiles in the game add a lot of replay value to the game. - Creatures have diverse powers and add a lot variety to the battles. - Divine intervention cards add a layer of unpredictability to the game especially during battles. - There is no player elimination, you win by having x number of victory points. - Kemet discourages players from turtling, the majority of victory points are earned by being the attacker in battles. - Great combat resolution mechanic with the card system.[/i]

item.name: King of Tokyo
item.comment:
Sold via auction 6/15/15 Easter gift 2013 (Family)
[i]- Great, thematic art and some of the most amazing dice we have. - This game is just fun, you can't help but smile and laugh when you play this. - Great gateway game that we have had great success introducing other families to. - Might be the easiest game to teach that I own... Roll claws! - The cards add some fun twists to the game and are worth collecting energy for. That said, I only roll for claws and very rarely leave Tokyo.[/i]
[i]Favorite KoT moment: winning the [thing=144606][/thing] at a Tabletop Day event at the Adams Memorial Library for my daughter. She was so excited and this will be a cool keepsake reminding her of our day spent gaming together![/i]

item.name: King of Tokyo: Power Up!
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]King of Tokyo: Power Up![/COLOR] was sold via marketplace 3/27/15.
My thoughts:
[i]We no longer use any of the power up cards, they just add unnecessary length/decisions to the game. KoT excels as a quick, accessible game and this expansion takes away from that. The only thing we use is the giant panda.
After playing over 10 games with the expansion I am lowering my score from 9 to a 4. Why? Even though the individual monster powers seem cool,they add something else to keep track of without actually being really beneficial.[/i]
item.conditiontext: Excellent condition. *Please note - This comes with everything but the Panda figure. All the power up cards and tokens will be shipped in the expansion box.

item.name: Kingdom Builder
item.comment:
My son and I had fun playing this and I think it would be a good family game to own. But, since we have gotten so many new games I am going to hold off on getting this one. I would like to play it with my wife and daughter before buying it to see how much they would like it.
[i]Update: With so many games available to play, I have very little desire to play this again.[/i]

item.name: Kingdoms
item.comment: Another Knizia scratched off the list. Mat picked this one up and taught me. Luckily this game is played over three rounds because the first round fell flat for me. During the next 2 rounds things began to click and I started to see the different timing/strategy of when to lay castles vs. picking up tiles. This is a very abstract game (shocking I know), but I enjoyed it.

item.name: Kingsburg
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Kingsburg[/COLOR] was traded away for Alhambra Anniversary Edition 3/11/14.
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR])
[i]The one big negative I have for is that the game is usually is decided by the end of the 4th year. This is compounded by the fact that the scoring is all open, there is no hidden scoring like all of the civilization cards in Stone Age. This lead to me trading the game away.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Love how the dice are used as your workers, this adds some great tension to the game. - I also like all the different ways you can choose to build buildings, there are lots of ways to combine powers from different buildings. - Good family game, however I believe Lords of Waterdeep and Stone Age are better introductions to worker placement.[/i]

item.name: Kingsburg: To Forge a Realm
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Kingsburg: To Forge a Realm[/COLOR] was traded away for Alhambra Anniversary Edition 3/11/14.
My thoughts and rating (8)
[i]- I love parts of the expansion, and would definitely recommend picking it up even if you only use some of the included modules. - We always play with the expanded building boardsand the alternate building rows. These 2 modules really add a lot of variety to the game and in my opinion are must haves. - We played a lot with the soldier tokens, but I did not like how deterministic battles have become. I prefer the uncertainty of the reinforcements die. - Sometimes we used the special adviser cards, but I have found that they can really unbalance the game if one person gets a really powerful ability. We have pretty much stopped using them. - I do not like the random event cards that you would play once a year, they seem very arbitrary to me.[/i]

item.name: Las Vegas
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Las Vegas[/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 1/5/15. (Received Yardmaster KS edition)
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
[i]I ended up acquiring both the base game and expansion, but ended up trading it away after playing a few games with my family. It was not the hit I thought it would be and I have a lot of other dice games I would much rather play. I also found that the game dragged after a while, this is not a game I need to play again (I think Qwixx is a much better family/gateway dice game).[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8)
[i]A very light game I could see playing with my extended family. I really want to find a dice filler to play with my them, but I am not convinced this is the one. I have enjoyed my plays of it though.[/i]
item.conditiontext: Excellent condition, only played a few times.

item.name: Las Vegas Boulevard
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Las Vegas Boulevard[/COLOR] was traded away with Great Heartland Hauling Company, Sushi Go and Thunder Alley for Fleet/Fleet Arctic Bounty (with all KS rewards), Friday and Viva Java the Dice Game 12/29/14.
My thoughts:
[i]The expansion really adds to this game and is the reason why I added it to our collection. My two favorite modules are the large dice (which count as 2) and the purple kicker dice.
In the end it wasn't enough to keep Las Vegas in our collection so it got traded with the base game. I'd definitely recommend it if you like the base game however.[/i]
item.conditiontext: Excellent condition, only played a few times.

item.name: Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Marvel Legendary[/COLOR] was sold via auction 8/2/14.
My thoughts and rating change [COLOR=#FF0000]9 -> 4[/COLOR]:
[i]This was another game we got early on and as such received a lot of plays. Since that time we have come to realize that we just don't care for most deck building games. It is just a mechanic I do not enjoy.
Love the theme, but I found the game play unsatisfying especially when yo would save up to by a rare superhero and then be lucky to actually get to play that card once. I found that in almost all of our plays that most of the game you were playing with mostly commons and a few uncommon cards from the superhero decks. Also set up and tear down is a bear. I did really like the different scenarios that you played each game, that added a good amount of replay to the game.
In the end it is an okay game that I do not need to own nor play again.[/i]
item.conditiontext:
Good to very good condition. I have played this game 20+ times and the cards are not sleeved, so the cards show some normal wear.
Trade interest: High

item.name: Legendary: Dark City
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Marvel Legendary: Dark City[/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 5/20/14. (Received RFtG, a second copy)
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]4[/COLOR]):
[i]I still stand by my original thoughts on this expansion, I think it greatly improves the base game of Legendary. However; almost every deck builder we have tried has fallen flat with us and Legendary is no exception. I found the set up/clean up took too much time and was very fiddly. This is not a game I want to put 60 to 90 minutes into. Still looking for the comic book game that we will enjoy.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]Played our first game with the expansion, most fun I have had playing Legendary. The game is harder and more intense, but not because everyone has a high attack value. Instead there are all kinds of new effects/powers that create a more challenging game. The new scheme twists are also very good, with lots of unique set-ups.[/i]

item.name: Legendary: Fantastic Four
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Marvel Legendary: Fantastic 4[/COLOR] was traded away with a copy of Cockroach Poker and Haggis for Zooloretto.
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]4[/COLOR]):
[i]By now my feelings on most deck builders have been well documented. While this expansion added some interesting new powers, I had enough plays of Legendary already under my belt (20+) and this game was soon traded away.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]This is another solid expansion to a fun deck builder. I really like some of the new abilities found in this set with villains, masterminds and the hero powers (specifically Focus). Card art is hit or miss depending on the cards, personally I did not mind the art in the base game as I found it to be overall of a higher quality.[/i]

item.name: Lewis & Clark
item.comment: I have only played this once and initially my thoughts on the game were higher. Now that I look back on the experience I am not sure how often I would want to play this game. I love race games with card play [i](RFtG is a top 5 game for me)[/i], but I want a clean streamlined experience. I felt like L & C was made up of a lot of starts and fits. The worker placement element is not nearly as elegant as the rest of the game. It is extremely inefficient to use those spaces to get goods [i](I am specifically referring to canoes and horses)[/i], I don't understand why I can only buy one canoe or horse each turn but it basically kills those spaces. I had bought cards that let me maximize canoes, but then I had to take multiple actions to get multiple canoes. You really need to focus on the cards you get to help you become more efficient with your actions and ignore the allure of the board spaces; then my question becomes why bother including all of the wp elements in this game, it just slows the play way down.

item.name: Libertalia
item.comment:
I had been looking forward to playing this for years and finally got my chance and wow was I disappointed. We played with 6 players and there were a lot of turns when 3 or 4 of us played the same cards. Then player order is decided by a number on your card... awful mechanic since this happened quite often and made the game feel much more luck based than it seems at first glance. The set collection was okay, but even then there really wasn't much tension and choice.
