I really enjoy role selection games, but I will stick with [i][thing=131357][/thing][/i] where there are very limited roles, but the bluffing mechanic really fleshes out the game play. Libertalia felt extremely dry and mechanical, the theme fell completely flat with me.

item.name: Linko!
item.comment:
Sold via auction 6/15/15, reacquired 11/14/15.
[i]This was another fun trick taker Mat introduced me to. Currently I am comparing these games to [thing=56692][/thing] which has been getting a lot of play with my dad and son.
Linko doesn't surpass Parade for me so I am not sure that I would add it to my collection [i](Especially since I think [thing=152162][/thing] is going to hit that sweet spot for me)[/i]. However I would play it anytime, I really enjoy trick taking card games and this is a good one.[/i]

item.name: London
item.comment:
Not sure where I stand with this one. I enjoyed my play, but it ran a little long and I didn't have any prior knowledge of the cards so players with previous plays have a distinct advantage. In some ways it feels like an optimization game in the vein of Rosenberg's games with a much different thematic feel.
I feel like I would need further plays to really give a proper opinion of this game. I would play it again, but it wouldn't be my first pick since I didn't love the mechanics of the game [i](it also went long, but I am assuming further plays would shorten the game length)[/i].

item.name: Loopin' Louie
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Loopin' Louie[/COLOR] was given away.
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
[i]Even my youngest daughter (now 5) would rather play any of our other children's games (The Magic Labyrinth, The Enchanted Tower, Russelbande, Spooky Stairs and Animal Upon Animal) so I ended up giving it away.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8)
[i]We got this game to play with our youngest daughter Lilly (she is 3) and I am happy we did. Our kids all have fun playing this, and Lilly loves it, she is very proud to have her own game. She is very protective of her white chickens! This is a very fun dexterity game with great bits and it is very sturdy. Great family game, highly recommended![/i]

item.name: Loot
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Loot[/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 8/8/14. (With Love Letter and Cheaty Mages for Pyramix)
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]4[/COLOR]):
[i]Another okay game that we got when we did not have many games. Part of it may be the meta game that my family has developed, where everyone stockpiles cards before trying to sneak some ships by. This game is very light and really shows it's age when compared to other card games, definitely not a game I need to play again.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (6):
[i]This is a very basic trick taking game, with a few cards that have special powers. This game plays quick, so we play before bedtime or as a filler during our family game night. This game is a great intro into trick taking games for kids due to the ease of game play and great theme.
This game plays well at 3 or 4 players, I would not recommend it for 2 players. This is my least favorite card game that we own; I would always rather play Morels, Jaipur or Guillotine (when we have more than 2 players). I would only recommend this game to play with younger kids as an intro into trick taking games.[/i]

item.name: Lord of the Rings: The Confrontation (Deluxe Edition)
item.comment: Traded away in a math trade 5/20/14. (Received The DC Deckbuilding Game)
item.wishlistcomment: Would like to get the version I had (the 2005 FF Deluxe Edition)

item.name: Lords of Vegas
item.comment: [i]- Great family game, I believe this is the replacement game for Monopoly (at least for my family). - You only score if your casino card gets flipped the beginning of each turn. This really helps in a family setting because you can have a huge 9 point green casino, but the green cards don't get flipped (this happened to me); meanwhile someone else who has a smaller 6 point purple casino keeps scoring it because purple cards get flipped. - You know how many of each casino color has been flipped, this becomes important knowledge as you build casinos. However; it is not perfect knowledge because you do not see about a fifth of the cards each game. - Trading and negotiation: In this game it is necessary because at the beginning of your turn you get ownership of a random lot. This may be a lot you want, but more than likely it is going to be another player who really wants it. Therefore in order to get lots near each other to build on you will most likely spend lots of time wheeling and dealing. - There are ways you can really mess some one over and get ownership of a casino when you only own one of the tiles in that casino. - The point track: at first you go up one point at a time, but then later in the game you need to have a casino that will score 2, 3, 4... in order to advance on the score track.[/i]

item.name: Lords of Waterdeep
item.comment:
[i]Worker placement games have always been a hit in our house. I was initially turned off of this game, in part because I figured it couldn't live up to the hype. I finally got the game and have not regretted it at all.
- My wife loves this game, which is always a huge + for me. - The DnDeeples are amazing an really increase our enjoyment of the game. - I love the artwork on the board/cards. Really well drawn fantasy art, everything is easy to read and understand. - Family friendly design; my wife and older kids found it easy to learn played really well from the beginning. This is a very easy game to teach, the only area my daughter needed some coaching with was helping her figure out how important playing Intrigue cards could be. - Turns go by very fast, there is not much AP in this game. - Intrigue Cards: These make the game for us, they introduce a lot of direct player interaction.[/i]

item.name: Lords of Waterdeep: Scoundrels of Skullport
item.comment: My son was chomping at the bit to play this and I am glad we did because it is now off my wishlist. I really enjoyed it, but my son did not (even though he won) which really surprised me. He actually preferred the simplicity of the base game and did not like the skulls. He thought too much of the game was spent managing your skulls and not completing quests. I do not think my wife or daughter would enjoy the increased complexity of the expansion either. I am fine just playing the base game with family and I would recommend getting the Lords of Waterdeep: Character Meeples instead of the expansion if you are going to play LoW with your family.

item.name: Lords of Xidit
item.comment:
The scoring mechanic feels like an inelegant Knizia solution to scoring. For example in Tigris your score is the lowest total among all four colors; simple and brilliant [i](in my opinion)[/i]. This is something you have direct control over and can plan for. In Xidit you score three different resources (fame, gold and buildings), but in the beginning of the game you randomly decide an order that they are placed in [i](first, second, third)[/i]. Then the person with the lowest total of the first resource is eliminated from the game. You score the second resource and again the person with the lowest total is eliminated. Finally the winner is determined by having the most of the third resource. The problem is that there are situations where you know you need a certain resource, but you just can't get it. I understand that this scoring system adds tension to the game, but at the cost of simplicity and elegance. Why not adopt the scoring system found in Tigris, your score is the resource you have the least of.
Overall I really had fun playing the game, and I especially enjoyed having to plan out 6 moves at a time and then see how things worked out based on other peoples actions. In the end though, after playing a game for a few hours it really feels crappy getting eliminated from any possibility of winning because of a convoluted and wonky scoring system.

item.name: Lost Cities
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Lost Cities[/COLOR] was sold via auction 1/1/15. Received in a math trade (8/8/14).
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
[i]I can appreciate the importance of Lost Cities when looking at all the card games that have been influenced by it's design. However I would much rather play Knizia's Battle Line, which I think is brilliant in its execution.
If I am looking for a game that is in the same lineage as Lost Cities I'd choose Musée. Musee offers everything Lost Cities minus the wonky scoringand introduces a spacial aspect to the card play which adds more depth to the game but not complexity.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- A great cafe game, small footprint (you don't need the board if you don't have room). - Very easy to play/teach, but Mr. Knizia found a way to make it engaging. - I like being able to change the tempo of the game based on whether you deplete the deck of cards or take a card from one of the piles of face up cards. - The push your luck element: do you try to wait for one more handshake or do you start that third or even fourth expedition? - While the scoring system seems wonky at first it makes the game.
I prefer Knizia's Battle Line over this, but both will stay in my collection.[/i]
item.conditiontext: Very good condition, cards are not sleeved and may show some minor wear [i]nothing that effects game play.[/i]

item.name: Lost Legacy: Flying Garden
item.comment: [i]I really did not enjoy this game; on top of that I am not sure how many micro bluffing games we need. I still prefer the simplicity of Love Letter and personally do not see the need to keep reinventing that game. I am also not a fan of the art at all; this is not a game I feel any need to play again.[/i]

item.name: Love Letter
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Love Letter[/COLOR] was sent with KoT stuff 3/27/15.
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
[i]Cockroach Poker killed this game for me and my family. While an okay micro game, it doesn't offer any of the banter and humor of a game like Cockroach Poker so it quickly fell out of favor in our house.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Great cafe/restaurant game, 16 cards and some cubes. - Each round plays very quick, a whole game takes less than 15 minutes. - Great family game that introduces bluffing.[/i]
item.conditiontext: Condition: Excellent, cards have always been sleeved. [i]Comes in the red velvet pouch and I also upgraded the components to the heart shaped wooden tokens.[/i]

item.name: Luna
item.comment:
One of my favorite Feld's I've played [i](up there with [thing=25554][/thing] and [thing=35488][/thing])[/i]. Obviously I am drawn to his non-point salad games.
Highlights: - Theme and components really felt like they were connected to the game play. - Played great with 2, and only took about an hour. - Loved the combination of worker placement and area control. - All of your actions felt like they were working towards a common goal, this is not a point salad game. - Love working towards those bonus tiles, they really allow you to make some headway during the game. - Once this game is set up it looks great, excellent production values. - The candle/turn end mechanic... Amazing.
Really this video says it all [geekurl=/video/31340/luna/lunas-blues]Luna's Blues[/geekurl]
[i]I really hope this game sees a reprint, I could see playing this game with my family. For now it sits on my wishlist, but I don;t have high hopes for finding a copy.[/i]

item.name: Machi Koro
item.comment:
Wow, I really dislike this game. Yes it is supposed to be a light filler but there is too much downtime between turns. Maybe it was the people I played with, but this game dragged. It is also extremely luck dependent and while I don't mind that in a quick filler like Qwixx, Machi Koro is long and in my opinion quite boring.
[i]This is another game that rode the hype train into town and I just don't get it.[/i]

item.name: Madame Ching
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Madame Ching[/COLOR] was traded with Akrotiri for Memoir 44. Christmas gift from Mat 2014.
Initial thoughts and rating (6):
[i]- Beautiful artwork and high production values. I especially like the art on the movement cards. - Ship movement; to me this is the most interesting part of the game. - Hand management, planning how to play your cards to get your ship to where you want to go. - The added set collection mechanic add some needed depth to the game, by offering a secondary goal when playing movement cards.
Overall I am somewhat underwhelmed by this game. It has such a beautiful aesthetic but the game play is quite repetitive. Some of the encounter cards can really swing a game and that doesn't feel fulfilling to me. Especially when the movement part of the game is so precise and requires careful planning. In the end I don't feel like the game rewards careful planning. Also your decisions are usually quite obvious, even for a family game.[/i]

item.name: Made for Trade
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Made for Trade[/COLOR] was thrown out!
[i]:gulp: Wow, the definition of a random roll and move game with a supposed historical theme and educational value. My son told me I needed to rate this game a 1![/i]

item.name: The Magic Labyrinth
item.comment:
[i]- Beautiful production - A great game for young kids that can be enjoyed by the whole family - Everyone in my family enjoys this game, it is not just for little kids.
Someone had mentioned keeping the little rectangular cut outs from punching out the game in order to place them on the board once you find out where walls are. This definitely helped my little girl play this game and really enjoy it.[/i]

item.name: Marrying Mr. Darcy
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Marrying Mr. Darcy[/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 11/10/14. (Received Biblios)
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]4[/COLOR]):
[i]I don't have much else to say about this "game". We played it again and there really aren't any choices to be made. You flip a card and do what it says. Yes you can play a card from your hand, but there really isn't much choice to it. Do you have a certain personality trait, if so you play it and that's it. Who you end up marrying comes down to the roll of a die.
My wife is a huge Jane Austin fan and she thought the theme was good, but agreed after a few plays that there wasn't anything left to explore.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (5):
[i]I bought this game because my wife is a huge fan of the show. I am not sure what to say about this one, it is not bad but it also isn't much of a game. You basically play cards and read the text which definitely brings out the theme of the game. However; the game is very straightforward you literally play a card, do what it says and then usually draw another card. The end of the game (the marriage proposal) comes down to a die roll.
Enough said, if you or someone close o you is a fan of the show it may be worth picking up for a few plays.[/i]

item.name: Mars Needs Mechanics
item.comment: [i]This is the very definition of a mediocre game. It functions fine as a stock/commidity speculation game, but not only doesn't it bring anything new to the table it is also extremely dry. The art is a huge miss and fails to bring out the steam punk theme (it looks like free clip art). We did only play with 2 and completely lacked any tension, it was too easy to manipulate the board. I do think it would improve with more players but at that point I'd rather get enough people together to play Medici. I would play this again with more players, but I certainly wouldn't seek it out.[/i]

item.name: Marvel Dice Masters: Avengers vs. X-Men
item.comment: I enjoyed the game play, but I am not sure I want to get into the collectible nature of this game. Even though I love superheroes I am looking forward to the D&D version of the game. I think I will be less compelled to try to spend lots of money on boosters since I won't feel the need to collect all of my favorite superheroes.

item.name: Medici
item.comment: Highlights: - A really fun auction game with extremely simple rules and difficult decisions. Your success in this game comes down to how well you bid/manage your money. - Tension: this game is packed with it, I really can't believe how much fun this game is. You really have to play it; Medici is not as dry as it seems. There is plenty of take that and jockeying for position throughout the game. - I love any game where you are constantly reading people and past behaviors influence the decisions you make. - Coming from behind to win was awesome (which is not something that happens to me often).

item.name: Medieval Academy
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Medieval Academy[/COLOR] was sold via auction 11/5/15.
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
[i]Ultimately a bit disappointing, I was hoping for a bit more depth. There was not a lot of tension in the decisions you have to make. We'd still rather continue to play 7 Wonders in my house.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Quick drafting game (plays in a 1/2 hour). - Great gateway into drafting games, much better than Sushi Go (and in my opinion almost as easy to teach). - Best "new to me" drafting mechanic: as you draft cards you do not reveal them right away, instead starting with the first player each person plays one card and advances on the chosen track. This adds a fun card play and possible bluffing element to the game play. - The "advanced" side of the jousting knights adds a fun tug of war element to the game. - A variety of boards that all score a bit differently (although all but 1 provide either + or - vp's).[/i]

item.name: Medina (second edition)
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Medina[/COLOR] was traded in a math trade with Asara, Ninjato and Pyramix 2/1/15. (Received The Golden Ages)
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Beautiful wooden components, the game looks more and more amazing as you continue to play. - Simple rules, place two wooden pieces... that's it. - The score sheet helps remind you to score each separate piece/section. - Great family game.[/i]
[i]Traded because I couldn't see this hitting the table often (if at all).[/i]

item.name: Memoir '44
item.comment:
Traded away in a math trade 4/14/14. (Received Castles of Burgundy) Reaquired
[i]This was the second designer board game added to our collection. I figured my son would love the cool army minis, and he did.
- Excellent intro into light war gaming, and one that my kids can play. - Due to the dice based combat, which is very intuitive, there is enough luck in this game that the game remains very accessible. - This was one of the best gateway games that I introduced to friends that had formally played Risk, etc. They were instantly hooked. - Card play: I am in the camp that enjoy the tension created by never knowing if you are going to have enough movement cards to activate one of your zones enough times to pull of your plan. - A lot of scenarios, which all have a different terrain layout, found in the base game alone which gives this game high replay value.[/i]

item.name: Memoir '44: Eastern Front
item.comment: [i]The best part of the expansion is the limitations on choosing cards when playing the Soviets, great way to tie the theme to the game play.[/i]

item.name: Memoir '44: Mediterranean Theater
item.comment:
[i]A great addition to a game my son and I love playing. His favorite part of the game are the tank battles and since this expansion covers the N. African campaign there are lots of tanks! I would recommend splurging on the map, it definitely enhances how the game looks once it's all set up.
There are plenty of scenarios and some interesting new rules for the British troops, but I would recommend this expansion based solely on the awesome armor warfare![/i]

item.name: Memoir '44: Terrain Pack
item.comment: [i]Adds more terrain and scenarios to the game which is always a good thing.[/i]

item.name: Memoir '44: Winter/Desert Board Map
item.comment: [i]Definitely makes the set up look much better when playing the desert/snow scenarios.[/i]

item.name: Merchant of Venus (second edition)
item.comment: [i]- The sci-fi theme and the pick up and deliver mechanic found in this game. - Having to explore before you can really start selling goods because you are trying to find good trade routes to exploit. - Even though this is a roll and move it actually has some thoughtful choices you need to make when navigating. - The artifacts introduce some nice perks that may be found throughout the game. - For a game with so much depth, it is relatively easy to teach once you have the rules down yourself. - Plays great with 2.[/i]

item.name: Merkator
item.comment:
I am a huge Uwe fan, so I was quite excited to try out his take on a pick up and deliver game.
Highlights: - Plays relatively quick, I could see a 2 player game wrapping up in less than an hour with 2 experienced players. - The rules are quite straight forward and simple, the game really is all about optimizing your trade routes (which I love). - My son was able to pick this one up right away and do quite well. - The time track, basically the players determine how long the game will last depending on which cities they visit. - The ability to follow some one and get to fulfill a contract in that location. - You increase the value of your contract when you complete one (complete a 4 contract and earn a 5); however you can keep contracts and fulfill them multiple times. - Your contract is also currency, you are constantly having to choose between keeping valuable contracts or using them to by new bonus cards. - Bonus buildings give you alternative ways to score vp.
This is a pick up and deliver game that is all about optimization, there is no route building to be had. So I can see how this game is not for everyone, but I love it and it has moved way up my wishlist.
item.wishlistcomment: Really streamlined pick up and deliver game. Not sure if it would get played in my house though.

item.name: Mission: Red Planet
item.comment: I really enjoyed this game, it combined role selection (which I love) and area control. I will admit it can be a bit chaotic due to some of the character powers of the cards. I would definitely play this again and consider buying (since it is getting reprinted) because I could see playing this with my family.

item.name: Modern Art
item.comment:
This is a thematic Knizia game if I've ever played one, you actually feel like you are involved in an art auction due to all the conversation, negotiation and sales pitches that take place.
[i]This game will probably be bumped to a 10 if I can get in some more plays, which will all come down to the gaming group I belong to. I don't think that this would make a great family game because if one person's bids are out of whack it throws off the balance of the game.[/i]
item.wishlistcomment: [i]Favorite Knizia auction game, just not sure it would get played outside of when I'm gaming with a buddy who already has a copy.[/i]

item.name: Monster Fluxx
item.comment:
We've been in the hobby for about 3 years now and finally got to play a game of Fluxx. I happily played with a friend and his kids plus my son. I'll be honest I wasn't expecting much, but I was pleasantly surprised. I really liked the monster theme, there were a lot of references to things I grew up with (Scooby Doo and Count Chocula come to mind). We had fun playing and the game didn't overstay it's welcome.
[i]While it is not a game I would seek out, I would play it again with my kids. I also think it would be a great game for my kids to teach their friends.[/i]

item.name: Morels
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Morels[/COLOR]
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]10[/COLOR]):
[i]This was one of our first games and my wife and kids still love playing this game a 3 years later. (Even after my wife spilled coffee on the cards.) I had the opportunity to play the new Fungi version and while I like the new artwork, I still prefer the original version's artwork. This is still one of my favorite 2p card games and one I highly recommend.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8.5)
[i]This is one of my wife's favorite games and it is probably my favorite 2p card game to play with her. I was also lucky enough to get the actual frying pans and wooden sticks, they look awesome.
- Excellent cafe game, this game has a small footprint. - Great theme and beautiful artwork; I especially appreciate the different art found on the night time cards. - May be the best had management game I own, the limit on hand size combined with that fact that you can not just discard cards creates a nice amount of tension in the game. - Brent (the designer) is extremely helpful and supports the people that play his game. I have had two separate issues and he has generously sent me replacement cards![/i]

item.name: Musée
item.comment: [i]- Love the aesthetic of the game, really nice over sized cards, nice tiles with the chandeliers/staircases not to mention the great choice of artwork for the game. The graphic design is excellent as well. - The theme shines through, this game looks beautiful on the table especially once you finish your museum. - Has a similar feel to other classic 2p card games like Lost Cities and Battle Line [i](*Musee does play up to 4)[/i]. - Perfect combination between ease of learning and plenty of meaningful decisions to be made. - Excellent couples/family game, my wife really enjoys it.[/i]

item.name: My First Carcassonne
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]My First Carcassonne[/COLOR] was sold via auction 6/14/15
Updated thoughts and rating coming soon...
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Excellent kid's game (my daughter is 4) that is very easy to teach. - Awesome components; nice thick, over sized tiles with big, chunky meeples. - Fun, whimsical artwork that my daughter really liked.[/i]

item.name: Mythic Battles
item.comment: This was a learning game so I would play it agaian, but my initial impressions are somewhat meh. I know Mat will shudder when he reads this, but I think Summoner Wars does this type of cards/tokens dudes on a map game much better. I think these games offer similar game play mechanics and I much prefer the pace/play of Summoner Wars. I found Mythic Battles to be a bit fiddly, but I would play it again.

item.name: Nations: The Dice Game
item.comment: I had a chance to play this tonight and found it to be a rather mediocre experience. I'll echo everyone else, how can you not have different starting civ powers?!i can't imagine this game would have gotten any of the buzz it's had if it wasn't thematically tied to Nations, but really theme has been completely wasted. I also can't see this game standing up to repeated play, the decision space is too restricted. I am glad I got to play though because I love dice games and may have purchased it blind.

item.name: Nauticus
item.comment:
Another Kramer/Kiesling game that I got to play thanks to Mat. While not my favorite from these designers [i](that honor belongs to [thing=129948][/thing])[/i] I really enjoyed it.
Highlights: - Another innovative use of the wheel system found in a few of their other games [i]([thing=27173][/thing] and [thing=129948][/thing]).[/i] You never know how actions will line up in future rounds which changes the price for goods and amount of free dock workers you get. - Beautiful components, great art in the game [i](once you figure out how the sails stack the built ships look cool)[/i]. - There is a lot of future planning that needs to be done, but it is not overly complex. - Perfect balance of length and complexity, the game played in a little over an hour. - Building combos when you complete ships is fun since you can piggy back the rewards you get from completing multiple ships.
This is definitely a game I would love to play again, unfortunately for me I think it is a bit heavy to play with my wife. She loves Palaces, but Nauticus is definitely a step up in rules complexity. [i]This is on my wishlist, but not a priority since it wouldn't get much play at home.[/i]

item.name: New York 1901
item.comment:
[i]- This game has a great pace to it and ends at the right time (you still want to do more, but at the same time you feel like you accomplished something). - Variable end game goals (both street and bonus cards) add variety and can significantly alter how you play the game. - Features the amazing artwork of Vincent Dutrait (quickly becoming my favorite illustrator).
I was weary of the hype with 1901 and my recent track record of new acquisitions hasn't been too hot, but I saw it for a great price and decided to buy it. I've only had it for about 2 weeks, but so far I am quite impressed. NY 1901 seems like it may pull off what TTR has done, which is create a gateway style game that also appeals to folks like me that also enjoy heavier games.
Includes the Flatiron promo with the all the new cards.[/]

item.name: Nexus Ops
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Nexus Ops[/COLOR] was sold via marketplace 11/1/15.
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]8[/COLOR]):
[i]I actually regret selling this one; I actually forgot I had it listed in the marketplace and it sold months later... whoops. My original thoughts still stand and in the end I actually enjoyed it more than Kemet due to the simplicity of set up and teaching. I miss having a quick skirmish game in our collection, Memoir is great, but set up can be a bear.
I'm actually thinking of trying to get a copy of the old Avalon Hill version since I like the minis better and it has the awesome center tile.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8.5):
[i]- Great replacement for Risk. - Works really well as a 2p game. - No player elimination, person to garner x victory points wins. - The game encourages combat, that is how you get most of your VP. - Fast set-up and gameplay, about 45 minutes to an hour. - Beautiful minis for the units. - Energize cards add to the replayability, especially combat. - Alternate unit powers. - Dice based combat is handled simply but allows for interesting decisions concerning which units to have fight. - Set up of the board has some random elements which adds to the replay factor.[/i]

item.name: Ninjato
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Ninjato[/COLOR] was traded in a math trade with Asara, Ninjato and Pyramix 2/1/15. (Received The Golden Ages) Received in a trade (4/30/14).
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]8[/COLOR]):
[i]I enjoyed the plays we got in as a family, my favorite element of the game was the area control aspect that was brought into the WP genre. However; I never really enjoyed the combat aspect of the game, it never felt very satisfying. Also it was not a game that my kids enjoyed; V and I liked it but the 2p game feels very lackluster.
With so many WP games in our collection at the time Ninjato was another game that fell victim to the Jones Theory. Ninjato is still a game I would play, but I don't miss not having it in the collection.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Great theme, with beautiful production from the artwork to all the wooden shuriken. - This is a great family game. - This game is the perfect length, it plays in about an hour. Also the tension ratchets up after each scoring round (of which there are 3). - The theme ties in very well with the different actions you can take. - Ninjas, enough said.[/i]
item.conditiontext: Very good condition, my copy comes with 2 laminated player sheets that give a breakdown of the rules and list all of the dojo tile powers. All the components are bagged.

item.name: No Thanks!
item.comment:
Another classic I got to play and while I found it enjoyable I wasn't blown away. Although in all fairness I only played it once and would gladly play it again.
[i]Personally I would break out [thing=172][/thing] instead of this game as a quick filler/ intro into the hobby.[/i]

item.name: Notre Dame
item.comment: Thanks for teaching the game Jeremy and thanks for playing Chris. My son also played this game with us and did quite well. I really enjoyed playing this game, especially the card draft that began each round. I think it would work well as a family game, my older daughter could definitely grasp this game. It is too bad that it is currently out of print, but I will patiently wait for a reprint (I hope).

item.name: Odin's Ravens
item.comment:
[i]Wow, I'm glad I never acquired this game because it was a huge disappointment. The game was much lighter than I expected with very few meaningful choices. I really disliked the magic way deck which serves as a bolted on catch up mechanic (basically if you have the majority of those cards you get 3 points).
I also don't understand how this game is always mentioned with Balloon Cup as being two of the OOP Kosmos 2p games that you should own. Maybe time has not been kind to this design with all the new 2p games out there, but Balloon Cup has. Definitely not a game I want play again.[/i]

item.name: One Night Ultimate Werewolf
item.comment: Fun when played with a larger group. Definitely one I'd be interested in playing more, but I don't see it appealing to non-gamers [i](especially in my family)[/i] so I probably won't ever buy a copy. There are just too many gamerly elements found in the game. As I said I'd love to have a agroup to play with though.

item.name: Onirim (second edition)
item.comment:
[i]- Similar to Sylvion this game has great art, it's really evocative of a surreal, dream like place. - Very simple game play, but it plays so fast that it holds up well to repeated play. - 7 expansions, I've yet to play with any of them, but they seem to add a lot of variety and challenge to the game play. This game could keep you busy for a while. - Be aware that this game requires a lot of shuffling which is part of the reason Sylvion has seen more plays, plus I prefer the tower defense style game as opposed to the more standard card play of Onirim. - This has been a surprise hit with my older daughter (10), she's probably already played 30+ times.[/i]
0 expansions - 1/3 wins

item.name: Pacific Typhoon
item.comment: Highlights: - Can't believe how well the theme ties in with the game play, especially since this is basically a trick taking game. - The historical flavor text also has implications during the game since some cards can be eliminated if a specific card is played. - This game took a few rounds to understand, but once it clicks all the different rules make sense. - Having the ability to choose how your going to fight (air, land, sub each with their own values) really changes how a hand will be played, including who may ally with you. - Temporary alliances: this game is all about forming alliances in the hopes of getting a share in the spoils. Love games where alliances are constantly shifting since there will only be one winner.

item.name: Pagoda
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Pagoda[/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 2/7/15. (Received 10 Days in Africa)
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
[i]I really liked my initial plays of this game and I thought it was a beautifully produced game. However; after a few more plays it became apparent that you could really get behind the 8 ball in this game if you got poor card draws and couldn't complete floors to get the bonus abilities. I played too many games were one person got the cards to complete purple floors and therefore could have a bigger hand size; this lead to that person pulling further ahead because they had a better chance of getting the colors they needed.
In the end that sucked a lot of fun out of the game, because it left one player feeling like they didn't have a chance from the beginning. In the end Pagoda had some very interesting mechanisms, but we encountered a serious runaway leader problem.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Another great 2p game I can play with my wife. - Also a great game to play with your kids. - Beautiful components. The game looks amazing as you build and eventually complete building the pagodas. - Simple game play expanded upon by the special actions you can earn for finishing floors of a pagoda. - Special actions: this is were games are won or loss, the abilities aren't game breaking, but they let you do a little extra on your turn which helps you earn a few more points. - So far our games have mostly been close, thus the game remains tense as you play.[/i]
item.conditiontext: Excellent condition, only played a few times. All the components are bagged.

item.name: The Palaces of Carrara
item.comment:
6/15/15 - I was finally able to get an English copy to replace my German one!
[i]- Plays great with 2. - This is one of those perfect mid weight Euro's that plays in under an hour and can easily be enjoyed by my family. - I enjoy the tension created each turn by having to decide between building with the blocks you have or buying more bricks from the wheel. - You also have to balance scoring points versus earning more money (to buy bricks) when deciding which cities to build buildings in. - The end game is not static; you may (but you don't have to) declare the end of the game when you have meet certain scoring/building requirements. - The alternative scoring cards can dramatically change the flow of the game. Sometimes it is an absolute sprint to the finish because the end game triggers are easy to reach, while at other times you have more time to build a better engine. I love how no 2 games feel the same once you introduce those cards.[/i]

item.name: Panamax
item.comment:
[i]Ouch, my head still hurts from playing this game. I love some heavier games, but this one pushed the envelope for me. I found the game to be rather long (I played a 3p game and it took over 2 and 1/2 hours to finish), and really I don;t think there are that many interesting choices to make. You pretty much have to figure out how to most efficiently transport your goods to turn a profit.
The one thing I really liked was buying stock in your company and others, especially since you had to pay dividends out to your shareholders each round out of the company's profit. If you couldn't your company lost value and you didn;t get money (personal wealth is the determining factor in deciding who wins, not your company's money).[/i]

item.name: Pandemic
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Pandemic[/COLOR] was sold via auction (2013).
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
[i]Haven't played this in a few months and every time it gets brought up no one wants to play it. Just didn't connect with my family (most co-ops haven't).[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (7):
[i]So far I like the game, but I can't help feeling a little disappointed with this game. Probably because of all the hype surrounding the game. I also find the theme a bit bland. This is a game I always play it with my wife and kids. We have fun when we play, but it does not get suggested a lot.[/i]

item.name: Pandemic: The Cure
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Pandemic: The Cure[/COLOR] was sold via auction...
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Love the dice rolling, push your luck mechanic. - The roles you get all feel different and exciting to play especially since you get custom dice. - Plays great with 2, there is still plenty of tension in the game. - Quick set up and play time especially when compared to Pandemic.[/i]

item.name: Parade
item.comment:
Received in a math trade (4/14/14).
[i]- Beautiful artwork and high quality cards. - Really fun card game that has the simple rule set of a game like Spades, but there is lots of depth to be found once you begin playing. - Quick play time: 15 - 20 minutes. This is currently my favorite trick taking game.[/i]

item.name: Pastiche
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Pastiche[/COLOR] was traded away 12/8/14 (received Asara).
My thoughts:
[i]- Beautiful components (love the easels) with an awesome theme. - Tile laying to mix colors [i](although it is more limited than I thought it would be)[/i]. - Easy to teach/learn and definitely a game you could break out with more casual gamers.
All of that said I was disappointed with this game. There really aren't that many decisions to be made, basically you lay a tile, get paints, mix paints and fulfill commissions. For a game with so few decisions I felt like it really outstayed it's welcome, I played a 3p game and it went over an hour. This game held my interest for about half that time.
There is no tension in this game which may appeal to some if you are looking for a really casual experience where you can easily talk/chill and play a game with family and friends. However that niche is already filled by other games in my collection. In fact I would highly recommend [thing=147431][/thing] which has a great art theme, beautiful components, and some added depth but still offers a relaxing game experience.[/i]

item.name: Patchwork
item.comment: [i]- Excellent family game that sets up and plays quick, meaning it will hit the table a lot. - One of the most beautiful games I own, I love the patterns for the quilt pieces. - Buttons are both your score and income, which really makes this game extremely tense. - Time track, I love games that use this mechanic, part of your planning has to take into account how many turns in a row you may get or give to the other player.[/i]

item.name: Patronize
item.comment: [i]I enjoyed both plays of Patronize and would much rather play this over [thing=129622][/thing]. I liked the addition of the cubes you are collecting and the different "suits" of cards will trump a higner number when going for a scoring card. All that said, I am not interested in owning this game. The rule set is a bit clunky and I don't see this game holding up to a lot of plays which is my problem with a lot of card based micro games. I much prefer a quick dice game like [thing=131260][/thing] or [thing=117942][/thing]. And if I want to play a card game I would choose a game that has ties to traditional card games like [thing=152162][/thing] or [thing=56692][/thing].[/i]

item.name: Penny Press
item.comment:
[i]I really need to play this again to speak intelligently about it. I really enjoyed my first play, but man did it fly by. I think the one thing you need to wrap your mind around while playing is that there are not fixed scoring rounds (going to press), you choose independently of everyone else when to go to press.
That is the key to the game because you don't want to fall behind other players and potentially either lose out on going to press one time or having to go to press before you really set up your reporters.
I love the theme and art (nice job Asmadi) and the flavor text on all the cards is great as well. I am really looking forward to playing this game again![/i]

item.name: Pergamon
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Pergamon[/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 8/8/14. (Received Balloon Cup) Received in a math trade (5/15/14).
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
[i]This game had a short life in my house. In a nutshell it quickly fell victim to the Jones Theory in favor of Thebes: The Tomb Raiders (which we already owned). I had heard a lot of good things about Pergamon, and I definitely enjoyed the bidding process for gold/where you could dig, but after that the game offered very few difficult decisions. Building the exhibitions with the tiles was fun, but the whole museum aspect of the game fell flat for me.
In comparison I like how time track determines player order in Thebes: TTR and the fact that you never know what you are going to pull from a dig, even if you know what cards are in the pile. I also appreciate the different scoring opportunities in Thebes: TTR, where as in Pergamon you only score based on your museum position and a few bonuses along the way. Thebes:TTR also plays better with 2 and is quite portable making it a great cafe game.
At the end of the day Pergamon isn't a "bad" game, but in our small collection I only felt the need to keep one archaeology game and Thebes: The Tomb Raiders won by a land slide (the same was true for my kids which sealed the deal).[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- The push your luck mechanic when choosing how much money you try to get which is also tied to which level of dig site you can excavate from. - Putting together exhibitions is fun, as you try to put together all the different tiles you have excavated. - My kids enjoy it, especially my daughter.[/i]
item.conditiontext:
Excellent condition, only played a few times. All the components are bagged.
Trade interest: High

item.name: Perry Rhodan: The Cosmic League
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Perry Rhodan: The Cosmic League[/COLOR] was traded for the complete Battlestar Galactica DVD set (11/11/14). Received in a trade (7/12/14)
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
[i]An okay 2p pick up and deliver game that got lost in the shuffle when looking for a quick, 2p game. I got this to play with my son because he loves Merchant of Venus, but the gameplay felt samey and the die rolls could be a killer (and even though MoV has dice, you feel like you have more time to overcome a few bad rolls which is not the case in Perry). The card play definitely added some variety to the game play, but not enough to draw us back in for repeated plays. We're still looking for the quick pick up and deliver experience that has a small footprint (We've played Great Heartland and we weren't fans).[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (7):
[i]- Designed for 2 players. - Pick up and deliver in under 30 minutes: When we don't have time for a game of Merchants of Venus we can pull this out. - Theme/aesthetics: both my son and I enjoy the sci-fi/space artwork in the game.
I need to play it more to give it a solid rating, it could easily go up or down.[/i]

item.name: Pickomino
item.comment:
Another fun dice filler, this one designed by Reiner Knizia [i](a designer I really admire).[/i] I only got one play in and honestly don't know how I feel about it yet. I had fun playing, but it was at the end of the night so hopefully I can get some more plays in and report back in a year... I also need to mention that the tiles in the game are amazing [i](similar to nice dominoes)[/i], I just wish the new reprint came with better dice [i](they're still light, wooden dice)[/i] but it's not a reason to avoid the game.
[i]I have gotten so many dice games lately that I am holding off on acquiring this one until I play it more and weed out some of the other one's from my collection.[/i]

item.name: The Pillars of the Earth: Builders Duel
item.comment:
I will never play this game again, what a horrible experience. I only played once, but my buddy told me the same thing happened when he played which is the rich get richer while you wallow in the dregs unable to accomplish anything. There is a huge advantage to going first and it is not always possible to get first player depending on how your opponent puts out their seals. Add to that some of the take that cards where you can basically stop someone from having any actions that whole round, no thanks.
[i]This might be the worst game I've ever played![/i]

item.name: Pirate Fluxx
item.comment: [i]Feel the same about this as Monster Fluxx, fun to play with my kids and this was the version my son picked up.[/i]

item.name: Plucky Pilots
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Plucky Pilots[/COLOR] was sold via auction 6/15/15
My thoughts:
[i]Wow, what a let down. I got this game to play with my youngest daughter (she's 5) and it bombed. I had read Joe in Colorado's thoughts a while back and he wasn't kidding, there really aren't any decisions to be made in this game. It is really just roll dice and see what happens. Basically you end up inching your way up the point track because you are continually busting. The way the arrows are laid out you will never use blue (except to get to the last space) and a few spaces in you need one color to advance and by that point you've had to spend a die as gas. I understand it is a push your luck game, but it just ends up feeling very random and seems like it could have benefited from more play testing.[/i]
item.wishlistcomment: Think it would be a hit with Lilly, love the dice.

item.name: Port Royal
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Port Royal[/COLOR] was sold via BGG marketplace. (10/15/14) Received in a math trade. (9/14/14)
My thoughts:
[i]I traded for this game because I was looking for a light/quick push your luck game and I really liked the art. In a nut shell this game drags on and is quite boring (just ask my kids). You constantly flip cards only to draw two ships of the same color with a high attack value, thus ending your turn. Other times you flip over 10+ cards only to get nothing you need/can get because you don't have enough money. On top of that it is a bit gamery and not suitable to play with family and friends that are not familiar with a lot of games.
I would recommend Incan Gold/Doiamant, which is a quick playing push your luck game that your whole family can enjoy, instead of Port Royal.[/i]

item.name: Potato Man
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Potato Man[/COLOR] was sold via auction 4/20/15.
Updated thoughts and rating coming soon...
[i]Although I need to mention that I want to play this again because I may not have played enough to really see the strategy of the game develop.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (6):
[i]This game fell flat for me, the decision space is not very interesting since there are too many instances when your choice is very limited and therefore quite apparent. There is some thought that goes into watching what other people play because the round immediately ends when someone can't play a card on a trick (I've experienced rounds where 2 tricks were played and then ended, not very satisfying).
I know that there is probably a bit more strategy to be uncovered with more plays, but your decisions will still be quite limited too often becuase of the structure of the game [i](way to many times when you have to play a color with no hope of winning the trick)[/i].
[i]I am not willing to put any more plays into a quick trick taking game that doesn't click right away since there are so many others to choose from [i](I much preferred the still very light, but much more fun [thing=151835][/thing] this month)[/i]. [/i]
item.conditiontext: Condition: Very good

item.name: Power Grid
item.comment:
Received in a math trade (1/12/15).
[i]I just acquired this game so I am looking forward to getting it to the table more. After I got to play it a second time it was a game I knew I would love to own, but at the time I didn't think it would go over well with my wife and older daughter. Based on all the games we've played since then I think they will enjoy the game. I ended up getting the original version of the game because I actually prefer the artwork and components of the original. Plus they removed trash from the game which is my son's resource of choice.
Everything I originally said about the game a year ago still stands today, this is a brilliant combination of auctions, resource/income management and route building.[/i]

item.name: Power Grid: Benelux/Central Europe
item.comment: [i]Excellent map for lower player counts (3/4) and the Benelux map really speeds up the game. I would recommend this map to those of you looking to play Power Grid with your family, it is an excellent intro map.[/i]

item.name: The Price Is Right
item.comment:
So one of my favorite childhood experiences was being able to watch The Price is Right when I was home sick from school. One of my early childhood ambitions was to be on the show [i](and operate an excavator)[/i], but unfortunately it never happened. Then that magic moment happened, I was at TotalCon and Chris from [family=19168][/family] [i](one of my favorite podcasts)[/i] asked my buddy Mat and I to join a game of The Price is Right. I jumped at the chance, we also played with another Matt and Eric Summerer [i](who played the role of a contestant and Rod Roddy)[/i]. Needless to say the experience was a blast and brought back all those memories from watching the TV show.
[i]If I find a copy of this game I will pick it up, it would be a blast to play it with my wife and kids and the rest of our family.[/i]

item.name: Pyramix
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Pyramix[/COLOR] was traded in a math trade with Asara, Ninjato and Pyramix 2/1/15. (Received The Golden Ages) Received in a math trade (8/8/14).
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]8[/COLOR]):
[i]I actually regret trading this one, but this happens once and a while when trying to fit your collection in a small space. Everything I said a year ago holds true, this is a quick, easy to teach gateway game with a really cool "board" (basically a pyramid of dice that slide down as you pull one out). I'll probably pick this one up again when my youngest daughter gets a bit older, if not sooner.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (7):
[i]- Plays excellent with 2 and 3 (haven't played with 4 yet). - Great family game (not surprisingly since it comes from Gamewright). - Plays really fast (under 15 minutes) and doesn't outstay it's welcome. - Great gateway/family game, really easy to teach/learn. - Simple to play, but packed with meaningful decisions. - Really nice production quality, this game looks good set up.[/i]
item.conditiontext: Excellent condition.
item.wishlistcomment: [i]Regret trading this one, can see Lilly playing this in the next year or so.[/i]

item.name: Quantum
item.comment: Highlights: - Dice as ships: each number is a different type of ship with it's own special power. - Finding the combos between using your 3 basic actions and your ships special powers. - Researching/ placing quantum cubes nets you cards which either grant a lasting ability or a one time ability (The card powers are great and work well and let you manipulate the game in different ways). - Great artwork and production. - It plays fast and remains fun throughout the whole game.

item.name: Quicksilver
item.comment:
Played a 3p game at TotalCon with Mat and my son. We had fun playing, this is as much a screw your neighbor game as it is a race. Based on how you choose to play cards you can decide to focus on the race or spend cards to damage your opponents ships or force them to discard cards. My son had fun, but he wanted to spend more time shooting my ship, but I was focused on staying far away from him [i](knowing his tendency to want to blow my stuff up)[/i]. Although in at the end he had a chance to shoot me twice which would have caused my armor to drop to 0 and I would have lost my next turn. First attack, he hit me on the second attack... he missed and I was able to cross the finish line on my next turn. Great end to the game though.
I love the theme and the art on the cards really evoke the theme of distinguished gentlemen/women taking part in a race. However; the board art is really boring. I know it is a landscape, but it is quite blah, with very few colors and details added to the map. Once you are playing this doesn't matter at all as you are trying to plot your movement to maximize how far you can go and hopefully stay out of firing range of your neighbors. There are some interesting mechanisms in the game, I particularly like how you adjust your speed each round [i](which correlates to the # of dice you roll)[/i] by forcing you to discard cards to get the maximum # of dice [i](which is 3)[/i]. That is a really tough decision because the cards all have very useful abilities.

item.name: Quilt Show
item.comment:
First off, I loved the artwork in the game, the tiles and cards are beautiful. I thought it was pretty cool that the designer of the game designed the quilt block patterns for the game.
Now on to game play, this is where the game felt very samey when compared to Ticket To Ride. Granted you are building quilts and vying for different amounts of prize money, but the mechanics and strategies felt extremely similar. You are still managing what cards to pick up vs. when to buy certain quilt blocks.
All of this is still fun, but I don't have room in my collection to have two games that play extremely similar to one another. For me Quilt Show would fall victim to the Jones theory in favor of TTR and here is why; I love how the board develops when you play TTR it looks great. In Quilt Show the quilts you make don't look that impressive; using 3 or 4 tiles to make a quilt isn't satisfying and they don't really look like much of a quilt.

item.name: Qwixx
item.comment:
Received in a trade (12/18/14)
[i]- Quick dice filler that you can play anywhere, with anyone. - Great twist on the standard dice rolling game, the scoring adds some decisions and tension to the game. - For such a simple game it is quite fun.
This is a fun filler that I may keep in my car to play when we are out at a restaurant or cafe. The choices are not that difficult, but there is some tension in the decisions you have to make. You need to balance taking white dice when it is not your turn with possibly limiting the rolls that will help you when you have to take dice on your turn or suffer a -5 penalty.[/i]
item.conditiontext:
This is a second copy I own.
Condition: Like New, unplayed
Edition: German second edition with SdJ 2013 nominee mark
Sweeteners: Qwixx gemixxt - New in shrink Two scoring pads for the game Qwixx - German version, New in shrink

item.name: Qwixx gemixxt
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Qwixx gemixxt[/COLOR] was sold via auction 11/5/15.
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]I enjoy playing with the expansions, but the game does take a bit longer because you are constantly looking for the different numbers and/or colors on the sheet. When using the sheet with the different colors in each row one of the other players says aloud what color/number combinations are available which definitely helps keep turns quick.[/i]
item.conditiontext:
This is a second copy I own.
New in shrink

item.name: Qwixx: Das Kartenspiel
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Qwixx: Das Kartenspiel[/COLOR]old via auction 6/15/15
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
[i]Coming soon...[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Quick card game that plays great with 2 - 4 players. - Another version of Qwixx that is simple to teach, with a clean rule set [i](perfect as a gateway game, especially for traditional card players)[/i]. - There is no Jone's theory here, both games use the same scoring rules but they both play very differently. - While this version retains some of the luck found in the dice version, you can mitigate it with clever play especially once you add in the wild cards.
This is a great translation of the dice game, I am always willing to play either of these games. This version has more depth than the dice version since you are not reliant on die rolls, but it is still a light, gateway game.[/i]

item.name: Ra
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Ra[/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 10/5/15. (Received Elysium) Received in a math trade (11/10/14).
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]10[/COLOR])
[i]For a time this had become my favorite auction game (replacing Knizia's Medici), but has since been replaced by Modern Art (another Knizia classic). Out of the 3 I still think this is the easiest for new players to grasp, especially since everyone has bidding tiles so it is really hard to completely mess up the economy of the game, where as in a game like Modern Art a really bad bid can hand someone the game. There is also a lot of decisions to make in the tiles you decide to collect because there is no way you can do everything, and on top of that you can lose points if you fail to collect any tiles of certain groups.
Ra ended up leaving my collection because my family had no interest in playing it and a lot of the other people I game with have copies. I still consider it an excellent game and one I am always willing to play. In my opinion Ra it is the closest to a gateway/family game when considering Knizia's auction games (I think For Sale is the best when considering other designers).[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Bidding tiles: obviously this is what makes the game. You can only bid with one of the 3 tiles you have in your hand which is extremely difficult since you may end up over paying for a group of tiles. - Set collection: I always enjoy this mechanic in a game. - Ra: Again there is a time crunch because once the Ra figure reaches the end of the track that round of bidding is over. This becomes especially stressful when yo are the only person pulling tiles/bidding at the end of a round [i](do I take another tile and chance getting nothing if I pull a Ra tile?)[/i].
This is an excellent game that I can see becoming a classic with more plays. I am really looking forward to introducing this one to my family, I think it will be a great step up in auction games from For Sale.[/i]

item.name: Ra: The Dice Game
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Ra: The Dice Game[/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 9/14/14. (Received Cubist)
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]8[/COLOR])
[i]This is one of those games that I really enjoy and will happily play my buddy's copy whenever it gets brought out, but it wasn't better than any of the dice games we already own (Cubist, VivaJava: The Coffee Game: The Dice Game, Qwixx and Würfel Bohnanza) so it got traded.
As an aside the ties to Ra are thematic only, this game has nothing in common with Ra (which is an amazing auction game).[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]I bought a copy of this at a local FLGS because I knew it was hard to find and I really wanted to find a dice filler I enjoyed that plays well with two. Mat taught me this game (2p which he told me was not an ideal player count) and while it was fun, I knew it was not what I was looking for. I can see how it would be really fun with more players, since there would be much more competition over certain areas (monuments comes to mind). The scoring penalties wouldn't be so harsh either, since usually the person with the least amount of something receives the penalty.
I would really like to play this with more players, because I know I would enjoy the game a lot more. However; I am going to trade my copy, mostly because I know this game would not see much play with my whole family (too many other games we want to play with 4) and the 2p game is not that fun.[/i]
item.wishlistcomment: Why did I trade this?

item.name: Race for the Galaxy
item.comment:
[i]- Role selection and trying to leech off your opponents role(s) - Cards have multiple uses during the game - Excellent 2p with the advanced rules - 20 minute play time packed with strategy - Seemingly endless replay value
My son and I had very little trouble figuring out the icons, I find that whole argument to be a little overblown. It may hold water if you are teaching this to a non gamer, but this isn't a game I would pull out in that circumstance.[/i]
35 -> Base RftG 50 -> Arc 1, The Gathering Storm + Rebel Imperium 73 -> Arc 2, Alien Artifacts [i](7 included the orb)[/i]

item.name: Race for the Galaxy: Alien Artifacts
Race for the Galaxy: Rebel vs Imperium
item.comment: [i]I am starting to think that this expansion adds too many cards to the game. I prefer the second arc expansion.[/i]

item.name: Race for the Galaxy: The Gathering Storm
item.comment: Received in a math trade (5/20/14).

item.name: Rampage
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Rampage [/COLOR]was sold via auction 1/5/15.
My thoughts:
[i]My son picked this out at Total Con last year and we played it a bunch that month, then it sat on the shelf. My kids played it a few times, but my wife and I didn't enjoy it at all. I thought the game would be much more fun than it is, there are moments of fun with a lot of frustration in between those moments. Worst part is that I spent an hour applying stickers to the pieces this summer only for the game to never get played again.[/i]

item.name: Rapa Nui
item.comment:
Highlights: - Excellent family game - Plays in under an hour, even with four - Extremely innovative blend of mechanics... [i]Resource collection[/i] - you are trying to manage which out of the 4 resources will be worth the most points by not only collecting them but also sacrificing them [i](discarding them from your hand)[/i] to the gods [i](the card most sacrificed is worth 3, the one sacrificed least is worth 0)[/i]. [i]Activating workers[/i] - First you place a card from your hand into your tableau of workers, then you draw a card from one of 4 rows [i](each column in a row has 4 cards to start)[/i] and you activate the card underneath the card you took. This really creates some interesting decisions, because you may really want a card, but activating the next one helps your opponents more than you. [i]Building Moai[/i] Lets you sacrifice a card from the draw piles and then secretly sacrifice another card [i](giving everyone else less info on how many of each type are in the sacrifice pile)[/i].
[i]I haven't played anything like this before, it is an excellent, quick game that I can't wait to play again. Unfortunately it was never released in the States and Kosmos has no plans to reprint it in German.[/i]

item.name: Rattlebones
item.comment: [i]- Brilliant family game, quick rules explanation and your off and running. - I wasn't sole on the theme until I actually got the game, but it works quite well, I love the art and the components are top notch (especially the dice). - Dice building, you are actually constructing your dice (removing faces and popping on new ones). - This game is just fun, trying out new ways to construct your dice is a blast especially since there are so many different combinations of abilities to try.[/i]

item.name: Red
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Red7[/COLOR] was given to Chris as a small thanks for running the TotalCon 2015 math trade.
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR])
[i]After a bunch of plays I really didn't want to play any more. The game has a clever set of rules, but they don't come together to make an especially exciting or tense game. I primarily played this with my wife, and considering the limited time we play games there was no way this was getting picked over any of the other card games we play together.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Quick card game that plays well 2p and more. - Easy to teach, but really has some depth to it. You really need to plan out how you can play your hand of cards. - 7 cards: That's it, you do not draw additional cards in this game. - Simple artwork, but quite beautiful, with excellent graphic design.[/i]

item.name: Relic Runners
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Relic Runners[/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 2/7/15. (Received Saint Malo)
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]8[/COLOR])
[i]Why did I get rid of a game I still rank an 8? Mostly because it was a game I got to play with my family and my kids enjoyed it at first, but then it languished on our shelves. I tried to bring it out at my game group, but there was never any interest. Since I am committed to fitting my collection on a certain shelving unit it got traded to make room for some new games.
I still think this is an underrated DoW game and is great for families, and one I'd still play. However; be warned that while it is relatively light it is not a good gateway game. In the end I think that has a lot to do with Relic Runners lack of success. There newest game, Five Tribes, has enough depth to appeal to gamers while families can enjoy it as well.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Awesome family game that has some hidden depth to be uncovered; I am looking forward to some more plays. - Excellent production, love how you build the temples out of different shaped cardboard tokens and the relics are really nice (they remind me of Forbidden Island). - Great intro into route building (it is simple, but you need to put some thought and planning into where your routes are going to connect). - It is satisfying when you finally get to go on a relic run after spending lots of time exploring temples and building pathways. - Variable powers can be obtained by exploring certain temples (there are 3 colors of temples and they each give you different abilities or points).[/i]

item.name: The Resistance: Avalon
item.comment:
Another new to me game played at the library meet up. First of all this is a great group for these kinds of games since we tend to be a bit raucous. I think this game depends on having the right group dynamic, I could see it becoming very dry and procedural if played with the wrong group.
[i]All that said I would enjoy playing it again, especially since it plays so fast, but it is not necessarily a game that I feel the need to own. Partly because someone in our group has it and I think the more players the better, I would not want to play this with less than 5 or 6.[/i]

item.name: Rights
item.comment:
[i]An okay card game that will draw comparisons to No Thanks. You are drawing a card and keeping it or paying a coin to pass it to the next player. The person taking that card receives all the coins places on it. What does it add... more luck in the form of 3 cards being dealt to you which will added to the tableau of cards in front of you to find out who has the majority of each number.
What is frustrating, and a missed opportunity, is that you have no control over your hand. Those are the cards you will add to your tableau once the round is over. The only purpose those cards serve is having some hidden information from your opponent. Since those cards can never be changed there isn't a lot of choice to be had, you flip a card and decide whether or not pass or keep it. The game is quick and functional, but I didn't find it fun or engaging. I really don't have much desire to play it again, I would much rather play No Thanks.
A note on components: These cards are tiny! 2/3's of the box is taken up by wooden discs ( your coins), the other 1/3 is devoted to the cards. Really?! I understand that this doesn't having anything to do with game play, but it really detracts from the play experience.[/i]

item.name: Risk Legacy
item.comment:
Christmas gift 2014 (Lucien)
[i]I won't be posting my thoughts till we finish the campaign. I will say that 5 or 6 games in and I'm less enamored with it than I was at first. Concept is awesome, but it is still Risk (which hasn't aged well considering my found memories of playing that game countless times while growing up).[/i]

item.name: Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island
item.comment: [i]- A truly immersive gaming experience, one of the first games I've played that really tells a story of your particular adventure. - The artwork is awesome, the tiles look beautiful and I love how the character mats and various decks of cards have sepia toned gesture drawings that look like they were done with ink in a field artists sketchbook. - The production is top notch, there are absolutely no cut corners in this game, the $ of this game is definitely more than justified once you open up the box. - Amazing how such a complex game flows quite smoothly after your first play or two. [i]Overall I found the rule book to be well written and any other questions I had were answered on one of the faqs found here on BGG.[/i] - I love how brutal this game can be, it really intensifies the stress you feel and forces you to work together as a team if you are going to have any chance at surviving [i](i.e. winning).[/i] - The game does take a while [i](our games have been between 1 1/2 to 2 hours each)[/i], but time flies since the game is so engaging. - By far the best co-op I've played, in fact I already bought the first expansion, but we won't break it open till we play through [i](and survive)[/i] the rest of the scenarios in the base game.[/i]
item.wishlistcomment: [i]High on the list because we still haven't found a COOP we like. While it's not our favorite genre, I think the theme of RC is awesome and one my kids would get into. It also looks like a meaty experience which is right up our alley. May be fun to solo as well... Maybe a Christmas gift if I don't get it sooner.[/i]

item.name: Roll for the Galaxy
item.comment: [i]- Excellent translation of Race for the Galaxy into a meaty dice game. - Beautiful art and production quality, everything feels/looks top notch. - Much easier to teach than Race; the iconography is greatly reduced and the tiles have their powers printed on them. - Double sided tiles are a great solution for the explore action, there are plenty of times when you really would benefit from both options. - Having produce before ship is more intuitive and helps streamline the produce/ship strategy and - Purple die; boosts the produce/ship strategy by acting as a wild color (effectively increasing the value of goods consumed). - There are a lot of strategies to explore in this game giving Roll high replay value.[/i]

item.name: Roll for the Galaxy: Ambition
item.comment:
Initial thoughts and rating (10):
[i]I'm surprised this game hasn't hit the table more, probably due to so many new games coming into our collection this month. That said I love what the expansion adds to the base game. Ambition doesn't do anything to fundamentally change game play or add any new elements to the existing game play a la RFtG (takeovers or the orb anyone?).
Instead what Ambition does is add more variety to the game by adding a bunch of new start tiles, 6 tiles to go in the bag (some RFtG favorites) and two new dice types. The black leader dice and orange dice are awesome, many sides showing 2 symbols or the ability to buy back the die automatically if you use it for it's native purpose. Ambition also adds goals (similar those found in The Gathering Storm expansion for Race) which can give you some focus in your tableau buidling. What I like most about the goal tiles is that it is not just straight VP, instead you can spend the chits you get to act as a one time use wild worker die. Any tokens you choose not to use are worth 1 VP each at the end of the game.
All in all I think this is an excellent expansion and a must buy for fans of the base game. I love the ability to draft starting tiles in the beginning of the game and the new dice are extremely powerful but well balanced (you can only have 1 leader die and it is very difficult to obtain the orange dice).[/i]

item.name: Roll Through the Ages: The Bronze Age
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Roll Through the Ages: The Bronze Age[/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 5/20/14. (Received RFtG: The Gathering Storm) Received in a math trade (3/12/14).
[i]I found this game to be quite boring. It was definitely not the dice filler I have been looking for.[/i]

item.name: Rolling Freight
item.comment: I played a 2p game with Mat teaching and had a blast. I love pick up and deliver games and this also added in rolling dice. Even with the dice this game never felt random, I always had options on my turn, maybe not always what I wanted but that's okay. The upgrade cards you get will definitely keep the game fresh because they can definitely alter how you will play the game. I also enjoyed optimizing my delivery routes in order to score bonuses on goods that either wanted a fast delivery [i](minimum number of connections between cities)[/i] or a slow delivery. I thought the game worked really well with two and I am looking forward to playing again.

item.name: Royals
item.comment:
[i]Royals, or Ticket to Ride meets area control. I honestly got the same feeling playing this as I do in TTR with one important exception. First the similarities, in both cards you are collecting cards in order to play sets of colors to take control of spaces on the board. In TTR you are trying to complete routes, in Royals you are competing for control of countries and each type aristocrat in the game.
The biggest difference in the games is that in TTR you can block people permanently (unless you're playing with stations), whereas in Royals there is a second card type you can draw called an intrigue card. You can play an intrigue card with the required number of colored cards to kick someone out of a space on the board. Late game this becomes extremely important as the board fills up with cubes.
I mention the connection to TTR because I think Royals is very close to being a gateway game or at most a very small step up in complexity. I enjoyed my play of this game, it is a very clean design without any unnecessary rules clutter. The game play is quite straightforward, but the decisions you have to make are quite deep. You really have to pay attention to your opponents and what they are doing.
I would consider this the gateway game into the genre of area control. It is as interactive as El Grande (my personal favorite), but easier to get into.[/i]
item.wishlistcomment: [i]I Really enjoyed my one play and even though the game is dry I think I could get it to the table at my house. I definitely think V would play since the mechanics are so simple.[/i]

item.name: Rummikub
item.comment:
Rummikub... I honestly don't know what to say about this tile version of Rummy. It adds some interesting twists to basic rummy since you can use jokers and switch tiles from melds that have already been played as long as you use all the tiles.
I only played one time with my buddy Mat (This also happens to be one of his favorite games). I enjoyed it, but I feel like a game this simple is all about nuance and I just don't have the plays to really judge how much I like it. I want to play with my wife and get her reaction, she may love it, but I could also see her suffering from major AP.

item.name: Rüsselbande
item.comment: [i]- Like all of Drei Magier Spiele's games the production quality is through the roof, awesome art, thick cardboard tiles and beautiful wooden pigs that stack. - The game plays fast and is a great introductory racing game to play with young children. - You are never out of the race: [i]If you roll a black 1 you can roll again. If you roll a black 3, and you are in last place, you roll again.[/i] [i]Once per game you can move the first tile of the track to the end, lengthening the race.[/i] - I love the fact that children can really work on their fine motor skills by stacking the pigs and discs in all sorts of combinations(the rulebook actually shows tons of examples)[/i].

item.name: Russian Railroads
item.comment:
RR is going on my wishlist, but it is definitely too heavy to be a family game at my house right now. I also do not think it would be quite as good playing 2p with my son. So for now I will play it whenever I get a chance at a con, etc.
My rating could go up with a few more plays, but for now it is an average game.

item.name: Sail to India
item.comment:
Highlights: - Love the cube management, basically they are your ships, traders, scientists, bankers and historians (score keepers) which leads to lots of tough decisions to make when you are taking actions. - Appears to be lots of replay value, especially due to the different technologies you can invest in which lead to different ways to score. - There is a decent amount of player interaction since there is a limited number of buildings, resources and technologies. - Nice production: the artwork is okay, I really like the over sized cards.
Looking forward to playing this again, not sure if I would buy it because the minimum player count of 3. I know my son would enjoy it, but I don't know if my wife and daughter would dig it. Since guys in both groups I game with own it, it is really not a priority. (Although the game is cheap!)

item.name: Saint Malo
item.comment:
