[COLOR=#FF0000]Saint Malo[/COLOR] was sold via auction 4/20/15. Received in a math trade (2/7/15)
My thoughts:
[i]I have to admit I had high hopes for this game and was utterly disappointed. To sum it up this game ends up feeling very scripted. If pirates are rolled early you have no choice but to focus on walls and soldiers or you will get hammered with negative points.
I ended up feeling like your decision space was very limited, even when you could flip dice, especially since you can't flip pirates and the people symbool is on the other side. Therefore you need to roll people naturally to do all the cool stuff and we all spent countless turns trying to get 3 to 4 people in order to build merchants, architects and jugglers.
We gave it 3 plays and each successive play was less and less interesting, therefore I will be trading this one away.[/i]

item.name: Saint Petersburg (second edition)
item.comment:
[i]Please note I haven't played the original game and I was playing with a bunch of sharks who new the game inside and out. The other players were telling me about the changes/additions to the 2nd edition and I definitely enjoyed what the new market phase added to the game. I could see how really good players could basically solve the 1st edition game (not that I'd be able too) so the market added another way to score a variable amount of points depending how hard other people pushed it.
I enjoyed having to figure out how to manage my income, keep track of the cards in my hand and still actually get something done in the game. The game is very demanding and would take a couple of plays before I think I would have a chance to win. It is not overly complex, but it does reward repeated play because there is very little margin for error and if you fall behind you're not going to catch up.
I really enjoyed my first play, but it ran long (at least 2.5 hours). One player had serious AP so I can't really fault the game, but it did detract from the experience. That said I'd definitely like to play this again, but it is not the kind of game I'd add to my collection or recommend to families (it is very unforgiving, especially if you don't manage your income properly). [/i]

item.name: Samurai
item.comment:
Yet another Knizia played this month and I really enjoyed it. I was only able to play a 2p game and I thought it was great, however I read a lot of discussion about the 2p game favoring the first player and was a bit disappointed because I would probably primarily play with 2. However; as I thought about it it wouldn't be bad since I would be playing with my kids and this could give them a small edge when playing against me (although they really don't need it).
Highlights: - Beautiful components, modular board that adjusts depending on the number of players. - Another simple to teach, but packed with strategy board game. - Just enough different types of tiles to really make the game packed with tough decisions and lots of replay potential.

item.name: Samurai Spirit
item.comment: Another co-op that in the end falls flat for me. The game play is fun, but the theme is completely lost which is really the most disappointing aspect of the game for me. I don't know how you can take such an amazing premise (basing a game on 7 Samurai) and completely fail to take advantage of it. Everything in the game feels very dry and mechanical. All that said the game functions fine, but if I am going to play a coop game I want to play something that is much more thematic and has some kind of narrative arc to it [i](I'm really interested in playing Robinson Crusoe)[/i].

item.name: San Juan (second edition)
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]San Juan[/COLOR] was sold via auction 4/20/15.
Updated thoughts and rating coming soon...
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
- Excellent family game and one my wife enjoys, it also makes a great cafe game. - A game that plays very similar to Race for the Galaxy [i](one of my favorites)[/i] that is easy to teach. - Multi use cards, one of my favorite game mechanisms [i](cards can be played to your tableau for points/abilities, used as goods or spent as currency)[/i]. - High replay value - a lot of interesting building synergies to discover through repeated play.
All of my comments reflect playing with the expansion buildings which are included in the second edition. I would rate the game a 6 without the expansion, I didn't think there was enough variety to the strategies you could try with just the base game. Once I added the expansion cards I really enjoyed this game.[/i]

item.name: Santiago
item.comment:
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]I really enjoyed this game, perfect blend of strategy and negotiation. The use of the once around auction mechanic not only creates a lot of tense moments (every $ counts in this game), it also keeps the game moving along at a quick pace. The added dimension of having one player be in charge of placing the additional water each round adds further negotiation and planning, you really have to pay attention to everyone and make sure you're not placing your crop where the chances of it getting watered are slim to none.
I would always be willing to play this game, but I think you need at least 4 players. Unfortunately even though my buddy Mat owns this game I don't think I'll get to play that often if at all, hopefully I'll get the chance at Totalcon this year.[/i]

item.name: Sator Arepo Tenet Opera Rotas
item.comment:
Meet some fun folks at TotalCon (Brian and Dan) and after teaching them one of my favorites ([thing=129948][/thing]) Brian taught brought this game out. You begin the game by placing Tetris shaped pieces to build pathways on the board in order to collect books that are scattered about. Sounds easy, except the whole game is screwing over everyone else by moving the paths they need away from them while also trying to position the pathways you need into position. You can move pieces orthogonality or rotate them on any axis. You are drawing cards which give you different abilities and each player also has their own deck cards that are even more powerful [i](but they can only be used once per game)[/i].
This was a really fun game, the take that wasn't really mean and half the time what you thought was really going to screw someone over ends up helping them out.
[i]I would recommend you check this one out, I was glad to play a game I never heard of before. The only problem is that it was designed and produced in Italy and had a small print run, so it is not easy to find.[/i]

item.name: Scripts and Scribes: The Dice Game
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Scripts and Scribes: The Dice Game [/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 4/14/14. (Received Bohnanza)
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR])
[i]I was probably a bit hasty trading this one away, it was before I belonged to a regular gaming group. At the time I traded it away because my kids had a hard time playing it, especially when it came to the gold auctions. The other reason was the horrible art and mediocre components. I am very excited about Biblios Dice and will probably pick up a copy. I was really happy when I read how Dr. Finn streamlined the auctions and cut it down to one type (no more clunky gold auctions). I think this version will be much easier for my kids to learn.
Now that I have played Biblios I think the card version beats out Scripts and Scribes Dice, but I am looking forward to seeing how Biblios Dice compares.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- This is a fairly light game that my older daughter (8) can play. - A game my wife enjoys. - It plays well with 2+ players. - Quick play time (less than a 1/2 hour). - Dice rolling and dice selection to move up certain tracks to score points. - The value of each track fluctuated because you can sometimes change the value of a specific column. - The auctions, especially to be able to use all the dice yourself.[/i]

item.name: Seasons
item.comment: I played this with my son, and while we both liked it I found it to be very fiddly. You constantly need to check all of your cards and also base your play off of all those different powers. My son plays lots of games and he holds his own but he found it hard to find a strategy in this game.

item.name: Seeland
item.comment: [i]- Excellent 2 and 3 player game [i](and my wife really likes it).[/i] - The theme shines through for me, the mechanics of the game simulate the - Love the wooden windmills, the board looks beautiful as you place windmills and the well illustrated tiles [i](which feature different crops).[/i] - Simple mechanics (buy a tile, place a tile and possibly score a windmill), but a lot of hidden depth to be found in those simple choices. - The rondel mechanic used to handle your income in this game is genius.[/i]

item.name: Seventh Hero
item.comment: Fun bluffing game that I need to play again. The problem for me is that my family loves Cockroach Poker, enjoys Love Letter and I love Coup so I am not sure that I need another bluffing game in this vein. Definitely a step up in complexity from a game like Love Letter because you can "tap" cards to use their abilities. It was fun and I would not turn down a game, but my favorite bluffing game is still Cockroach Poker.

item.name: Sheriff of Nottingham
item.comment: Fun, but overly complicated for a bluffing game. I still prefer Cockroach Poker if I want to play a pure bluffing game, especially with family.

item.name: Siberia: The Card Game
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Siberia: The Card Game[/COLOR] was sold via Marketplace 6/14/15
Initial thoughts and rating (6):
[i]I saw this game mentioned on a geekbuddy's New to Me list. I ended up finding an inexpensive copy a few months ago and finally got it to the table. It is a very simple game where you are playing cards to collect resources trying to earn the most money for the resources you've collected. There are a few worker cards that adjust the endgame payout of resources, but the game is still quite straight forward and seems to play out very similarly game to game. It's a game my son enjoys, so we'll get some more plays in, but there isn't enough there to keep this game in our collection for the long term.[/i]

item.name: Sky Tango
item.comment:
[i]The art is awesome, I am really glad it they didn't change it for the US release. This is a great, quick playing card game that plays fast and has some take that since you can interrupt the other players melds they are building.
What separates this game from other card games is how the scoring works. Basically you need to have at least 5 cards in a row on the table before you can score; however you can only draw new cards when you empty your hand of all 5 cards. This creates some awesome tension for a game with such a simple rule set.[/i]

item.name: Sky Tango
item.comment:
Sold via auction 6/15/15
[i]The art is awesome, I am really glad it they didn't change it for the US release. This is a great, quick playing card game that plays fast and has some take that since you can interrupt the other players melds they are building.
What separates this game from other card games is how the scoring works. Basically you need to have at least 5 cards in a row on the table before you can score; however you can only draw new cards when you empty your hand of all 5 cards. This creates some awesome tension for a game with such a simple rule set.[/i]

item.name: Small World
item.comment: [i]Okay game play, but definitely showing it's age. Personally, I don't think this game srands the test of time (I know many will disagree).[/i]

item.name: Smash Up
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Smash Up[/COLOR] was sold via auction.
[i]Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]2[/COLOR])
Since I only played this once I will stand by my original comments. In my opinion this is not a family game, nor is it very fun. This is probably the least fun game we have gotten, I have no desire to ever play this game again. That said I know a lot of people find it fun, it just did not work for us which is kind of a bummer since I love the concept.
Initial thoughts and rating (3):
Just played with mt two oldest kids (10 and 7) and the game bombed. We played for 45 minutes and we had 2-3 points apiece. Way too much text on the cards for this game to be accessible to my 7 year old. She is a good reader, but having a hand of 5 - 10 cards with lots of text overwhelmed her. My son wasn't really enthralled with it either.
Both of my kids play and love Summoner Wars, but SU is not nearly as approachable nor would it have the depth of SW to play at a higher level with other skilled players. So a huge thumbs down, I am really disappointed with this game.[/i]

item.name: Smash Up: Awesome Level 9000
item.comment: [COLOR=#FF0000]Smash Up: Awesome Level 9000[/COLOR] was sold via auction with Smash Up.

item.name: Snakebit
item.comment: This is a really fun trick taker that is played with a [thing=37301][/thing] deck. I would love to play it again, the one thing that stood out was that the cards have 2 suits, so poisoning the trick is a bit easier. If you play this just be prepared to possibly end up with a negative score, this game is not easy and would take a lot of play to become proficient playing it.

item.name: Snowdonia
item.comment:
[i]- I think this would make am excellent 2nd tier family weight WP game. - The theme shines through; in both mechanisms and art/aesthetics. - A lot of tension, especially due to the event track. You really can't wait too long to act or the man will come in and due it before you. - The weather really helps the theme come through and forces you to plan ahead since every turn the efficiency of your actions can change. - The variety of the contract cards really open up a variety of strategies to pursue, there is a lot of game in this box.
I didn't think I would get into solo games, but I've been playing a lot of Loyang. Not only do I think my family would enjoy this game (trains seem to be a hit in our house) I would also enjoy trying it out solo.[/i]

item.name: Soulfall
item.comment:
[i]Obviously this is based on one play, but I was completely underwhelmed by the very basic game play. You can take 3 actions on your turn from a list such as draw cards, place tokens, flip tokens, play a card from your hand. Yes you could set up some very basic combos, but I never felt like I was accomplishing anything.
Why, because it is very easy to have everything you do on a turn become completely undone by another player without any way to protect yourself. The the random nature of the card play basically kills the opportunity to set up actions you can execute on your next turn which means each turn is self contained and to be honest quite boring.
The scoring is fine if a bit formulaic (it feels like an inelegant Knizia scoring system that really just rewards you for treating each scoring currency with equal value). The end game trigger is extremely problematic because after it is triggered everyone gets one more turn (besides the person triggering it) making it a disadvantage to the player ending the game because they are out of actions and at the mercy of the other players. At that point the game could come to a stand still as people math out where everyone stands and then decide what the best play is for them. Not exciting to say the least, especially since some players will be so far out of it the only decision they will have is who to king make. This game feels like it needed more play testing and some streamlining of the game play. There isn't anything in this game that makes me want to play again.[/i]

item.name: Space Cadets: Dice Duel
item.comment:
This was the last game my daughter and I played at TotalCon, and it was an excellent way to end the con. This is by far the most fun I've had playing a real time game. It perfectly blends the chaos of real time while still offering a lot of tactical play. The components are beautiful, the dice are really nice.
The reason I probably will not add this to my collection is because even though you can play up to 8 it is not a party/family game that you can teach to anyone. There is enough complexity in how everything works that I could not imagine bringing this out with my parents or extended family at a holiday get together, where as a game like [thing=155362][/thing] is so easy to teach I have been able to teach it to a lot of people.
I will happily play this game anytime I get the opportunity as long as it is with 6+ players.

item.name: Space Empires: 4X
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Space Empires 4X[/COLOR] was sold via auction 11/5/15.
My thoughts:
[i]I can see how amazing this game would be if you could find a dedicated group to play it consistently [i](this isn't a game to bring off your shelf once or twice a year)[/i]. This really feels like some of the space conquest games I grew up playing on my pc [i](the original [thing=68287][/thing] comes to mind)[/i].
I played two solo games and I didn't find the [i](solo)[/i] game compelling enough to justify the time invest needed to set up and play. I also know that my son will not be interested in learning and playing this game long term. He's always willing to learn a new game and play with me, but I know he'll be done after one play so I'm not going to invest the time in teaching him this game [i](especially since he showed 0 interest in it while I was playing solo)[/i]. I also don't have a group that would want to invest in learning/playing this game with any regularity.
If I had a time machine and could go back to my 17 year old self I'd have played this game countless times with my old group of friends, but now this kind of game doesn't fit into my lifestyle. Maybe some day...[/i]

item.name: The Speicherstadt
item.comment:
[i]I can't wait to play this game again, I guess I really like auction games ([thing=12][/thing] and [thing=46][/thing] are also favorites of mine)[/i].
Highlights: - Really tight auctions, every coin matters. - Building an engine that will not only generate some income, but also score you points. - This is an easy game to learn, but there is so much depth for such a simple game. - The worker placement to determine the price of the card up for auction and determining bid order... perfect. - Fires; yes they suck, but the firemen add another layer of tension to the auctions.

item.name: Splendor
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Splendor[/COLOR] was traded away with Dixit Origins and Le Havre: The Inland Port for Blue Moon City 10/31/14.
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]4[/COLOR]):
[i]The first time I played it I was completely underwhelmed. Then I got the game as a gift and played it a lot with my kids over the course of a month. Then it fell off a cliff, I think we all got tired of the game play and complete lack of a theme.
A lot of people have mentioned that this is a great gateway game, but I strongly disagree. I don't think it holds up to repeated play which to me is a huge part of what defines a good gateway game (Ticket to Ride and Camel Up come to mind).
I will also mention that I absolutely agree with Camel Up winning the Spiel last year. Camel Up has delivered every time I pull it out whether it is family, gamers and more casual gamers. I don't think Splendor holds a candle to Camel Up.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Easy to teach, quick play time. - Great family game. - Beautiful components [i](yes this is definitely part of the appeal of this game).[/i] - Stripped down version of 7 Wonders [i](collecting resources to buy other card types).[/i] - 3 levels of cards which are worth more points and provide you with a resource. - Bonus nobles can really change how you play the game. - You need to pay attention to your opponents and possibly take cards you don't need so they don't score easy points.[/i]

item.name: Spooky Stairs
item.comment: [i]- The first memory game that I have found that is a blast to play, even if your memory is awful (which mine is). - Typical amazing component quality from Drei Magier Spiele, everything is much bigger than I imagined (especially the board and ghosts). - This game looks awesome when it is set up, it really is inviting to children. - Another game that is engaging not only to my 5 yo daughter, but also my older kids (13 and 10).[/i]

item.name: Star Realms
item.comment: [i]This is actually a deck builder that I could get behind. It plays quick, doesn't necessarily rely on deck thinning and has awesome artwork. I am still on the fence as to whether or not I want to add this to my collection; I still would rather pull out Race for the Galaxy to get a quick card gaming fix. My biggest complaint is keeping track of your life total using dice or cards, it is very tedious. For now I will be content to play this game with my buddy Joel who loves this game.[/i]

item.name: Starfighter
item.comment:
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Wow this game is vicious, you can destroy someone quick if they aren't paying attention. - Games last about 15 to 20 minutes [i](which is the perfect length considering the random nature of the card draws.[/i] - If you like building card combos this is the game for you, it is possible to chain together 3 or 4 moves by playing 1 card. - There are 4 different ship boards included and I was quite surprised by how they changed your strategy. - Innovation, the combination of having to pay attention to your ship board and the way you play cards is unlike anything I've played before.
This is a really hard game to describe without visuals, I'd highly recommend you check out [geekurl=/video/78697/starfighter/video-review]Marco's video overview[/geekurl], he does a great job explaining the mechanics of the game. It is easier to understand once you see how the board/cards interact.
All that said I'm not sure how long this game will last in our collection since we have so many 2p games and I have a feeling this game could get old do to the limited card pool. However; I definitely think this is a game worth checking out.[/i]

item.name: The Staufer Dynasty
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]The Staufer Dynasty[/COLOR] was sold via auction 4/25/15.
My thoughts:
[i]The Staufer Dynasty is an area control game with some specific rules on how you move around the board and eventually claim spots in a territory. Mix in some bonus tiles that let you move for free or spend one worker to claim a spot on the board. There are also end game goals you are trying to complete, but in reality you can really only accomplish them on your last turn.
Here are my thoughts, I would much rather play El Grande if I want to play an area control game. El Grande is a much cleaner design with a lot less rules overhead. There is also much more player interaction in El Grande, you are vying for control of the same region in order to score it. In The Staufer Dynasty everything is indirect, it feels more like worker placement. Someone takes one space so you now need to take another spot. I also prefer the immediacy of your actions in El Grande, you get into it with people where as The Staufer Dynasty is a much more passive affair.
My thoughts in a nutshell: El Grande creates an amazing meta game due to those tense, edge of your seat moments that you will be talking about during future plays. The Staufer Dynasty is completely devoid of those moments and therefore falls completely flat for me (it feels too much like a solitaire game).[/i]

item.name: Steam Park
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Steam Park[/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 2/7/15. (Received Trajan) Received in a math trade (5/15/14).
[i]Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]8[/COLOR]):
[i]I really loved the theme and art of this game, building a theme park is a lot of fun thanks to the great components. I had a lot of fun playing this with my family, unfortunately after 10+ plays it started to get repetitive and my kids lost interest in playing. The real limitation of the game is the placement rules for the rides and buildings, after a while you realize that there really isn't that much variation in how you set up your park.
There are also some buildings that are much better than others which leads to a very similar game play experience because everyone tries to be the first to grab those buildings. Same thing with the scoring cards, there are really only a few different ways to score points with the cards, the color just changes (i.e one cad is green rides vs. another card being blue rides.
That being said we enjoyed the game and it is a great family game, but after about 12 plays you've seen and done it all. Playing it a couple of times a year would still be fun and the game would feel fresh, but I don't keep family games in our collection if they aren't going to see a lot of play. However; I think 12 plays is great for this style of game and we enjoyed the ride while it lasted.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Awesome artwork! I love all of the different rides this game is a visual feast for the eyes. I love building my park and seeing all of theses cool rides and robots in it. - Great placement rules for the rides, they force you to really plan out your park in advance. It adds a great spacial puzzle to the game play. - Easy to teach to new players. - Great family game, my kids love the theme and game play. They find the simultaneous dice rolling a lot less stressful than in Escape. - The "dirt" mechanic really ratchets up the tension in this game since you can not just focus on building the best park. - Multiple paths to victory, especially if you use the special powers of the different stands you can buy.[/i]

item.name: Stichling
item.comment: [i]- I really enjoy the artwork (monsters are poking the numbers with sharp objects). - After my first couple of games I was extremely disappointed, but after a couple of more plays the game really opened up. - There are two unique mechanisms found in this trick taker: [size=6]1[/size]. There can be 4 potential tricks on the table at one time. [size=6]2[/size]. You have 3 scoring cards face down in front of you. Each time you take a trick you flip up the next scoring card and flip down the previous one [i](you only ever have one face up scoring card)[/i]. - The real fun of the game is balancing tricks you want to take, while making sure to force your opponent(s) to take at least one extra trick. - I don't want to get into a complete rules overview, but you can read them for yourself [filepage=117519]here[/filepage].[/i]

item.name: Stone Age
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Stone Age[/COLOR] was sold via auction 4/4/15.
[i]Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
This was our introduction into worker placement games and is probably my wife's favorite game. Personally I prefer other WP/action selection games[i](Agricola, Targi, Snowdonia, Agricola ACBaS and Lords of Waterdeep if I'm looking for a gateway WP game).
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
- Plays great with 2 (probably my preferred player count). - Plays quick with 2 (under an hour). - Great family/gateway worker placement game, the dice introduce some randomness into the game so that you can not math your way into winning. - Rolling dice to collect resources is fun as opposed to just collecting "x" number when you go to a certain location (a la Lords of Waterdeep). - I enjoy the diversity of ways you can score points [i](set collection, building huts, collecting builders, shaman or farmers)[/i], I like going for the civ cards. - Beautiful board art and really nice components.
[i]This is one of my wife's favorite games and I have been threatened with bodily harm if I trade this game... until today![/i]
item.conditiontext:
Condition: Very good
Edition: English third edition, Z-Man Games

item.name: Strasbourg
item.comment: Highlights - Upfront planning; you really need to have a plan in this game and pay attention to all 5 rounds, making sure you pinpoint what the auctions will be for you based on the hidden goals you have. - Auction mechanic is excellent, you start the game with 24 bidding cards for 35 auctions. - Income management; you need to win an auction to sell goods, which forces you to pay attention your income. - The ability associated with being 1st player [i](lets you build the city tile)[/i] or 2nd player [i](lets you build the chapel)[/i] makes that auction quite competitive.

item.name: StreetSoccer
item.comment:
I want to play this one again, the game play was much more strategic than I expected. You really need to think about how you position your players. Even though you are relying on dice rolls I didn't find this game to be very luck dependent.
[i]I had fun playing this and it would make a great cafe/pub game.[/i]

item.name: Subdivision
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Subdivision[/COLOR] was sold via auction 6/15/15
Updated thoughts and rating coming soon...
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- A great combination of tile drafting and the spacial puzzle of deciding where to place your tiles. - The aesthetic tie in with Suburbia [i](and that's where it ends, this game is nothing like Suburbia)[/i]. - This game manages to pack in a lot of variety in strategies with limited tile choices [i](5 zoning tiles that each produce a different improvement tile)[/i]. - Excellent 2p game that sets up quickly and plays fast.[/i]

item.name: Suburbia
item.comment:
Christmas gift 2013 (Lucien)
[i]- Plays well with 2, I also really enjoy it with 3 (haven't played with 4 and I'm not sure I want to). - Sim City the board game, enough said. - Nice components, I actually really like the graphic design and aesthetics in this game. Once you finish constructing your city it looks great. - I really enjoy all the different ways the various tiles interact with each other, and the variety of the buildings themselves. - Having to balance your income versus reputation is really difficult and since different tiles come out every game, this is a game you can play a lot. - This game is usually pretty tight and the winner is not decided till the end.[/i]

item.name: Suburbia Inc
item.comment: 8 plays with the expansion. At this point I almost want to play just the base game. I have found that with more plays the borders get ignored a lot and I am not a fan of the bonus goals that go on the B and C stack.

item.name: Summoner Wars: Master Set
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Summoner Wars[/COLOR] was sold via auction 12/14/14.
Updated thoughts and comments coming soon...
Initial thoughts and rating (10):
[i]- Excellent family game to play with your kids. - Another 2p gem that plays in about 30 minutes. - Almost endless replay value due to all the different factions you can play. - Faction balance even though most factions have very different play styles. - Rewards repeated play, it definitely helps to know the cards in each deck. - Lots of dice rolling built into a game that rewards skillful play, most of the time the better player will win. - However; when playing with less skilled players they can pull off the upset, combat is not deterministic. - The map really makes this game shine, you have the added component of having to think about movement and placement of your troops on a board.
I also owned the following factions: Guild Dwarves vs Cave Goblins Phoenix Elves vs Tundra Orcs Guild Dwarves 2 Summoner Phoenix Elves 2 Summoner[/i]

item.name: Super Motherload
item.comment:
Received in a trade (6/2/15)
[i]- The perfect translation of a video game into a board game (I sunk countless hours into I Dig It HD for iPad). - Excellent family game, it's easy to learn, has a fun theme and plays quick. - A deck builder I really like for two reasons: 1. You don't have to cycle cards out of your deck, they are all useful. 2. Your deck is small (after an average game you probably have 12 cards in your deck). - Combos are relatively easy to set up, you can piggy back a bunch of actions together using artifact powers and the one time powers you get from buying cards. - The addition of the goal cards add a lot variety in how you score points and help kids see different combos and plan ahead. - I love the tactile nature of the game, I enjoy seeing the board fill up with tunnels we've dug[/i]

item.name: Survive: Escape from Atlantis!
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Survive[/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 3/17/15. (Received Camel Up)
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]8[/COLOR]):
[i]Unfortunately this stopped seeing play in favor of other gateway games with extended family (Camel Up and Diamant to name a few) and my kids didn't really want to play so I traded it away. In my opinion this is still a great game to introduce to family and friends that are new to the hobby. I definitely prefer it over The Downfall of Pompeii.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- A great introductory family game as long as your family can deal with some take that game play. - I have found that it plays well with 2, we each play 3 colors and use the overcrowded variant. This helps ensure lots of meeples getting eaten. - Extremely easy to teach, making it a great family game. - Beautiful components, especially the sea creatures.[/i]
item.conditiontext:
Condition: Very good, components are stored in the original insert (which is really nice for this game).
Edition: English fourth edition (30th anniversary)
Sweeteners: Survive: Escape from Atlantis! 5-6 Player Mini Expansion Survive: Escape from Atlantis! Dolphins & Dive Dice Mini Extension Survive: Escape from Atlantis! The Giant Squid Mini Expansion
[i]*I will only trade with all the expansions included.[/i]

item.name: Survive: Escape from Atlantis! 5-6 Player Mini Expansion
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Survive: 5-6 Player Mini Expansion[/COLOR]
My thoughts:
[i]This is my favorite mini expansion for Survive and the only one I would buy if I were to get the game again. I love the game with 5 or 6 when playing the overcrowded variant. Also, when we play 3 players we each control two colors of meeples and use the overcrowded variant. Again this adds to the ensuing carnage and hilarity that ensues.[/i]
item.conditiontext: Will only trade with base game.

item.name: Survive: Escape from Atlantis! Dolphins & Dive Dice Mini Extension
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Survive: Dolphins and Dive Dice Mini Expansion[/COLOR]
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]4[/COLOR]):
[i]I am rethinking my initial thoughts after playing with the dive dice a lot. I find that there are too many turns when you are just moving a boat or a dolphin. I definitely prefer the red die. On top of that the dolphins are way under powered compared to the tile. Dolphin meeples protect swimmers, but they only move one space. The dolphin tile is actually useful because it allows you to move a swimmer 3 spaces.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]Much prefer the dive dice versus the red creature die. The expansion is worth it just for the dice. I could take or leave the dolphins, but my daughter loves them so we always play with them.[/i]
item.conditiontext: Will only trade with base game.

item.name: Survive: Escape from Atlantis! The Giant Squid Mini Expansion
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Survive: Giant Squid Mini Expansion[/COLOR]
My thoughts:
[i]The squid are fun but not necessary although they look great on the board. We have definitely found that you rescue a lot less meeples because if you move a squid next to an island tile with a meeple on it the squid can eat the meeple. Because of this we use the squid once and a while; I would not recommend it to someone picking up the game.[/i]
item.conditiontext: Will only trade with base game.

item.name: Sushi Go!
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Sushi Go[/COLOR] was traded away with Great Heartland Hauling Company, Las Vegas Boulevard and Thunder Alley for Fleet/Fleet Arctic Bounty (with all KS rewards), Friday and Viva Java the Dice Game 12/29/14.
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
[i]After my initial excitement I ended up buying a copy. After a couple of plays our interest quickly faded and I ended up trading it. For my money Medieval Academy is the better drafting family/filler game (and even that game is on the bubble for me).[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Excellent gateway into card drafting games. - The art is perfect for this game, great color palette. - Quick filler that is perfect for beginning/ending a game night. - Plays great with 3+ players. - Excellent card quality except the backs of the soy sauce promo don't match my copy.[/i]
item.conditiontext: Excellent condition, played once. Cards have a linen finish in my edition.

item.name: Sylvion
item.comment:
[i]- Some of the best artwork I've ever seen [-]in a board game[/-], period. - This art in the game creates this surreal world which really immerses me in the game. - I love the way you draft the deck of cards you're going to play and it also increase replay and encourages you to try different deck compositions. - This is a tower defense game that I don't need a computer to play! - You can easily set this up and play in 30 minutes or less.
Up until recently I haven'y played many solo games [i](well since playing Risk solo as a kid)[/i], but I was drawn to this game and Onirim because of the art. I'm happy to say this game also delivered on creating a really fun solo game that is quick to set up and delivers a fun tower defense style card game.[/i]

item.name: Taj Mahal
item.comment:
[i]This game fell completely flat for me. The different actions in the game did not coalesce into a fun gaming experience. The set collection is very basic and underwhelming, the route building served as a means to an end, but the bidding was somewhat interesting although it felt clunky.
I think that sums up my feelings on this game perfectly, Taj Mahal is a clunky and counter intuitive game to play. Where as I feel that Medici, Modern Art and Ra all offer elegant and simple rules, my play of Taj Mahal felt like a slog. The previous 3 games can be taught in a matter of minutes and even if you don't play well it's more of a lack of understanding of the perceived value of the various items you are collecting; the actual bidding/auction mechanics are clean and intuitive. I can't say the same for Taj Mahal, and there is really nothing there that is calling me back to play it again (especially since I could be playing Modern Art, Ra or Medici).[/i]

item.name: Takenoko
item.comment:
Christmas gift 2013 (Madeline)
[i]- This is by far the most beautiful game we own; I love looking at the board as we play with all the bamboo growing. - The panda and farmer are really well painted minis. - The game oozes charm; people will be drawn in because of the great components. - Easy to learn rules (we do not play with any variants).
I believe this is an excellent family/gateway game with easy to pick up rules. Takenoko oozes charm; people will be drawn in because of the great components. This game does have some luck involved, but that is great for a family game that you are going to play with younger kids and more casual gamers.[/i]
Plays 20+ have included the Chibis expansion.

item.name: Takenoko: Chibis
item.comment:
[i]- This expansion just makes Takenoko even more fun! All of the additions enhance game play and build on what players already know, there isn't any added complexity. - Mama panda is adorable, my girls instantly fell in love with her. - Added scoring cards which add more global challenges (x # of watered tiles of a color, etc.). - The new* tiles are all awesome and help pick up the pace of the game. - Panda babies which give you points and a one time special ability. - In my opinion one of the few "must have" expansions I own.
*New tiles - an extra water tile, a tile that can grow all 3 colors of bamboo, 1 tile in each color that grows bamboo on all the same colored tiles and one that lets you look through the top card of each deck and choose 1.[/i]

item.name: Tales of the Arabian Nights
item.comment:
This game was a fun story telling adventure. There is really not a game here, but there were some funny moments. You have absolutely no control over your destiny.
Saying all this, I think it would be a fun time to play this with some non gaming friends while enjoying a few cocktails.

item.name: Targi
item.comment:
Received in a math trade (4/14/14).
[i]- Excellent 2p only worker placement game. - The board is laid out in a grid which adds a spacial element to placing your workers. - Once you place your workers you will get the good/action on that card and the cards where your workers intersect in the grid. - Cards on the edge are always the same, but the cards in the middle rotate between goods tiles and tribal cards (which award points). - Tribal cards have different synergies between them. - When you play a tribal card you also have to consider it's placement in your tableau because this will effect how you score it.
Overall this is an extremely innovative worker placement game that I would highly recommend. It has become one of my favorites and I haven't played another wp game that feels at all similar.[/i]

item.name: Temporum
item.comment:
Another game that was donated to the library from Rio grande. I was interested in playing this partly because most of Donald X's games do not click with me [i](Dominion, Greed and now this)[/i]. The one game I enjoyed was Kingdom Builder [i](I only played once but I am looking forward to getting an opportunity to play again)[/i].
I though the game was mechanically sound, but it did not feel like a time travel game at all. It is another play a card, take some gold or points and move on. This game did nothing to stand out to me, and the whole switch time between 2 different cards felt very unnecessary since both locations allowed you to do similar things. On top of that I found the artwork and components to be quite blah and uninspired.

item.name: Terra Mystica
item.comment: Highlights: - The first thing you get is your own faction to play, each with a very distinctive set of powers/ play style. - This game is heavy, but it does not take long to understand how the game works. - There are a lot of variables in the game which will make each game a unique experience. - There is so much you want to do, but your actions are limited really forcing you to focus on how you are going to score points. [i]This particular aspect of the game reminds me of Agricola and is something that I personally love in games.[/i]
item.wishlistcomment: [i]Loved every play of this so far and my older daughter is getting to the point were I think she could handle Decided that I'm going to probably wait till next summer (2016), maybe I can get a play in with my kids and Mat.[/i]

item.name: Thebes: The Tomb Raiders
item.comment:
Received in a math trade (3/12/14).
[i]- Works well with all player counts (2 - 4) although I find it to be a bit easier with just 2 since there is less competition over the cards. - Great adaptation of Thebes as a card game - I really like how the different draw piles refill, you are never sure when the right time to dig is. - Multiple ways to get vp: most knowledge of a color, museum shows, trading in artifacts and the artifacts themselves. - Turn order is dependent on how long your actions take, like Glen More and Thebes you could potentially have multiple turns if you take actions that don't cost a lot of time. - Even though they are hobbit cards, they a really good quality. - Excellent family game![/i]

item.name: Thunder Alley
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Thunder Alley[/COLOR] was traded away with Great Heartland Hauling Company, Las Vegas Boulevard and Sushi Go for Fleet/Fleet Arctic Bounty (with all KS rewards), Friday and Viva Java the Dice Game 12/29/14.
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]8[/COLOR]):
[i]This is a tough one for me to talk about a year later. Obviously it didn't stand the test of time, but part of that was due to my wife and son really disliking the game (which really surprised me). I think the game length was the real deterrent and I also felt that it ran long for what it offered. With that said, I still think this was a really fun racing game with some great card play. My daughter loved this game, but we never played with 2, I thought the experience would be anti climactic since you're only racing one other person.
I would still enjoy playing the occasional game and a buddy of mine has a copy so hopefully that would happen. Due to the length of the game I'd be happy to play Thunder Alley once or twice a year.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (9):
[i]- You feel like you are racing a team of cars, this game is fun! - This is an excellent family game, my kids love it. - The rules are pretty straight forward and it is really easy to teach once you are comfortable with the rules. - The card based play is great, it adds a different kind of strategy than dice would. - The different types of movement really give you lots of options when deciding on which car to activate with which card. - The damage tokens add tension to the game without being overly punishing. - Really nice production, you get four race tracks in the box![/i]
item.conditiontext: Excellent condition, also note all the chits have been trimmed using a counter cutter. All the components are bagged.

item.name: Thunderbirds
item.comment:
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]My biggest surprise of the month, especially considering that I'm not a huge fan of co-ops. The game play was both fun and familiar (I think I've played all of Matt Leacock's co-op games) so we were able to dive right in after a very short rules explanation. For me it was the theme that made this game truly shine even though I'm not huge Thunderbirds fan; it was the fact that all of us role played our characters making the game extremely funny and a blast to play.[/i]

item.name: Thurn and Taxis
item.comment:
I was really interested in trying it out since there are definitely some gamers that prefer this over TTR [i](which is a game I love)[/i].
Well Joel was right, I played a game with my two older kids and we weren't impressed. [-]I really didn't like the hand management aspect of the game [i](every time you finished a route you lost your cards)[/i], that pretty much killed the game for me.[/-] [i](I found out I was playing the game wrong, you only discard down to 3 cards)[/i]. As others have noted, I felt that the game really pushed you to get your 7 carriage as quickly as possible, making the game somewhat one dimensional.

item.name: Ticket to Ride
item.comment:
Received in a trade (3/3/14).
[i]We didn't play this game until we had been gaming for over 1.5 years. I was hesitant to get it because I thought we would find it too light, well I was wrong my whole family enjoys this game.
- Simplicity of choices: take trains, build routes, choose new route cards. - My wife loves it! - A very fun, relaxing game to play. (In the same vein as Finca and Takenoko) Don't get me wrong, things still get tense when you think you have been cut out of a certain city, but usually you can find some way to get where you need to go.[/i]
3 plays on the Legendary Asia map 4 plays on the Team Asia map 5 plays on the Switzerland map 2 plays on the India map

item.name: Ticket to Ride Map Collection: Volume 1 – Team Asia & Legendary Asia
item.comment:
Received in a math trade (1/12/15).
[i]- 2 new maps that completely change the feel of the game... - The Team Asia map forces you to pay attention to what your teammate is doing so you can help them [i](you can't discuss/show them your hand/tickets)[/i]. - The Legendary Asia map adds mountain routes (you need to spend extra trains to complete them), which can really push the end game. - the Legendary Asia map also has ferry routes which give added importance to the locomotive cards.[/i]

item.name: Ticket to Ride Map Collection: Volume 2 – India & Switzerland
item.comment:
Received in a math trade (3/17/15).
[i]- Switzerland map is excellent for 2p. - India map is great with 3, the bonus scoring (the Mandala) is fun and challenging and really makes you plan differently when building routes.[/i]

item.name: Ticket to Ride: USA 1910
item.comment: [i]In my opinion a must have expansion for the following reasons: 1. Full sized cards 2. Additional destination tickets which allow you to play with different sets of cards (Big Cities, Mega variant, 1910, etc.) 3. Significantly improves 2 player game[/i]

item.name: Tides of Time
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Tides of Time[/COLOR] was traded away for the NY 1901 Flatiron expansion 11/1/15.
[i]Initial thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
Tides of Time is definitely a fun 2p drafting micro game, but it's still a micro game. The game play is clever, there are plenty of choices to be made when it comes to the end of each age and you need to decide which card to build (and permanently have in your tableau) and which one to remove. It's a testament to the designer that he could pack in so many decisions into an 18 card deck. I have enjoyed my plays of the game , but in the end I am left wishing that this had been developed into a full fledged game instead of a microgame (selfish I know).
All that said I would definitely recommend checking ToT out, especially since it is so inexpensive and portable. It is by far the best micro game I've played (but I'm realizing that micro games just aren't my thing).[/i]

item.name: Tigris & Euphrates
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Tigris and Euphrates[/COLOR] was traded away for Among the Stars and Qwixx 12/18/14.
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]10[/COLOR]):
[i]I still think this is an amazing game and hopefully I will get to play it more. This is definitely a game that requires repeated play in order to start to pick up all the nuances of game play. As is often joked about, this has been a game I've brought to meet ups and it's usually ignored. I was hoping with the reprint that there would be some renewed interest, but so far I haven't seen it.
I am glad to have played this classic game, it provides a lot of insight into modern board game design and in my opinion is a must play game.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (9):
[i]Absolutely loved my first play of this with my family. It only took one play to realize why this game is considered a classic.
- Brilliant scoring system; you need to make sure that you are scoring points consistently in all four colors. - Love the interaction between the leaders, there is only conflict if two of the same type of leader are in the same territory. - Two types of conflict (revolution versus war) which are both caused/resolved using different tiles. - Accessible to my older kids (9 and 12), but they have played a lot of other games. - I am one of those people that find this game thematic (even though you are collecting colored cubes for vp). I thing it is interesting to watch the territories grow and expand and then splinter off into different territories. The monuments make thematic sense, they are the artistic pinnacle of each civilization. Granted everything takes place on a very macro level, but I think the civilization building theme makes sense.[/i]
item.conditiontext: New in shrink.

item.name: Times Square
item.comment: Was taught this game by Mat and thought it was okay. While some of the different restraints on moving the various pieces was interesting (especially how the diva only moved between her two bodyguards) it is not a game I feel the need to add to my collection. I find some of Knizia's other card games are not only more streamlined, but also offer more interesting tactical decisions ([thing=760][/thing] springs to mind). I also prefer the push your luck aspect found in [thing=50][/thing].

item.name: Tiny Epic Galaxies
item.comment:
[i]I really enjoyed my play of TE Galaxies a lot more than the Kingdoms. Similar to a game like RftG because this game is definitely a race, you are trying to maximize your die rolls to capture planets and score points. The dice in work well, there is plenty you can do on your turn to mitigate luck (especially since you can burn energy to re-roll any number of dice as many times as you want). Most of the planet abilities offer you the ability to manipulate one aspect of the game, whether it be gaining a specific type of resource or helping you capture planets. I think it was an excellent decision for your opponents to also benefit from the planet actions, you always recieve more of a benefit but you need to be careful what the ramifications are to helping out your opponent(s).
I'm not sure whether this is a + or - but this game is definitely a filler. There are decisions to be made, but there is not a lot of variance in how the game will play out. There didn't seem to be radically different strategies, just slight tweaks in how you go about winning the game. Therefore for me it is a pass since I think the engine driving the game is similar to RftG or Roll and I'd rather play either of those games since they offer a lot more depth and variety in the way you go about building your engine (Race plays quicker, Roll may be a bit longer than Galaxies). That said if you are looking for a simpler engine building/race game I would recommend checking out TE Galaxies and I would definitely play again.[/i]

item.name: To Court the King
item.comment:
This was a fun dice rolling game where you got to buy cards [i](using your die rolls)[/i] which let you manipulate dice in some way or give you extra dice to roll. I had a lot of fun playing, but I felt like the game went long with 4 players (my guess is 3 would be the sweet spot) and by the end you have a bunch of cards/abilities to manage. While we didn't have any problems doing that I don't think this would make a great gateway game even though it is quite light.
[i]In the end I am glad that I played it [i](since I am always looking for new dice games to play)[/i] but it doesn't come close to challenging any of my favorites [i]([thing=147431][/thing], [thing=139899][/thing] or [thing=131260][/thing])[/i] for a spot in my collection.[/i]

item.name: Tobago
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Tobago[/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 3/12/14. (Received Jamaica)
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
[i]As a family we never really got into Tobago. The bits were beautiful, but there were parts of the game that really fell flat for us. Our two biggest problems were the SUV movement and the treasure mechanic. As far as the SUV movement was concerned it was not very intuitive and if you started using amulets you really had too pay attention to how many movement actions you used. The push your luck element with the treasure deck was never that exciting; sometimes it felt like you did all this work only to get nothing because a curse popped up before you had a chance to grab some loot.
In the end we loved playing cards to locate the treasure, but that was not enough to save it from being traded after a few plays.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Component quality: This game has some beautiful wooden huts, palm trees and jeeps plus these amazing Easter Island statues. The board is made up of 3 sections that can be attached in different ways to create over 30 different maps. The game oozes theme thanks to the beautiful components. - We love narrowing down where treasure is located by playing cards, a really innovative mechanic. - Amulets: add some variety to the game by letting you perform extra actions and protecting you from curses. - Driving your jeep around the board is just fun. - I love the push your luck element to disperse the treasure.
I believe this is an excellent family/gateway game with easy to pick up rules. It is not a game we will play every day/week, but I can see us pulling it out once or twice a month and enjoying it.[/i]

item.name: Tokaido
item.comment:
[i]I really had a great time playing this game, it was completely laid back and chill. We played with the Crossroads expansion and to be honest I think I would enjoy just playing the base game. I wouldn't go into a game of Tokaido looking for depth of strategy, in my opinion it is an experience game. You truly feel like you are walking along this path and experiencing the journey.
When you are looking for a game to play after a particularly stressful day and you need to relax take Tokaido off the shelf, sit back and enjoy a sublime experience.[/i]
item.wishlistcomment: [i]Really enjoyed this one, another zen game. The problem is it probably wouldn't get much play after the first few games since I don't think it be a stand out with my kids.[/i]

item.name: Traders of Osaka
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Traders of Osaka[/COLOR] was sold via auction 11/5/15.
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- I love the art/Japanese theme of the second edition. - Set up is a breeze, plays fast and is excellent with 2. - Relatively small footprint making it an excellent pub/cafe game. - Speaking of footprint, kudos to Z-Man for packaging this in a small box! - This game has a lot of take that, but it's not nasty which makes it a great game to play with older kids. - This is a simple game, but it demands planning ahead and really figuring out how to manipulate the market to make sure you benefit when boats get scored (and make sure you don't lose goods when boats get caught in the tidal waves).[/i]

item.name: Trains
item.comment:
Highlights: - A deck builder with a board - Scoring based on the tracks you lay and cards you can purchase - I enjoy having to manage the waste cards that you build up, it adds some tension to the game.
I will admit that I was hesitant at first when this game got brought out because I really don't like Dominion. Definitely high on my want to play again list, especially with my family.

item.name: Trajan
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Trajan[/COLOR] was received in a math trade (2/7/15) Sold via auction 4/4/15.
[i]I really enjoyed this game, but unfortunately I can not imagine anyone in my family wanting to play this. The multiple ways to score points in conjunction with managing your mancala would probably even overwhelm my son. The guys I played with played at a brisk pace, but I can see this game inducing AP in lots of people. I would love to play Trajan again.[/i]
item.conditiontext:
Condition: New in shrink (the shrink is peeled in a few areas).
Edition: English first edition

item.name: Trambahn
item.comment: [i]- Another hit in the Lookout 2p player line [i](which in my opinion has replaced the Kosmos 2p series of games in terms of quality)[/i]. - Relatively small footprint making it a great cafe/pub game. - The theme is a little dry, but thankfully the choice of art is awesome [i](Lookout used historic illustrations and original art by Klemens Franz)[/i]. - Another new game that builds on Lost Cities and, in my opinion, is a superior game [i]([thing=163056][/thing] and [thing=140934][/thing] being the other two)[/i]. - Multi use cards [i]( cards can be played as currency, train routes or passengers).[/i] - A very tense hand management game, routes always need to be played in ascending order [i](a la Lost Cities)[/i] and you must have trains you purchased to keep your routes in play . - Probably the most innovative mechanism in the game is how scoring works. In a nut shell you are playing passengers to certain stations and once there are 4 passengers all routes of that color score [i](whether or not you and your opponent have any routes in that color)[/i]. After 10 scoring rounds the game is over, this really keeps the game moving and can really mess you over if you don't get into rhythm with the scoring rounds.[/i]
item.wishlistcomment: [i]Really interested in the newest 2p from Lookout, but I'm waiting to see a few videos to figure out if it would break into our 2p game rotation.[/i]

item.name: TROLL
item.comment:
[i]I absolutely love the aesthetic of this game. I always appreciate minimal design and the art in this game pulls it off quite well.
The game play is fun, if a bit wonky. The rules are obtuse and make everything sound much more complex than it is. In the end it is a very simple push your luck game with great art. I do think that the game can devolve into a betting game in later rounds because you have no choice but to try and score big knowing you have no other way to win. This could potentially dilute the experience and make it less about bluffing and more about gambling. Still, I had fun playing and think this could definitely be a fun, family game. I'm looking forward to playing it again.[/i]

item.name: Tzolk'in: The Mayan Calendar
item.comment:
Highlights: - Beautiful production, even with unpainted gears. - The artwork on the board/tiles really evokes the theme in a very simple/clean way. - A unique entry into the worker placement genre that feels fresh and different. - Planning and using the gear mechanism well is a delicious puzzle to solve. - This is a game you continue to think about after you play, there is a ton of decision space to explore.
[i]I really enjoyed my play of this game even though my mind was reeling trying to effectively plan the placement/removal of my workers.[/i]

item.name: Uchronia
item.comment:
I have been wanting to play this one for a while since I really like Glory to Rome. Personally I found this to be a far cry from GtR; in my opinion all of the tension and interesting card synergies are missing. The locations are all very lackluster and are just worth 1, 2 or 3 points with very generic powers. The worst part of the game is how poorly the theme is tied into the game. Dinosaurs, awesome... except none of the theme comes through with any of the cards.
[i]This game was another disappointment and not something I would seek out to play again.[/i]

item.name: Via Appia
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Via Appia[/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 5/15/14 with Drizzt. (Received 1775:Rebellion)
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
[i]My initial thought were pretty accurate, this is a beautifully produced game with some strategy. After multiple plays the game felt very samey and eventually the rock crushing mechanic was not enough of a draw to get this one to the table. Via Appia also suffers from a similar problem as Kingsburg; about 3/4 of the way through the game you pretty much know who is going to win. There are not enough hidden points in the game to add much doubt as to who is going to win. Add to the fact that it really doesn't play well with 2 and this game ended up languishing on our shelves for a while before I traded it.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]First of all this is a beautifully produced game, everything is top notch. The rock "crushing" part of the game is the highlight, the rest of the game is okay. There is some light strategy in this game. This game plays best with 3 or 4, I would not recommend it as a 2p game (there seems to be a runaway leader problem.)
Overall I would recommend this game to families looking for a light weight game everyone will enjoy. I think this game would work well with younger children (I would say 6+).[/i]

item.name: Vikings
item.comment:
Originally received in a math trade (11/10/14), reacquired 11/14/15. Traded away in a math trade 3/17/15. (Received Eclipse)
Highlights: - Plays great with 2 and is a great family game. - Tile laying: one of my favorite mechanics in games especially when it is not the [i]only[/i] mechanic. - The market wheel: Innovative mechanic that determines how much a certain tile/veeple set is going to cost. [i]This creates a lot of tense moments when you try to determine whether you can wait one more round to get the tile/veeple you need for a lower price.[/i] - Bonus tiles add more strategy to the game without adding a lot of new rules or added complexity.

item.name: Viticulture
item.comment: Highlights - A worker placement game that also is a race to [i]x[/i] number of victory points, awesome because you really have no time to waste. - Theme, I love wine and instantly felt immersed in the theme of this game. - Played really well with 2, the game still felt tight and spaces were hotly contested. - Optimization, I love building and optimizing an engine to generate a commodity which is then converted into money or points. - I appreciate any wp game that allows you to select a space someone else already chose [i](in this game you have one "large" worker that can share a space with another worker)[/i].

item.name: VivaJava: The Coffee Game: The Dice Game
item.comment:
Received in a trade (12/29/14).
[i]Highlights: - Fun dice filler with a theme I love (Mmmm... coffee). - Easy to teach/learn and it plays quick. - Nice component quality, especially the dice. - Research abilities add some strategy to the game.[/i]

item.name: Vs. System 2PCG
item.comment:
Received in a math trade. (10/5/15)
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- An excellent head to head 2p game that was also quite fun as a 3p free for all match. - The superhero theme shines through, the character abilities fit each of the different characters (Hulk's my favorite). - There is a ton of variety in this game starting with the possible main characters you can play, the supporting characters, plot twists and then each group of heroes are different from one another (the base game includes the X-men, Avengers, Guardians of the Galaxy and Villains). - Deck building is not usually my thing, but it is really easy to tweak your decks especially since we want to limit each deck to one affiliation. - Set up is a breeze compared to a game like Marvel Legendary.
This game has become a huge hit with my son and my daughter can't wait to play. I have a feeling this will fill two holes in our collection, both Summoner Wars (a 2+ player fighting game) and Marvel Legendary (a thematic superhero game). This game wasn't even on my radar, but I had an opportunity to play with one of the designers (who I meet through another friend) and had a blast. This game offers everything I wanted out of a superhero game, head to head battles instead of a semi co-op game.[/i]

item.name: Waggle Dance
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Waggle Dance[/COLOR] was sold via auction 8/8/15.
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- Perfect gateway/family game for a dice worker placement game. [i](My kids love this game.)[/i] - Excellent rule book that really makes learning/teaching this game a breeze. - The components and artwork are amazing [i](the dice have honeycombs for the pips and the 1 is a bee)[/i]. - Great tie in between the game mechanisms and theme [i](e.g. you get eggs and then hatch them to get new worker dice).[/i] - Waggle Dance is another relaxing game to play in the vein of Takenoko and Finca.[/i]

item.name: Walk the Plank!
item.comment:
Yankee swap 2014
Highlights: - Fast, fun filler game that you can teach anyone in 60 seconds (And most of our games lasted 10 minutes or less). - Pre-programmed movement, but you are setting up 3 moves at a time. By the time you get to your third move you may end up running right of the plank and meet your untimely demise. - The artwork is really good with nice components and pirate meeples. - This game is funny; it is hard not to laugh at the chaos that unfolds as the game progresses.

item.name: Walnut Grove
item.comment: Highlights: - A quick, extremely tight worker placement game. - Tile laying; you are building out your land which will determine which goods you can harvest each round. - Having to work your way around town without being able to back track forces you to plan multiple moves in advance. - The random season disc really forces you to think on your feet because you never know what the feeding/heating situation will be.

item.name: Wasabi!
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Wasabi[/COLOR] was sold via auction 4/20/15. Received in a math trade (1/12/15).
Updated thoughts and rating coming soon...
Initial thoughts and rating (10):
[i]- Excellent family game that plays great with 2, [i](although the game doesn't feel as cut throat compared to a 3p or 4p game)[/i]. - Great artwork, it is very clean, and beautiful components especially the glossy tiles and the bowls used to hold your wasabi cubes. - Very simple rule set which makes this game a breeze to teach while still offering plenty of depth and strategy. - Tile laying with a lot of great player interaction, especially with the bonus cards. - The bonus cards give you the opportunity to manipulate the board state in different ways. - Recipe management; you can work on three recipes at a time, but you choose from 2, 3, 4 and 5 ingredient recipes. [i]Completing smaller recipes will earn you power cards quickly while the bigger recipes offer much better scoring opportunities.[/i] - Wasabi cubes, completing recipes "in style" [i](ingredients placed in the order shown on the recipe card)[/i] will earn you bonus points in the form of wasabi cubes (and serve as the tie breaker).[/i]
item.conditiontext:
Condition: Very good, the box does show some minor shelf wear. All of the game pieces are in great shape.
Edition: Z-Man games, I believe first edition [i](not sure how to tell)[/i]

item.name: Wildlife Safari
item.comment:
Highlights: - Awesome family filler game that my kids really enjoyed. - Everyone in my gaming group also enjoyed it when they played. - Great bits (namely the plastic animals) that my kids loved. - Another Knizia with a great scoring system; trying to time when to play your high value cards before the game ends while not giving someone else the opportunity to play a low number. - In essence this is a stock market manipulation game. You can take any animal you want, no matter what animal card you played which allows you to hedge your bets.
[i]I immediately added this to my wishlist and then found out they are changing the name which in my opinion is awful (from Botswana to Wildlife Safari). I hope I can find a copy of Botswana for a reasonable price.[/i]

item.name: Wir sind das Volk!
item.comment:
Highlights:
- The theme/historical basis of this game shines through. [i]This game is a perfect vehicle point for getting kids to become interested in the history of East and West Germany and how it impacted the rest of the world. [/i] - The game play is extremely smooth and intuitive. It will take a few plays to remember how the end of decade scoring works, but everything happening not only makes sense, it also ties in perfectly with the theme. - Multi-use cards (which usually have an alignment to one of the two sides), each card functions in multiple ways and the decision of how to use each card really makes you think about your long term strategy [i](usually based on what your opponent is doing)[/i]. - A shared card pool, each turn you are selecting a card to play from a shared row. This creates some wonderful tension as you way the benefits of a card that will help you, versus leaving a card you know will be a boon to your opponent. - It's fun! Seriously, a game like this could crumble under it's own weight but Wir... manages to keep the game play snappy and the rules overhead low creating a really snappy, fun play experience.
[i]There are many more things I could say about Wir... but really you need to play this game to really appreciate what a brilliant design it is. Kudos to the designers Richard Sivél and Peer Sylvester for creating such an elegant game. I'm really looking forward to getting in more plays of this brilliant game.[/i]

item.name: Würfel Bohnanza
item.comment: [i]- Nice dice with great artwork on them. My only complaint is that it is not easy to tell the difference between the white and cream colored dice. - Turns are quick; plus you are always engaged since you can fill orders when it is someone else's turn. - While there are not a lot of decisions to be made during the game, there is a nice push your luck element when deciding whether or not to score a card. - The fact that you can sell at anytime allows you to sell one card and then start the next one with the same pool of dice keep the game moving.[/i]

item.name: Wyatt Earp
item.comment:
player powers. I especially liked the addition of adding money to the wanted posters which you will then collect during the scoring phase depending on the melds you have versus just playing melds in front of you for points. I also really enjoyed the theme, this was a very pleasant surprise.
[i]I am looking forward to playing this again, I would definitely like to try it with more than 2 to see how it changes the game. However; if I was going to add a Mike Fitzgerald card game to my collection I think I would go with [thing=151022][/thing].[/i]

item.name: Yahtzee Free for All
item.comment: [i]I got to play this with Mat and his wife and cousin while enjoying some fine :tankard:. Excellent Yahtzee variant, I've played lots of Yahtzee and this version is much better. Perfect game to play while chatting with friends.[/i]

item.name: Yardmaster
item.comment:
Received in a math trade (1/5/15).
[i]- Perfect cafe game, small footprint and plays fast. - This is a great gateway/ family game. - Easy rule set to learn/teach. - Plays well with 2.[/i]

item.name: Yspahan
item.comment:
I enjoyed my play of this game, but it is not a game I feel the need to seek out. Drafting from the dice pool was fun, but the choices you had to make seemed to be obvious most of the time. Most of the "difficult" decisions came when you were the one who rolled the dice and therefore got to choose first.
Overall I had fun, the game played quick and had enough light decisions to make it interesting. I think this would make a great, light family game that introduces some different game mechanics in a very easy to learn manner.

item.name: Zeus on the Loose
item.comment: This is another game I don't feel the need to play again. I found there to be very little strategy in this game and there are a lot of other light card games I would rather play/teach.

item.name: Zooloretto
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Zooloretto[/COLOR] was traded away in a math trade 9/14/14. (Received Thebes) Received in a trade(6/22/14). I traded away Cockroach Poker, Haggis and Legendary Fantastic 4.
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]6[/COLOR]):
[i]This game started off strong, but after the initial 3 plays my daughter was really the only one interested in playing. We tried it with 2, but it fell flat. I wouldn't recommend it with 2 players, I think you need at least 3 to make it interesting and it's best with 4.
I really enjoyed pulling the animals out of the bag, placing them in the trucks and having to decide when to grab that truck versus pushing your luck for one more turn. However; after that the game got kind of boring. Placing your animals wasn't that exciting and I hated how artificial it felt to build the carts in your park since they only gave you points based on a set collection mechanic. We also have Zooloretto Dice and it is one instance were I think the pared down version of a game is much better.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]The dice game plays much quicker, plays well with 2, still has beautiful components and manages to capture the feel of it's big brother (especially the tension in deciding how to split up your animals in the trucks and when to take a truck versus pushing your luck and rolling more dice). Highlights: - Theme really comes through because of the art/production. - Awesome family game that plays well with 3 and 4, haven't tried a 2p game yet. - Simple mechanics that work well together and still offer some difficult choices to make each turn. - Filling the trucks with animals: this is the meat of the game to me, when do you take a truck and when do you push your luck and hope to draw another animal you really need. Of course then someone else can snatch that truck from you. - Coins: they help you have more control over your zoo and move animals around or buy them from other peoples barns.[/i]

item.name: Zooloretto: The Dice Game
item.comment:
[COLOR=#FF0000]Zooloretto: The Dice Game[/COLOR] was sold via auction...
Updated thoughts and rating ([COLOR=#FF0000]8[/COLOR]):
[i]I picked this up for my daughter at Total Con and I have actually come to enjoy the game more now than when I first picked it up. This is definitely a direct result of my having picked up Zooloretto over the summer and playing that. I thought Zooloretto dragged on for what it was and the dice version condensed the game down to my favorite part - loading and taking trucks. Zooloretto dice packs in all the tension/push your luck of deciding when to chance rolling the dice again versus taking a truck that will help you and packs it into a quick playing dice filler.
However; after a bunch of plays the game has wore out it's welcome and started to feel very samey. It was fun while it lasted, but there just isn't enough variety game to game to merit it's staying in our collection.[/i]
Initial thoughts and rating (8):
[i]- My daughter loves it, especially the theme. - The dice are beautiful (really nice animal silhouettes engraved into the wooden dice). - The score sheets are in full color with some nice art. This helps get the theme across. - Quick, fun family game that younger children could easily play. - However; there is some strategy involved with placing dice in the trucks and deciding when to stop rolling and pick animals. - This is a very well designed, light filler game.
I highly recommend this game for kids, it is a game they could easily teach to their friends and play on their own. After owning/playing Zooloretto I would rather play this version and traded away my copy of Zooloretto.[/i]
